title.narrative: Dec19 Beslut om ändring av insats, Icddr,b forskningssamarbete 2016-2020
Feb18 Beslut om avtalsändring, Icddr,b forskningssamarbete 2016-2020
ICDDR,B/International Centre for Diarrhoeal Disease Research
Mars19 Beslut om avtalsändring, Icddr,b forskningssamarbete 2016-2020

description.narrative: In 2019, the support to icddr,b from the Swedish Embassy in Dhaka had phased out, with the exception of a training in intellectual property rights (IPR) and the initiation of an evaluation (joint by Embassy and FORSK). This was also true for spring 2020. In addition to the research support, additional support from Sida SOCIAL was initiated and activities started in May 2020. Reporting for this component is done separately, as it is handled by SOCIAL. An interim report was assessed in June 2020. Related to the covid-19 pandemic, there are a lot of delays in the “original” programme, but also some interesting new results and initiatives, and even an improvement when it comes to some training programmes. The pandemic is still ongoing (Aug 2020) and there are a lot of uncertainties of future activities. At icddr,b a major part of staff and activities are directed towards supporting Bangladesh. Researchers, who are often also clinicians or nurses, have put their research on hold in benefit of serving as health personnel. According to our main contact at icddr,b, Bangladesh is the most impacted country when it comes to fatalities of health staff due to lack of protective gear (PPE). There are also several icddr,b professionals who have deceased in the past few months. In addition to these challenges, a third of the country is flooded. Icddr,b support the Government in the analysis of covid-19 infections, and have tested 48 154 samples as of Aug 18th, in part from 9 different district-level hospitals. They also do community surveillance and different research projects to inform policies/strategies as well as developing methods to limit the spread and impact of the disease. icddr,b were selected to conduct the third-phase trial of a potential COVID-19 vaccine developed by China's Sinovac Biotech Ltd. As Sida provides funding from global strategies, we cannot support work that is directly targeting Bangladesh without the possibility to also benefit other countries. But icddr,b also has the possibility to contribute to the global pool of knowledge and innovation, and the support from SOCIAL has a special focus on these issues, with a focus on WASH and urban settings. The research support is used in projects and trainings that can still take place virtually, as well as two additional projects which were approved after one researcher had to leave her project: - “Optimising the treatment of COVID-19 adults with severe pneumonia and/or ARDS in Bangladesh”, using an adaptive version of locally made Bubble CPAP. The nasal interface needs to be adapted (to minimize potential nasal leakage of oxygen during the delivery of oxygen to adult COVID 19 affected patients and simultaneously to attain adequate positive airway pressure). It took engineers almost two months to prepare this adaptive nasal interface as during the COVID 19 crisis it took more time to arrange silicon materials to prepare the nasal interface (with 3D interpretation) with the help of local plastic company. The research protocol is now with the icddr,b Research Review Committee and Ethical Review Committee, and they are planning to start the design and safety phases of the study by the end of September. - “Clinical evaluation of a point-of-need diagnostic system for detection of COVID-19 towards its deployment at peripheral health care settings”, where lab works for initial validation and optimization of the laboratory SOPs. Meanwhile, all RNA samples from 100 COVID-19 patients have been retrieved, as well as equal number of controls, and the experimentation will start in the coming month. Training takes place by digital means, and interestingly this has been received very well. Some citations from the online training on Research Protocol Development: “The COVID-19 situation has created an intense mental pressure on all of us. The vigorous discussions, intense group work, supervision by the faculties throughout the course has relieved the anxiety by taking off our mind from all the negative news of the pandemic. This positive mental health is another side of this training I am grateful for”, “I am working in icddr,b for almost 10 years, but in the field. For the last 10 years I couldn’t join any capacity building program. Thanks to Sida, Research Administration and TTU to arrange this online course. Only for being an online course, I was able to join and I have learnt so many things”, and “I have participated in a lot of face-to-face training. Usually in a face-to-face training, one or two trainees dominate participation throughout the training. The aspect I love about this is that there is no first or last benchers in online training. Everyone can participate and speak out their mind with the same level of comfort”. An external evaluation of icddr,b was finalised in spring of 2020, with quite a few important comments regarding the research programme. The evaluation and Sida’s response is found in a separate file in Trac. The evaluation was financed jointly by the Embassy and FORSK, and evaluated both core support and research support. In general terms, it was a positive evaluation, clearly showing the importance of the center. The capacity building programme and the training are both important and successful programmes. Criticism was mainly regarding the underutilisation of the genomics facility, and although progress is being done it is important to follow the progress. In times of covid-19 the need for a national/regional resources is clear. Selected results from 2019: Icddr,b general Each year, millions of severely malnourished children fail to recover completely, remaining stunted and sickly even after they are well fed. Ten years of research has pointed to a root cause: Their gut microbes do not mature. 2019, an international team built on that research to come up with a low-cost, easy-to-obtain supplement that preferentially stimulates the growth of beneficial gut bacteria. The supplements performed well in a small trial, and larger scale clinical trials are now underway to see how well the supplement works to prevent stunting. Many countries will not be able to achieve the SDGs for malnutrition, according to icddr,b. As a result their brains do not develop properly and they remain susceptible to diseases for many years after. This is due to their gut microbes which remain in an immature state. Scientists from icddr,b and Washington University investigated the impact of diets on the gut microbiota, and how members of microbiota that are beneficial are affected positively. Another key outcome of this study was to see the effect of diets on proteins produced in the body of the children. These results were recognised as one of top ten scientific breakthroughs in 2019 by Science magazine (https://vis.sciencemag.org/breakthrough2019/finalists/#Microbes-combat) Sida support to young promising scientists Icddr,b writes in its report that “Sida support has in the past played a catalytic role for icddr,b; specially since it supports the young and upcoming researchers who otherwise finds it difficult to secure competitive funding from external sources at the beginning of their scientific career. It’s a unique mechanism of support as it gives icddr,b management the opportunity to invest in research areas of the Strategic Plan for which external funding is scarce. Sida’s project support has also aided in the career development of young scientists as funds can be budgeted for support from external experts on specific areas to assist them with their projects. Fund is also provided to young researchers for attending workshop/seminar to present their findings and data. This gives young researchers exposure and networking opportunity.” The selection of projects was done differently than the previous round, as decided by icddr,b's Senior Leadership Team (SLT) and discussed with Sida. The reason was to get better evaluations and feedback to the scientists. Each scientific division was asked to select the best five concepts from their divisions to allow those to be sent to the external scientific advisory group (SAG) for review. Each scientific division in icddr,b formed a gender balanced selection committee comprising of their senior and mid-level scientists and the applicants had to make a brief presentation to this committee. From this initial screening, a total number of 24 concept notes were short-listed out of which 11 were led by female researchers. This time it was much easier to get the target three reviews for each concept note from panel members of the SAG and as a result, it was easy to attain a meaningful average score for each application. Also, the reduced numbers made it possible for the SAG members to provide qualitative comments on the concept notes, which the young researchers always find very useful as guidance for future competition. With the available funding, it was possible to support 10 new projects out of which 4 were led by female scientists. The allocation of Sida funds based on a competitive peer- review process very successfully and this has been recognized not only by the young researchers at icddr,b but also by the Board, Senior Advisory Group (SAG) and senior management of icddr,b. As a result of this, icddr,b has now launched a similar competitive grant process for the young female researchers of icddr,b and beyond. The funding comes from a Prize awarded to icddr,b for its global impact. As an example of how Sida’s funds for the young researchers plays a catalytic role in their career is “the FluMI project” led by a researcher who not only benefitted from the data generated from this study for his PhD thesis in Australia, but his collaboration with National Institute of Cardio Vascular Diseases in Bangladesh later helped icddr,b in getting a multi-country project (IAMI). The researcher’s successor at icddr,b is now surveying myocardial infarction patients for influenza and SARS-COV-2. Another example of interesting research results is presented in the last part of this text. Training Good to know is the long-term partnership since 2011between icddr,b and Uppsala University for their Infectious Disease Course Masters Program. Between 2011 and 2017, TTU has trained around 140 Masters level students from Uppsala. During 2019, to meet the training needs of young scientists, the newly formed ‘Learning and Development Unit’ – a team combined of TTU (Technical Training Unit) and TD (Talent Development) offered training courses on 10 topics in 13 batches and trained 290 participants out of whom 48% were female. However, the total number of applications received for these trainings were 630. This means that a huge unmet need is there among the young scientists at icddr,b for such in-house trainings. Icddr,b identified training needs and prioritized based on the following four criteria: *Unmet needs of previous years' training; *Feedback from participants about their current needs; *Recommendations from the senior leadership team (SLT) and senior advisory group (SAG); *Data on training needs from performance management and development system (PMDS). Bubble CPAP The Bubble CPAP project with AHRI in Ethiopia completed its Phase I , but due to the delay in getting approval from the Ethiopian IRB for some amendments made to the original research protocol, which included changing a hospital because of not getting enough patients enrolled, the study progress got delayed. Genomics facility The external evaluation had a few critical comments on the genomics facility, and it is important to follow up on the progress. Especially the use was criticised. The centre is running both WGS and 16s metagenomics. Lately, the number of tests in the genomics center (GC) has gone up significantly. It went up from 131 in 2017 to 315 in 2019. The bioinformatics core at the GC is now consist of national and young scientists and it is no more dependent on hired international consultants. GC has been receiving samples from other national institutions such as East west university Bangladesh and Jessore University. The current performance rate is 62% and it was only 27% in 2017. The underutilization rate has dropped from 74% in 2017 to 38% now. The cost of the tests is now negotiable depending on the number of tests. An example of one of the finalised projects of young promising scientists: “A study to systematically document the implementation related challenges of Shasthyo Suroksha Karmasuchi (SSK, Health Protection Scheme) of the Government of Bangladesh”, a collaboration with two institutes in UK and Karolinska in Sweden. 18 months long and a budget of 85 600 USD. "The main aim of this study was to assess the implementation-related challenges of SSK scheme, and specifically challenges in below poverty line (BPL) population identification, barriers in the utilization of health services, and assessment of service knowledge among the beneficiaries. The results show that around 30% of the non-BPL household got included in the BPL list, in part because the listing is done seldomly. Since then, “many of them got a job, and they are not poor anymore”. The results also show that there is a lack of knowledge; among the surveyed SSK household, around 68% ever heard about the SSK scheme and 63% had knowledge about the process of healthcare provision under SSK scheme. However, a majority of the respondent didn’t have knowledge that SSK provides free medicine (54%), free diagnostic (75%), and reimbursement of transportation cost for referral facilities (87%). The households members included in the survey, around 25% of them suffered from illness in the last three month. Among them, 82% utilized healthcare from different sources. However, only 8% of the patient utilized healthcare from SSK facility. The distance was found to be one of the major barriers to low utilization of SSK services from Kalihati UHC. A participant said “Suppose, I am suffering from fever, for this, do I need to go to Kalihati spending fifty to one hundred takas for transport? The fever would go just if I buy medicine of fifty taka from the nearby pharmacy. Then why would I go to Kalihati spending one hundred taka?” Findings have been shared with the Health Economics Unit, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and other implementing partners of SSK project. The study protocol has been published in BMC Health Services Research journal, and two more manuscripts are being prepared. The study findings will be useful to program managers for planning nation-wide scale-up of health financing scheme for below poverty level population in Bangladesh and similar other low-income country settings. A new research grant was received from the USAID’s Research for Decision Makers project for evaluating the SSK health protection Scheme (US$ 352,798) for conducting evaluation of the pilot SSK scheme on reduction of out-of-pocket healthcare expenditure and increasing utilization of healthcare among enrolled member. The researcher attributes this to his experience on SSK scheme and existing collaboration with Health Economics Unit, which was supported with Sida funds."
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Research cooperation 2015-2021
strategy.titleSV: Forskningssamarbete 2015-2021

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 International Center of Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Bangladesh (icddr,b) är ett internationellt center som producerar forskning av stor relevans och av god kvalitet. Namnet till trots bedrivs forskning på diverse områden utöver just de viktiga diarrésjukdomarna, inkluderandes mödra- och spädbarnshälsa.
Insatsen avser programstöd under perioden 2016-2020 till icddr,b. Det föreslagna stödet är en fortsättning på tidigare stöd, vilket förlängdes med aktivitetsperiod till 30 juni 2016. Det föreslagna totala beloppet är 30 500 000 SEK för perioden 2016-2020. Stödet från Sida är programstöd till kapacitetsökning hos unga forskare i enlighet med deras Strategiska Plan 2015-2018, vilket är en förutsättning för den flexibilitet som krävs för att kunna anpassa aktiviteterna efter behov och erfarenhet. Sida är för närvarande den enda givaren som stödjer denna del av strategin specifikt.
Icddr,b har målsättningen att utveckla lösningar inom hälsa som är kostnadseffektiva och realistiska för fattiga människor som lever i låginkomstmiljöer. Icddr,b är idag ett framstående center för forskning av global relevans, exempelvis barn- och mödravård samt reproduktiv hälsa. De arbetar utifrån ett starkt rättighetsperspektiv och ställer den fattiga människan i centrum för sitt arbete. De planerar och investerar i långsiktiga hälsoinsatser och har en rådgivande funktion inom bla WHO.
icddr,b har utvecklat många processer och produkter av stor betydelse för hälsa i låginkomstmiljöer, till exempel ett världsledande koleravaccin och vätskeersättningen ORS. Nyligen har de tagit fram en enkel-dos av koleravaccinet, en lågkostnads-luftpump för småbarn med lunginflammation och stelkrampsvaccin för nyfödda.
Målsättningarna i icddr,b's Strategiska Plan 2015-2018 är att bli ett världsledande center inom forskning på global hälsa, och att bygga en bättre och effektivare finansiellt hållbar institution.
De fem strategiska prioriteringarna är: 1. Minska mödra- och spädbarnsdödlighet 2. Förebygga och behandla undernäring hos mödrar och barn 3. Kontroll av enteriska- och luftvägsinfektioner 4. Upptäcka och förebygga nya och återkommande infektionssjukdomar 5. Uppnå allmän/universell sjukvårdsförsäkring
Utöver dessa fem områden, där icddr,b är internationellt konkurrenskraftiga, vill man bygga upp starkare kapacitet inom områdena: hälsoeffekter av klimatförändringar, samt förebyggande och behandling av icke smittsamma sjukdomar. I Bangladesh har man en unik möjlighet att studera just kopplingen mellan hälsa och klimatförändringar.
Det svenska stödet är inte stort jämfört med de riktade forskningsanslag som centret attraherar, men det svenska forskningsstödet ger ett stort mervärde och kan anses katalytiskt. Ägarskapet för insatsen ligger i linje med centrets strategiska plan. Då majoriteten av forskningsmedel är öronmärkta av finansiärerna är det föreslagna svenska stödet av största vikt för centret då det möjliggör långsiktiga satsningar som följer centrets egna prioriteringar. Fokus ligger på återväxten av framtida starka forskningsledare på centret – något som dels möjliggör icddr,b’s framtid, dels stärker forskningsområdet i sig. Sida kan göra störst skillnad genom ett flerårigt stöd som möjliggör en satsning på unga lovande forskare, vilka annars har svårt att få extern finansiering i konkurrens med etablerade seniora forskare. Dessa unga lovande forskare välj ut i konkurrens och måste vara anställda som forskare vid icddr,b och vara under 40 år. Stödet kommer även att gå till etableringen av icddr,b’s genomikfacilitet vilken initierades med svenskt stöd under 2015-2016.
Sida har gett finansiellt stöd till icddr,b sedan 1981 och har erfarenheten att centret har god kapacitet att uppnå sina mål.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The International Centre for Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Bangladesh (icddr,b) is an international health research institution located in Dhaka, dedicated to addressing the health challenges that disproportionately affect people living in poverty in Bangladesh and other low- and middle-income countries. Sida has supported icddr,b since 1981, and the institute has evolved considerably over time. The institute is today a centre of excellence producing research of global relevance, such as child and maternal health, including reproductive health. Icddr,b provides unique opportunities to address health challenges in low-income settings through low-cost, practical, lifesaving solutions. The track record includes the oral rehydration solution (ORS), zinc for diarrhoea treatment and tetanus vaccines for newborns, which have saved and continue to save millions of lives worldwide. icddr,b has the capacity to undertake a full spectrum of research spanning population-based studies and demographic surveillance, large-scale clinical trials, hospital-based clinical studies, and laboratory research. icddr,b has recently had some turbulent years with concerns of both organizational nature and regarding research sustainability, especially with regards to the regrowth of researchers at the senior level. These challenges are being addressed in different ways and the institute is currently at a transitional stage.
icddr,b’s Strategic Plan 2015-2018 reinforces icddr,b’s legacy of focusing not just on discovery, but also on strengthening the organisation’s ability to shape policy at the national, regional and global level, as well as advocating for the use of highly effective products and evidence-based discoveries. icddr,b reinforces these efforts through publishing and South-South collaboration, training and capacity-building, and continues to build a cadre of public health experts and capacities for low- and middle-income countries. In addition, strategic national, regional and global partnerships tap into the complementary assets of other organisations—academic, scientific, NGOs and private sector—to maximise the influence and reach of icddr,b’s work.
There are five key areas in which icddr,b has a strong track record and expertise (points 1-5 below) and two which are highly relevant to Bangladesh and where icddr,b would like to develop greater expertise (points 6-7 below): 1 Reduce maternal and neonatal mortality 2 Prevent and treat maternal and childhood malnutrition 3 Control enteric and respiratory infections 4 Detect and control emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases 5 Achieve universal health coverage 6 Non Communicable Diseases 7 Climate Change
The Strategic Plan has identified the need for regrowth of the scientific base, and aim to invest in the capacity building of junior and mid-level scientists through mentoring, training, travel and exchange opportunities. This will increase the overall capacity of the institution, create a cadre of researchers with leadership potential and ensure a new generation of scientist have a strong knowledge and skill set.
A new phase of research cooperation support to icddr,b is proposed for the period July 2016 - December 2020. The research funding is proposed to be used to fund research and capacity building targeting junior and mid-level scientists in line with icddr,b’s Strategic Plan. Although icddr,b is successful in attracting financing, the Swedish research support has the added value to provide support in line with the institution’s own strategic priorities including the continued capacity development of its staff. The proposal is to ensure the smooth transition from an older to a younger generation of scientists and addressing the research priorities identified in the Strategic Plan. In addition to the capacity building there is support to the finalisation of the establishment of a genomics facility, which was initiated in 2015. This facility forms the basis for innovative research and attracts international collaboration.
An important value of the Sida research support is the earmarking of research project funding to younger scientists and a possibility to plan a career development program of several years in a row. Another added value according to icddr,b is the relationship to Sida also as advisors, not just funders, who can support in developing processes and criteria for the calls and experience-sharing in capacity building. Sida strongly supports the ownership of icddr,b and collaboration with both South and North, which increases the potential of icddr,b researchers to attract international funding and hence the basis for icddr,b's sustainability.
There are several interesting synergies between the support to icddr,b and other initiatives, both at the Embassy and at Sida, including WASH (water and sanitation) and INDEPTH (Network of demographic surveillance site, where icddr,b is an important member). Considering that Bangladesh is highly vulnerable to climate change, likely to experience floods in the wet season and droughts in the dry season, as well as the high likelihood to experience extreme weather events, there are concerns that this may affect health in several different ways (polluted or dirty waters; increase of vector-borne diseases, reduction of crop production leading to undernutrition). For these reasons, Sida also foresees that icddr,b may become a model for climate change adaptation.

tag.narrative: 3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.
6.b - Stödja och stärka lokalsamhällenas deltagande i arbetet med att förbättra vatten- och sanitetshanteringen.
6.b - Support and strengthen the participation of local communities in improving water and sanitation management.

Many countries will not be able to achieve the SDGs for malnutrition, according to icddr,b. As a result their brains do not develop properly and they remain susceptible to diseases for many years after. This is due to their gut microbes which remain in an immature state. Scientists from icddr,b and Washington University investigated the impact of diets on the gut microbiota, and how members of microbiota that are beneficial are affected positively. Another key outcome of this study was to see the effect of diets on proteins produced in the body of the children. These results were recognised as one of top ten scientific breakthroughs in 2019 by Science magazine (https://vis.sciencemag.org/breakthrough2019/finalists/#Microbes-combat) Sida support to young promising scientists Icddr,b writes in its report that “Sida support has in the past played a catalytic role for icddr,b; specially since it supports the young and upcoming researchers who otherwise finds it difficult to secure competitive funding from external sources at the beginning of their scientific career. It’s a unique mechanism of support as it gives icddr,b management the opportunity to invest in research areas of the Strategic Plan for which external funding is scarce. Sida’s project support has also aided in the career development of young scientists as funds can be budgeted for support from external experts on specific areas to assist them with their projects. Fund is also provided to young researchers for attending workshop/seminar to present their findings and data. This gives young researchers exposure and networking opportunity.” The selection of projects was done differently than the previous round, as decided by icddr,b's Senior Leadership Team (SLT) and discussed with Sida. The reason was to get better evaluations and feedback to the scientists. Each scientific division was asked to select the best five concepts from their divisions to allow those to be sent to the external scientific advisory group (SAG) for review. Each scientific division in icddr,b formed a gender balanced selection committee comprising of their senior and mid-level scientists and the applicants had to make a brief presentation to this committee. From this initial screening, a total number of 24 concept notes were short-listed out of which 11 were led by female researchers. This time it was much easier to get the target three reviews for each concept note from panel members of the SAG and as a result, it was easy to attain a meaningful average score for each application. Also, the reduced numbers made it possible for the SAG members to provide qualitative comments on the concept notes, which the young researchers always find very useful as guidance for future competition. With the available funding, it was possible to support 10 new projects out of which 4 were led by female scientists. The allocation of Sida funds based on a competitive peer- review process very successfully and this has been recognized not only by the young researchers at icddr,b but also by the Board, Senior Advisory Group (SAG) and senior management of icddr,b. As a result of this, icddr,b has now launched a similar competitive grant process for the young female researchers of icddr,b and beyond. The funding comes from a Prize awarded to icddr,b for its global impact. As an example of how Sida’s funds for the young researchers plays a catalytic role in their career is “the FluMI project” led by a researcher who not only benefitted from the data generated from this study for his PhD thesis in Australia, but his collaboration with National Institute of Cardio Vascular Diseases in Bangladesh later helped icddr,b in getting a multi-country project (IAMI). The researcher’s successor at icddr,b is now surveying myocardial infarction patients for influenza and SARS-COV-2. Another example of interesting research results is presented in the last part of this text. Training Good to know is the long-term partnership since 2011between icddr,b and Uppsala University for their Infectious Disease Course Masters Program. Between 2011 and 2017, TTU has trained around 140 Masters level students from Uppsala. During 2019, to meet the training needs of young scientists, the newly formed ‘Learning and Development Unit’ – a team combined of TTU (Technical Training Unit) and TD (Talent Development) offered training courses on 10 topics in 13 batches and trained 290 participants out of whom 48% were female. However, the total number of applications received for these trainings were 630. This means that a huge unmet need is there among the young scientists at icddr,b for such in-house trainings. Icddr,b identified training needs and prioritized based on the following four criteria: *Unmet needs of previous years' training; *Feedback from participants about their current needs; *Recommendations from the senior leadership team (SLT) and senior advisory group (SAG); *Data on training needs from performance management and development system (PMDS). Bubble CPAP The Bubble CPAP project with AHRI in Ethiopia completed its Phase I , but due to the delay in getting approval from the Ethiopian IRB for some amendments made to the original research protocol, which included changing a hospital because of not getting enough patients enrolled, the study progress got delayed. Genomics facility The external evaluation had a few critical comments on the genomics facility, and it is important to follow up on the progress. Especially the use was criticised. The centre is running both WGS and 16s metagenomics. Lately, the number of tests in the genomics center (GC) has gone up significantly. It went up from 131 in 2017 to 315 in 2019. The bioinformatics core at the GC is now consist of national and young scientists and it is no more dependent on hired international consultants. GC has been receiving samples from other national institutions such as East west university Bangladesh and Jessore University. The current performance rate is 62% and it was only 27% in 2017. The underutilization rate has dropped from 74% in 2017 to 38% now. The cost of the tests is now negotiable depending on the number of tests. An example of one of the finalised projects of young promising scientists: “A study to systematically document the implementation related challenges of Shasthyo Suroksha Karmasuchi (SSK, Health Protection Scheme) of the Government of Bangladesh”, a collaboration with two institutes in UK and Karolinska in Sweden. 18 months long and a budget of 85 600 USD. "The main aim of this study was to assess the implementation-related challenges of SSK scheme, and specifically challenges in below poverty line (BPL) population identification, barriers in the utilization of health services, and assessment of service knowledge among the beneficiaries. The results show that around 30% of the non-BPL household got included in the BPL list, in part because the listing is done seldomly. Since then, “many of them got a job, and they are not poor anymore”. The results also show that there is a lack of knowledge; among the surveyed SSK household, around 68% ever heard about the SSK scheme and 63% had knowledge about the process of healthcare provision under SSK scheme. However, a majority of the respondent didn’t have knowledge that SSK provides free medicine (54%), free diagnostic (75%), and reimbursement of transportation cost for referral facilities (87%). The households members included in the survey, around 25% of them suffered from illness in the last three month. Among them, 82% utilized healthcare from different sources. However, only 8% of the patient utilized healthcare from SSK facility. The distance was found to be one of the major barriers to low utilization of SSK services from Kalihati UHC. A participant said “Suppose, I am suffering from fever, for this, do I need to go to Kalihati spending fifty to one hundred takas for transport? The fever would go just if I buy medicine of fifty taka from the nearby pharmacy. Then why would I go to Kalihati spending one hundred taka?” Findings have been shared with the Health Economics Unit, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and other implementing partners of SSK project. The study protocol has been published in BMC Health Services Research journal, and two more manuscripts are being prepared. The study findings will be useful to program managers for planning nation-wide scale-up of health financing scheme for below poverty level population in Bangladesh and similar other low-income country settings. A new research grant was received from the USAID’s Research for Decision Makers project for evaluating the SSK health protection Scheme (US$ 352,798) for conducting evaluation of the pilot SSK scheme on reduction of out-of-pocket healthcare expenditure and increasing utilization of healthcare among enrolled member. The researcher attributes this to his experience on SSK scheme and existing collaboration with Health Economics Unit, which was supported with Sida funds."
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Global strategy on socially sustainable development 2018-2022
strategy.titleSV: Global strategi för socialt hållbar utveckling 2018-2022

description.narrative: Målet är att bygga och frigöra kapacitet inom forskarsamhällen i låg- och medelinkomstländer, genom forskningsstödjande insatser kring vetenskaplig publicering. Detta bidrar i sin tur till lokalt producerad forskning av hög kvalitet, som behövs för att reducera fattigdom och bygga hållbara samhällen. Insatsen ska mer specifikt expandera den digitatala, globala plattformen AuthorAid, med både kurser och annat utbildningsmaterial, diskussionsfora, vetenskapliga läsklubbar, möjlighet att få en mentor och hitta samarbetspartner, med forskare från låg- och medelinkomstländer tidigt i karriären som främsta målgrupp. Insatsens mål är också att utveckla en hållbar affärsmodell för denna plattform, för att på sikt bli oberoende av Sida-stöd. Insatsen ska också främja kvaliteten, trovärdigheten och användningen av forskning producerad i låg- och medelinkomstländer genom kvalitetsarbete riktat mot redaktörer för vetenskapliga tidskrifter, både genom kurser och ramverket Journal Publishing Practices Standards (JPPS). Även för detta ramverk ska en hållbar affärsmodell utvecklas, i samarbete med African Journals Online (AJOL). Insatsens mål är också att underlätta för kvinnliga forskare i låg- och medelinkomstländer bland annat genom att stödja jämställdhetsarbetet på forskningsinstituioner. Utöver den globala plattformen AuthorAid kommer insatser specifikt att göras i Uganda, Etiopien och Kambodja, i samarbete med forskningsinstitutioner och andra relevanta partner inom de nationella forskningssystemen. En enkätstudie kommer också att genomföras för att ge en evidensbaserad bild av behoven hos forskare i låg- och medelinkomstländer, till stöd för INASP och andra aktörer att vidare utveckla sina forskningsstödjande tjänster. Särskilt fokus kommer att läggas vid genusfrågor. Aktiviteterna i Uganda, Etiopien och Kambodja genomförs i samarbete med nationella partner, och det exakta genomförandet kommer därför att utvecklas gemensamt över tid. När det gäller Kambodja initieras samarbete mellan INASP och forskningsinstitutioner genom denna insats. Insatsen ska resultera i bland annat - utökat och förbättrat utbud av utbildningsmaterial på AuthorAid för forskare och tidskriftsredaktörer - en grupp facilitatorer och moderatorer i Uganda och Etiopien som kan ge och facilitera färdighetskurser i vetenskapligt skrivande - nationellt anpassade online-kurser i vetenskapligt skrivande för forskare i Uganda och Etiopien - starkare online-system för nationell vetenskaplig publicering i Etiopien respektive utvecklat online-system för nationell vetenskaplig publicering i Uganda - fler forskningsinstituioner i Uganda och Etiopien som identifierar och adresserar jämställdhetsproblem - stöd till forskningssystemet i Kambodja kring olika aspekter av vetenskaplig publicering (tillgång, produktion, kommunikation) De globala och nationella aktiviteterna förväntas korsbefrukta varandra.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Stöd till globala plattformen AuthorAid, med onlinekurser i vetenskapligt skrivande och andra digitala resurser för forskare tidigt i karriären, i låg- och medelinkomstländer. Stöd till kvalitetsramverket Journal Publishing Practices Standards (JPPS) för kvalitetsutveckling och -märkning av vetenskapliga tidskrifter i låg- och medelinkomstländer. Stöd till insatser för att främja olika aspekter av vetenskaplig kommunikation i Uganda, Etiopien och Kambodja, inkluderande bland annat tillgång till vetenskaplig litteratur, kapacitetsutveckling inom vetenskapligt skrivande och vetenskapligt redaktörskap, samt insatser som främjar jämställdhet inom forskning och på forskningsinstitutioner.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support to the global platform AuthorAid, with online-courses in scientific writing and other digital resources for early career researchers in low and middle income countries. Support to the quality framework Journal Publishing Practices Standards (JPPS) for capacity development of scientific journals in low and middle income countries. Support to activities to improve different aspects of scientific communication in Uganda, Ethiopia and Cambodia, including availability to scientific publications, capacity development in scientific writing and scientific publishing, as well as acitivites to improve gender equality in research and at research institutions.

participating-org.narrative: INASP/International Network for Advancing Science and Policy

tag.narrative: 17.6 - Enhance North-South, South-South and triangular regional and international cooperation on and access to science, technology and innovation and enhance knowledge-sharing on mutually agreed terms, including through improved coordination among existing mechanisms, in particular at the United Nations level, and through a global technology facilitation mechanism.

17.6 - Stärka nord–syd-samarbetet, syd–syd-samarbetet och det regionala och internationella trepartssamarbetet kring och tillgången till vetenskap, teknik och innovation samt öka kunskapsutbytet på gemensamt överenskomna villkor, inklusive genom förbättrad samordning mellan befintliga mekanismer, i synnerhet på FN-nivå, och genom en global mekanism för teknikfrämjande.

4.5 - By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples and children in vulnerable situations.

4.5 - Senast 2030 avskaffa skillnaderna mellan könen inom utbildningsområdet och säkerställa lika tillgång till utbildning och yrkesutbildning på alla nivåer för utsatta personer, inklusive personer med funktionsnedsättning, ursprungsfolk och barn som lever under utsatta förhållanden.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

9.5 - Enhance scientific research, upgrade the technological capabilities of industrial sectors in all countries, in particular developing countries, including, by 2030, encouraging innovation and substantially increasing the number of research and development workers per 1 million people and public and private research and development spending.

9.5 - Förbättra forskningen och industrisektorernas tekniska kapacitet i alla länder, i synnerhet utvecklingsländerna, bland annat genom att till 2030 uppmuntra innovation och väsentligt öka det antal personer som arbetar med forskning och utveckling per 1 miljon människor liksom de offentliga och privata utgifterna för forskning och utveckling.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Det första året av insatsen förkortades från 12 till 9 månader, då båda parter föredrog en återgång till aktivitetsår=kalenderår. Tidigare hade givarkoordinering med DFID lett till aktivitetsår från april till mars. Detta fick till följd att första året av stöd var 1 april 2019 till 31 december 2019, vilket har påverkat INASPs planering och budgetering. I kombination med att avtal med Sida skrevs först i september 2019, ledde detta till en komprimering av aktiviteter till hösten 2019 och att en del aktiviteter fick flyttas fram till 2020. De delar av programmet som utvecklats framgångsrikt under 2019 är den kring den globala plattformen AuthorAid och de fördjupade aktiviteterna i Uganda och Etiopien. Däremot kom samarbetet med Kambodja inte igång som planerat, utan har påbörjats i blygsam skala först under senvåren 2020, ytterligare försenat av Covid-19-pandemin. Till genomförda aktiviteter hör vad avser 1) den globala plattformen - MOOC i vetenskapligt skrivande med över 3000 deltagare, varav 51% fullföljde kursen. För första gången hade en kurs en liten majoritet av kvinnliga deltagare, vilket är ett positivt resultat av INASPs aktiva försöka att öka det kvinnliga deltagandet, bland annat genom samarbete med OWSD. - en första online-kurs för tidskriftsredaktörer utvecklades och gavs, med över 200 redaktörer som påbörjade kursen. - påbörjat utveckling mot ett AuthorAid som i högre grad drivs och utvecklas av communityn (baserat på förslag och idéer som kommit fram ur enkät till AuthorAids medlemmar 2019 har arbetsgrupper av utvalda medlemmar bildats 2020 kring de av medlemmarna prioriterade områdena mentorskap, communities of practice (diskussionsgrupper och kollegialt lärande, tex läsklubbar) och jämställdhet). - utveckling och test av affärsmodell för att göra genomförandet av AuthorAids MOOCs finansiellt självbärande. Kursen i vetenskapligt skrivande sponsrades av Royal Society of Chemistry, OWSD och East African Science and Technology Commission, vars deltagare bland annat fick tillgång till egna virtuella klassrum för diskussioner och samarbeten i större grupp. 2) stärkt kapacitet och jämställdhet inom forskningssystemen i Etiopien och Uganda - bibliotekskonsortierna i Etiopein och Uganda möttes och utbytte erfarenheter (där konsortiet i Uganda är det starkare) och fick även kontinuerligt stöd av erfaren, INASP-knuten konsult och bibliotekarie från Kenya - kurs i online-facilitering med 283 deltagare från de båda länderna (64% fullgjorde kursen) för att utöka poolen av nationella facilitatorer till online-kurser i vetenskapligt skrivande m.m. - workshops med tidskriftsredaktörer i både Etiopien och Uganda för att stärka nationella vetenskapliga publikationer och publicering. Jämställdhetsfrågor integrerades i dessa. Arbetsmötet i Etiopien fick avbrytas på grund av social oro i landet hösten 2019. Resten av workshopen sköts upp till april 2020, men har inte kunnat fullföljas då heller, på grund av Covid-19-pandemin. Programansvarig på INASP försöker följa upp digitalt. - workshops i jämställdhet i Uganda och bildandet av ett nationellt forskar-nav för jämställdhet. Navet består av 74 forskare (40 kvinnor och 34 män) från 43 olika institutioner över hela landet. I jämställdhetsarbetet i Etiopien har man inte hållit några workshops än, men ett nav är bildat där diskussionerna pågår hur de vill ta arbetet vidare. Till positiva resultat hör att så många män är engagerade i jämställdhetsarbetet i Uganda, vilket enligt INASP är en tydlig förändring mot tidigare. Jämställdhet har gått från att vara en "sak för kvinnor" till att bli en angelägenhet för alla forskare. Jämställdhetsarbetet bedömdes generellt som mycket framgångsrikt, med stort intresse från ett brett spektrum av forskningsinstitutioner. Ett annat positivt resultat är synergieffekter mellan det globala och nationella arbetet, med rekordmånga deltagare från Etiopien (154) och Uganda (168) i onlinekursen i vetenskapligt skrivande. En viktig del av arbetet nationellt i Etiopien och Uganda har varit att etablera och stärka relationen till nationella partner, där Ethiopian Academy of Science (EAS) och Uganda National Council for Science and Technology (UNCST) valts ut som strategiska, nationella koordinerande partner. Några av kvaliteterna i INASPs arbete som blivit synligt i uppföljningen av denna första period av det nya stödet är att de arbetar i nära kontakt med sina partner i Etiopien och Uganda och tar aktivt reda på vad målgrupperna behöver för att möta upp där de befinner sig. Likaså har INASP på olika sätt tät kontakt med den stora gruppen medlemmar, dvs registrerade forskare (2020 över 20000) på AuthorAid och efterfrågar aktivt deras erfarenheter, behov och förslag, genom enkäter, tävlingar och inbjudan att dela med sig till andra i diskussionsfora och bloggposter. De låter olika aktiviteter (nationellt/globalt) berika varandra, organiserar peer support, testar aktiviteter och lösningar i liten skala innan de lanserar dem stort och bygger kapacitet hos forskarna, redaktörerna och bibliotekarierna, medvetet och långsiktigt.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Research cooperation 2015-2021
strategy.titleSV: Forskningssamarbete 2015-2021

description.narrative: Målet är att minska fattigdomen och förbättra människors liv i globala Syd genom att forskning som är relevant för utveckling tillgängliggörs och kommer till användning. För att uppnå detta använder SciDev.Net - vetenskapsjournalistik, i flera, fritt tillgängliga, digitala kanaler (webbplats, nyhetsbrev, sociala medier), och genom syndikering av innehållet i andra medier - genom att publicera debattartiklar och initiera diskussioner i sociala medier - genom nätverksmöten mellan forskare, journalister, beslutsfattare och andra intressenter, i samband med till exempel vetenskapliga konferenser i globala Syd - genom att kartlägga behoven hos beslutsfattare i globala Syd och anpassa forskningskommunikationen för att effektivt nå dessa - genom att stärka kapaciteten hos forskare, kommunikatörer och journalister i globala Syd i att effektivt kunna kommunicera forskning till det omgivande samhället, bland annat genom fritt tillgängliga praktiska handledningar och online-kurser. SciDev.Net kommer också koordinera flera partners i att nominera Nairobi som plats för World Conference of Science Journalists 2021. Det blir då första gången konferensen hålls i Afrika. Ett specifikt sidomål är också att bidra till bättre möjligheter för kvinnor i globala Syd att göra karriär inom naturvetenskap och teknik och att bidra till ökad integrering av genusaspekter i forskning och forskningsrapportering. För att uppnå detta har SciDev.Net en fritt tillgänglig online-kurs för forskare: "Integrate gender into your scientific research", och en praktisk handledning för vetenskapsjournalister i "How to consider gender in science reporting". SciDev.Net kommer också att producera och publicera en serie intervjuer med 150 framgångsrika kvinnor inom forskning och innovation, för att skapa förebilder för unga kvinnor att identifiera sig med, och tar regelbundet upp genusfrågor i sin nyhetsrapportering. Över de fem år som insatsen varar är målet att producera - 3500 nyhetsartiklar - 300 reportage - 800 multimedia-inslag (ofta en del av skrivna artiklar) - 150 blogginlägg med aktualitetskaraktär (SciDev@large) - systematisk vidareförmedling av redaktionellt innehåll till 300 andra medier - 150 porträtt av framgångsrika kvinnor inom forskning och innovation ("Role models") - 150 analytiska blogginlägg - 150 debattartiklar - 20x2 temapaket (2= utgivna på minst två utgivningsspråk) ("Spotlight features" - 25 online-diskussioner - 25 kartläggande intervjuer med seniora beslutsfattare (regeringschefer, ministrar, höga tjänstemän, ledare för INGO:s och mellanstatliga organisationer), till vilka utvalda artiklar sedan riktas. - 25 nätverksmöten för att bygga relationer mellan forskare, journalister och beslutsfattare Vidare ska 60 afrikanska vetenskapsjournalister få stipendium för att delta i Världskonferensen för vetenskapsjournalister (förutsatt att nomineringen vinner) och få utbildning i anslutning till konferensen. Fem av dem ska också få praktisk träning genom att skapa redaktionellt innehåll för SciDev.Net under personlig handledning. Insatsen genomförs av fem regionala redaktioner i Asien, Afrika och Latinamerika, med utgivning på engelska, franska och arabiska, och ett nätverk av lokala, frilansande vetenskapsjournalister och leds av en huvudredaktör i Storbritannien, där det också finns en "global" redaktion. Insatsen genomförs med administrativt stöd av den större organisationen CABI (med säte i Storbritannien), som SciDev.Net slagits samman med.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Stöd till SciDev.Net för utvecklingsrelevant forskningskommunikation, samt kapacitetsbyggande inom forskningskommunikation och nätverksbyggande aktiviteter för att främja kunskapsutbytet mellan forskare och beslutsfattare, så att forskningen kommer till användning och kan reducera fattigdom.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 SciDev.Net (since 2017 a part of CAB International) uses independent science journalism to help individuals and organisations apply science to decision-making in order to drive equitable, sustainable development and poverty reduction. SciDev.Net conveys science news and analysis and initiates debate and discussion on issues relevant for science and development, through its webpage, social media and syndication (the republishing of content on other media outlets). It has one global edition and five regional editions in Africa, Asia and Latin America, publishing its content in English, French, Arabic and Spanish and working with an extensive network of local, freelancing science journalists. In 2017 it had almost 100.000 subscribers to its newsletter, almost 3 million UPV:s (unique page views) of its website, a reach of 57 million on social media and a syndication reach of 19 million. SciDev.Net also builds capacity in research communication in low and middle income countries through online-courses and practical guides freely available online, for journalists, researchers and science communicators, as well as face-to-face training (in collaboration with other donors than Sida). They also arrange networking events for researchers, journalists and policymakers. Its activities contribute to the Sweden’s Strategy for research cooperation and research in development cooperation, which states the importance of research communication, making research available for the development of society.

participating-org.narrative: CABI/Centre for Agriculture and Biosciences International

tag.narrative: 17.6 - Enhance North-South, South-South and triangular regional and international cooperation on and access to science, technology and innovation and enhance knowledge-sharing on mutually agreed terms, including through improved coordination among existing mechanisms, in particular at the United Nations level, and through a global technology facilitation mechanism.

17.6 - Stärka nord–syd-samarbetet, syd–syd-samarbetet och det regionala och internationella trepartssamarbetet kring och tillgången till vetenskap, teknik och innovation samt öka kunskapsutbytet på gemensamt överenskomna villkor, inklusive genom förbättrad samordning mellan befintliga mekanismer, i synnerhet på FN-nivå, och genom en global mekanism för teknikfrämjande.

17.7 - Promote the development, transfer, dissemination and diffusion of environmentally sound technologies to developing countries on favourable terms, including on concessional and preferential terms, as mutually agreed.

title.narrative: Tillägg till avtal mellan Sida och SciDevNet_CABI 2018-2022

description.narrative: SciDev.Nets räckvidd har fortsatt öka starkt och antalet läsningar av deras material (på webb, i sociala medier och genom återpublicering i andra medier) var 2019 226 miljoner. Antalet sidbesök till deras webbplats var 2019 drygt 3 miljoner, vilket redan överträffar målet för 2022 på 2,6 miljoner. De lyckas på alla fronter: ökad läsning på webb och i sociala medier, ökat antal medier som återpublicerar deras material. Till det senare har överenskommelsen med AlphaGalileo bidragit, vilken låter SciDev.Net kostnadsfritt publicera sina artiklar på plattformen, där många vetenskapsjournalister (framför allt från Europa) söker material. De har också satsat på CC-bilder till artiklarna, för att underlätta återpublicering. SciDev.Net har i dialog med Sida satsat mer på egna nyheter, på att göra reportage och undersöka frågeställningar, för att skapa ett unikt material som inte återfinns någon annanstans. För att möljiggöra denna satsning har antalet features som ska produceras skrivits ned, då eget, längre material kräver mer arbete. Satsningen har lett till mer uppmärksamhet kring artiklarna, i linje med förhoppningarna. Till resultaten hör att politiska beslut kring bland annat användning av antibiotika, utdelning av forskningsstipendier och missbruk av malarianät till fiske påverkats i positiv riktning. De kan också se att personer i nyckelpositioner (tex högt uppsatta på WHO) delar deras material, prestigefulla medier återpublicerar och en artikel om zika-viruset fick motta ett pris från läkare och medicinjournalister i Argentina. Produktionen ligger kring eller över förväntan i de flesta artikel-kategorier. Exempelvis role model-serien, där framgångsrika kvinnliga forskare intervjuas, överträffar målen vad gäller antalet publicerade artiklar och får ett fortsatt gott mottagande hos läsarna. En del som inte fungerat som planerat är kartläggningen av beslutsfattare och deras behov av forskningskommunikation. I dialog med Sida har inriktningen modifierats och ett försök görs med nyhetsbrev till 25 utvalda nyckelpersoner inom hälsoforskning. Försöket påbörjas 2020. Nätverksmötena har varit ett ämne för dialog, då Sida betonat att dessa bör hållas i låginkomstländer eller lägre medelinkomstländer. I stället för en jämn fördelning av möten över alla regioner, är överenskommelsen att sats på Afrika och deltagare från låg- och lägre medelinkomstländer. Planerade nätverksmöten i Filippinerna och Latinamerika genomfördes därför inte. Klartecken för ett nätverksmöte för delegater från lämpliga länder som ändå befann sig på konferens hos CABI i UK gavs. Årets mål om 5 nätverksmöten uppfylldes (Egypten, Senegal, Kenya, Ghana, UK), men då bara ett nätverksmöte hölls under 2018 ligger resultatet ändå efter målen för hela programmet. Möjligheterna till nätverksmöten framöver påverkas i mycket hög grad av Covid-19-pandemin. Ett helt digitalt nätverksmöte kommer att prövas i september 2020. Fyra diskussionsfora online har hållits (målet för 2019 var fem): en global om funktionsnedsättningar, en i MENA om avsaltning, en i Senegal (kombinerad med nätverksmötet där, med bla landets tidigare forskningsminister) om hur utbildningssystemet behöver reformeras för att bättre tjäna forskning och utveckling och en i Latinamerika om fake news, som bedömdes som mest framgångsrik, då den nådde nästan 20.000 personer och blev "trending topic" i sociala medier. SciDev.Net stöds numer inte bara av Sida (som vid starten av denna insats, när SciDev.Net precis slagits samman med CABI och hade allvarliga ekonomiska problem), utan har lyckats attrahera flera givare, ibland via samarbetsprojekt med övriga CABI. Med CABIs hjälp arbetar de vidare för att långsiktigt säkra fortsatt finansiering.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Research cooperation 2015-2021
strategy.titleSV: Forskningssamarbete 2015-2021

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 De tre följande WHO-baserade forskningsprogrammen har ansökt om fortsatt stöd från Sida: i) The UNICEF-UNDP-World Bank-WHO Special Programme for Research and Training in Tropical Diseases (TDR); ii) The UNDP-UNFPA-UNICEF-WHO-World Bank Special Programme of Research, Development and Research Training in Human Reproduction, (HRP); iii) Alliance for Health Policy and Systems Research (AHPSR).
Det föreslagna stödet är en fortsättning på tidigare avtal 2016-2019. Det totala beloppet är 307,8 miljoner SEK för perioden 2020 – 2022, varav 138,8 MSEK till TDR, 99 MSEK till HRP och 70 MSEK till AHPSR. Stödet är i huvudsak icke öronmärkt.
TDR:s aktiviteter kommer under avtalsperioden att ha tyngdpunkten på forskning om hinder för effektivt genomförande av befintliga kontrollprogram för fattigdomsrelaterade infektionssjukdomar. HRP:s inriktning innefattar forskning om en bredd av frågor relaterade till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter (SRHR), bland annat migranters behov av SRHR, ungdomars behov av SRHR och kvinnors stärkta möjligheter till säker abort. AHPSR kommer att fokusera ytterligare på att genom forskning om hälsosystem och policies tillsammans med beslutsfattare bidra till att fattiga länder kan nyttja sina resurser för hälsosektorn på ett så effektivt sätt som möjligt.
Utöver icke öronmärkt stöd ingår fyra komponenter med så kallad "mjuk öronmärkning": en global hälsoforskningskonferens (genom AHPSR), nätverket ESSENCE, initiativet för social hälsoinnovation, och stärkt WASH-integrering (de tre senare genom TDR). Totalt uppgår denna mjuka öronmärkning till 8% av insatsens budget.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The following three WHO-based research programmes have applied for continued support from Sida: i) The UNICEF-UNDP-World Bank-WHO Special Programme for Research and Training in Tropical Diseases (TDR); ii) The UNDP-UNFPA-UNICEF-WHO-World Bank Special Programme of Research, Development and Research Training in Human Reproduction, HRP; iii) Alliance for Health Policy and Systems Research (AHPSR).
The proposed support is a continuation of the previous agreement 2016-2019. The total amount is SEK 307,8 million for the period 2020 - 2022, of which SEK 138,8 million to TDR, SEK 99 million to HRP and SEK 70 million to AHPSR. The contribution support is essentially unearmarked
During the agreement period, TDR's activities will focus on research on barriers to effective implementation of existing control programs for infectious diseases disproportionally affecting people living in poverty. HRP's focus includes, amongst many areas related to sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR), research on migrants' needs for SRHR, on adolescents’ need for SRHR, and women's enhanced opportunities for safe abortion. AHPSR will focus further on researching health systems and policies together with policy makers to help low- and lower middle-income countries use their resources for the health sector as efficiently as possible.
In addition to undesignated support, there are four components with so-called "soft earmarking": A Global Health Research Conference (through AHPSR), the ESSENCE Network, the Social Health Innovation Initiative, and enhanced WASH integration within the TDR (the three latter through TDR). In total, this soft earmarking amounts to 8% of the total support.

Three WHO-based research programmes are proposed for continued support: i) The UNICEF-UNDP-World Bank-WHO Special Programme for Research and Training in Tropical Diseases, TDR; ii) The UNDP-UNFPA-UNICEF-WHO-World Bank Special Programme of Research, Development and Research Training in Human Reproduction, HRP; and iii) Alliance for Health Policy and Systems Research, AHPSR, or "the Alliance". Sida/Sweden is a long-standing supporter of TDR since its creation in 1974. TDR is one of the earliest examples of a Global Health Partnership and has repeatedly received good reviews by external evaluators because of its relevance to both health and development. TDR is the 2011 recipient of the Gates Award for Global Health. With its long history of support, Sida is well familiar with the achievements of the programme. TDR helps facilitate, support and influence efforts to combat diseases of poverty, with the mission to "support effective and innovative global health research, through strengthening the research capacity of disease-affected countries, and promoting the translation of evidence into interventions that reduce the burden of infectious diseases and build resilience in the most vulnerable populations". TDR main areas are i) Research for policy; ii) Research for implementation; iii) Research for innovation; and iv) Research for integrated approaches. Sida/Sweden is an as long-standing supporter of HRP, even since a couple of years before its creation in 1972. As such, Sida is equally familiar with the HRP's achievements. HRP is the main instrument within the United Nations system for research in human reproduction, bringing together policy-makers, scientists, health care providers, clinicians, consumers and community representatives to identify and address priorities for research to improve sexual and reproductive health. The mission of HRP is "the attainment of all people of the highest possible level of sexual and reproductive health. HRP strives for a world where all women’s and men’s rights to enjoy sexual and reproductive health are promoted and protected, and all women and men, including adolescents and those who are underserved and marginalized, have access to sexual and reproductive health information and services". AHPSR is a younger programme than TDR and HRP and recently celebrated its 20th anniversary. Sweden was one of the drivers of the creation of AHPSR and has been actively involved since then, leading to good insights into their activities. AHPSR work to improve the health of those in low- and middle-income countries by supporting the generation and use of evidence that strengthens health systems. Together with organizations around the world, the AHPSR aims to i) provide a unique forum for the health policy and systems research community; ii) support institutional capacity for the conduct and uptake of health policy and systems research; iii) stimulate the generation of knowledge and innovations to nurture learning and resilience in health systems; and iv) increase the demand for and use of knowledge for strengthening health systems.
HRP and TDR are “special programmes” of WHO which gives them an independent status in relation to WHO. They are co-sponsored by a number of UN-agencies (UNICEF, UNDP, World Bank and WHO are co-sponsors of both TDR and HRP, and additionally, UNFPA is co-sponsor of HRP). As a WHO-hosted partnership, AHPSR is also guaranteed its independence. The difference between the two set-ups used to be the co-sponsorship of the special programmes, although today the definitions are being discussed at WHO. The future format of AHPSR is described later in this appraisal. When the special programmes were created in the early 1970’s WHO did not actively engage in research, but as a number of member states could see the importance of producing research of relevance (in this case tropical diseases and human reproduction), TDR and HRP were created. Over the years, the importance of producing evidence to feed into policies and guidelines was increasingly recognized and other UN agencies joined the effort as co-sponsors. Similarly, the areas of health policy and systems research were neglected and in the late 1990’s a group of global health leaders, including senior scientists, policy makers and representatives of various agencies and programs with a stake in health policy and systems research agreed on the need to create a body that would address these areas, and AHPSR was created as a hosted partnership at WHO. Being based at WHO and having a close interaction with the co-sponsors provides the research programmes with a unique opportunity to accelerate translation of research results into policies and guidelines. Through country and regional offices and their close relation to a county’s Ministry of Health, the possibility for implementation at this level is also improved. As WHO is now putting more emphasis into the country and regional offices, this is expected to play an even more important role in the coming years. The importance of research and evidence is even more clear now that WHO has assigned a first Chief Scientist and a Science Division, and one can foresee a closer interaction between the research programmes and WHO at all levels. Over the years, as the world changes, the areas of research addressed as well as the ways to address the need of evidence and implementation have changed in the three programmes. The research programmes show an embedded ability to adapt their activities to changes in global health and to take leading roles in the global research agenda. There are still pertinent questions to be addressed in the programmes’ respective areas. For example, there is presently a strong focus on implementation research and interaction with decision-makers, as well as strengthening research capacity in LMICs and ensuring that high quality research is done in countries. This will be further described in the next section. As the bulk of Sida's support to the programmes is given as undesignated funding, the results of the upcoming phase are expected to contribute to the attainment of the respective missions.

tag.narrative: 3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.
3.d - Strengthen the capacity of all countries, in particular developing countries, for early warning, risk reduction and management of national and global health risks.
3.d - Stärka alla länders, i synnerhet utvecklingsländernas, kapacitet när det gäller tidig varning, riskreducering och hantering av nationella och globala hälsorisker.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: WHO agreement_ Support to research pg 2020-2022.pdf

description.narrative: A report on TDR's results from 2019 and ongoing activities 2020 was presented at the annual Joint Coordinating Board (JCB), where Sida is a member. Many interesting results have been achieved in accordance with the Strategic plan and biennial plans, and in addition, their work contribute to the ongoing covid-19 pandemic. Through the WHO Science Division, research at different departments across WHO as well as between the three Sida-funded research programmes is more connected and synergies can be explored. A joint Theory of Change for research capacity strengthening has been developed for the three programmes. The TDR Secretariat is involved in more WHO activities now, especially thanks to the dual roles of TDR’s director (also being director of the newly established Research for Health department of the Science Division). TDR Director is also invited to more external meetings, such as the Global Fund, in his role as Director of Research for Health. TDR has a successful model for budgeting, with two budget scenarios which are approved at JCB. This way, they can smoothly and efficiently shift to the evolving final budget. This model was presented to WHO departments at the “WHO Value for Money” initiative last year. Selected results 2019: - TDR and WHO’s Department of Control of Neglected Tropical Diseases have collaborated with the International Atomic Energy Agency and its joint division with the Food and Agriculture Organization to develop guidance on testing the Sterile Insect Technique (SIT) to control diseases carried by Aedes mosquitoes such as dengue, Zika and chikunguna. - TDR, in collaboration with the WHO Global Tuberculosis Programme and technical partners, has developed an implementation/operational research package (ShORRT) to support the use of all-oral shorter drug regimens for patients with drug-resistant TB. Detecting tuberculosis cases in West and Central Africa is a persistent challenge, especially in children. It is estimated that 70% of TB cases in children under five are neither detected nor treated. In Senegal, to address these missed cases, the National TB Control Programme is studying a new active case finding strategy, where TB screening is integrated into malnutrition screening campaigns. If successful, the approach will be scaled up across other regions in Senegal. The pilot study was conducted during a one-week malnutrition screening campaign in Thiès and Tivaouane districts that gathered up more than 70000 children under five years old. Parents were also asked to bring their children ages 5 to 14 for TB screening. Community engagement was essential to ensure broad participation. - In June 2019, TDR and WHO launched a new training course on ethics in implementation research to ensure appropriate engagement with research subjects and relevant communities and to safeguard against any potential harm. “Implementation research is key to improving programmes for children in ‘real world’ settings, but must be done while protecting communities and children. As a TDR co-sponsor, UNICEF therefore welcomes this new training course on ethics in implementation research”, says Stefan Peterson Chief of Health, UNICEF, which alos shows increased collaboration with one of TDR’s so-sponsors. - In 2019, 744 scientists (72% women) were trained in good health research practices and 2999 (55% women) in implementation research. Short training courses in good health practices were institutionalized in five regions: - Africa: Kenya, Nigeria, Mozambique; - Americas: Bolivia, Ecuador, Guatemala, Honduras, Jamaica, Peru; - Eastern Mediterranean: Lebanon; - Europe: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Kazan State of Russia, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Ukraine, Uzbekistan; - South-East Asia: India, Myanmar, Nepal - More than 5000 researchers from more than 200 countries participated in TDR’s Massive Open Online Course on Implementation Research conducted in English, French and Spanish. - Complementing the training programmes on research for implementation, TDR also supports the Clinical Research and Development Fellowship scheme, which allows early- to mid-career researchers in low- and middle-income countries to learn how to conduct clinical trials. Participants are placed for 12 months in pharmaceutical companies, product development partnerships, or research organizations and receive a grant to reintegrate with their home institution. The fellowship is jointly implemented by TDR and the European & Developing Countries Clinical Trials Partnership (EDCTP). One of the fellowships is a researcher from Nigeria who is placed at the Sida-funded International Vaccine Institute, IVI, in South Korea. - TDR is at the interface between research and healthcare delivery. Embedded within the UN family through its co-sponsors (UNICEF, UNDP, the World Bank, and WHO), this unique position allows TDR to create a bridge from local communities to the World Health Assembly to enable the broadest possible scope of dialogue and debate across the spectrum of health research – from priority setting to evidence-based policy-making at local, national, regional and global levels. This global engagement includes collaboration with WHO regional offices on research grants, shaping the global health research agenda, leading a collaborative network on research funding, creating an enabling environment and providing evidence for community-engaged social innovations to transform health care delivery, and leveraging a global network of 7500 scientists and experts who have been associated with TDR. - 6 country hubs of the Social Innovation in Health Initiative are playing a leadership role in advancing social innovations through research. In 2019, one of the SIHI supported innovations in Uganda was presented to UNICEF and UNDP’s “Big Think Challenge”, and was awarded second prize. This initiative is run by a previous Sida-sandwich PhD student from Makerere university. TDR, UNDP and UNICEF now join forces to support the scale-up of this initiative on private health sector management for childhood illness. - In May 2019, TDR launched an online resource to guide the development of new drugs, vaccines and diagnostics for which there are limited markets or incentives for research and development. An essential tool for realizing universal health coverage, the Health Product Profile Directory aims to promote research and development for products to combat neglected diseases and threats to global health, including antimicrobial resistance and diseases with pandemic potential. The Health Product Profile Directory is a free-to use online resource created and developed by TDR on behalf of WHO as a global public good. It provides a searchable database of profiles for health products needed to tackle pressing health issues in global health, including those prioritized by WHO. The summary of the published profiles outlines 8-10 key characteristics (such as target population, measures of efficacy and dosage) for the development of health products, including medicines, vaccines and diagnostics. Building in these characteristics at an early stage of the development process is essential to ensure that the final products will be accessible to the populations that need them. Currently, the Directory contains 233 product profiles, with the majority describing the needs for three infectious diseases: HIV, TB and malaria. 2020 results until June: - TDR has built the capacity of scientists to investigate gender dimensions of health, which are often overlooked. There is a growing recognition that gender norms, roles, power relations, socioeconomic factors, and other drivers of inequality intersect with each other and influence access to health services and health outcomes. This must be considered when designing and implementing health interventions and monitoring universal health coverage. In response, TDR has developed tools to strengthen such research capacities, including an intersectional gender research toolkit and an online course on gender-based analysis. In June 2020 TDR launched its new strategy for intersectional gender research. Developed over a number of years with expert input, this strategy expects to lead to a more inclusive, effective response to infectious diseases. The strategy will shape how TDR works over the coming years. Sida Research Cooperation Unit was involved in the process, especially invited as Sida is considered leaders on gender issues in global development. - The establishment of a new Secretariat for the growing Social Innovation in Health Initiative (SIHI) network took place earlier this year. Based in the Philippines, the team will coordinate the work of SIHI and raise the profile of social innovation in health through effective communications, supporting social innovation through research capacity and advocacy. - There is a TDR paper in The Lancet Global Health focused on social innovation in health, making the case that rigorous research, engaging all actors, is needed to test, optimize, and scale up innovations. It calls for researchers, governments, and health professionals to adapt in order to reap the full benefits of social innovation in health. Sida Research Cooperation Unit contributes with an article as well. Covid-19 response: Although TDR are not reactive to emergencies, their work directly contributes to emergencies which appear. For example, TDR has long supported capacity building for research on infectious diseases of poverty through various training programmes. A recent TDR survey showed that 60% of the former trainees that replied were now responding to COVID-19, and almost 80% of these were able to do so thanks to the skills acquired in TDR training. TDR continues to work in many ways to contribute to the COVID-19 situation, including follow-up work of the COVID-19 Clinical Research Coalition, reviewing daily research publications included in the WHO database of publications on COVID-19, working with our co-sponsors on joint activities, and developing a customized training course on good clinical practices for research teams in hospitals participating in the WHO “Solidarity” clinical trial for COVID-19 treatments.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
