description.narrative: The results during 2019 are: Support to comprehensive differentiated and qualified Services for SRHR, Maternity Health Services and Gender Base Violence Services: - In 16 municipalities in the country 39 young counsels have been trained in SRHR Rigths. - 39 Municipalities have been strengthening in SRHR Rigths. - Public health, justice and education servers with strengthened capacities in integral SRHR care, adolescent pregnancy prevention, prevention and care, and punishment of gender-based violence with focus on gender, generational and intercultural approaches. Health care protocols and norms developed and implemented to improve sexual and reproductive health care practices: - New norms and protocols have been approved by the government and local municipalities. - Increased capacity within local municipalities and health systems at local level to carry out procedures aimed at improving the quality of care in public health services emphasizing maternal health, family planning, adolescents and youth as well as sexual gender based violence and HIV. Program for Prevention of Pregnancy: - Youth and adolescents Program against pregnancy have been approved at department level. Local civil society working with human rigths has been strengthening in LGBT, SRHR and indigenous peoples rigths in order to follow up the CEDAW recomendations: - Social organizations of women, adolescents, youth and indigenous people demanding their rigths and carring out social control the comunities and municipalities involved. Information system for SRHR: The creation of a tracking and information platform at municipalities in order to increase the capacity of the municipalities to monitor and follow up SRHR (39 municipalities have increased their capacity).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: SKR - Hållbart lokalt självstyre i en postkonliktsituation

description.narrative:
Colombia is facing a critical moment in its history, with a real opportunity to end a 50-year internal armed conflict with the largest guerrilla movement FARC-EP. This implies great opportunities and challenges for strengthening and changing the role of local government in the country. This process must be started quickly and provide clear changes after a peace agreement has been signed, otherwise the conditions to carry out an effective peace-building at the local level will be more difficult year by year.
Local authorities play an important role in the peace building process. They have a strong impact on peace and conflict situation due to their proximity, legitimacy and constant presence in the territories. In Colombia, the proposed peace agreements refer to "territorial peace" (Paz Territorial) which means that the peace process must be adapted to and implemented at the local level. The capacities of local authorities to implement this varies to a great extent and it is therefore important to strengthen their capacity where needed. Key priorities to included in the present project will be: 1) public participation, 2) improving systems of financial transfers between the authorities, and 3) methods to develop the local authorities' performance indicators. Key issues included in each of these priority areas is gender equality as well as environment and climate change, for example regarding the provision of public services including water and sanitation and waste management.
Public participation: There is a need to implement a real change in terms of public participation of women and men in political processes, from the current situation where this is done in a more formalistic manner without any real participation, to a situation where it is done in an efficient and effective manner. Swedish experience in the field can contribute as inspiration for this change towards a more inclusive approach to participation and social dialogue. SKL has supported municipalities, county councils and regions in Sweden to develop a civic dialogue, cooperation with civil society and to create openness and transparency. This includes the development of methods for strategies for participation in potentially controversial situations and ways to involve political leaders to promote public participation.
National guidelines for territorial control, including financial and performance measurement: From a post-conflict perspective, it is necessary to increase the financial resources for the weaker and conflict-affected municipalities. The primary financing in Colombia is the general system of state subsidies to local and regional units (Sistema General de Participaciones, SGP). Transfers through this system are largely earmarked for specific purposes, which prevents the weaker municipalities to improve other needs. Additionally they disencourage genuine participation because municipalities cannot influence how resources are to be used. DNP is currently looking at the formulas for how the redistribution of funds can be altered. In this context the large differences in generation of own income between Colombian municipalities, redistribution of royalties as well as a proposed fund for post-conflict support, must also be taken into account. Any reform intended to bring more resources to the municipalities where the needs are the largest would also strongly benefit from a formula that leads to a real growth of the total amount to be distributed.
The proposed Swedish contribution is designed to improve the conditions for peace and sustainable development in Colombia through increased participation for women and men and accountability, environmental sustainability and gender equality in the country. The project will largely focus on the DNP and national guidelines, where Swedish and international examples and best practices can help to improve their development. The main work will be complemented by local efforts in a number of pilot municipalities. At this level, the project aims to create new approaches and ways to work with the participation, as well as performance indicators.
SKL has proposed a five-year contribution with two main results and four outcomes:
1. Participation. In particular, developing replicable models of genuine participation and inclusion within specific sectors and processes at the local level.
Outcome 1A: Municipalities develop and implement inclusive ways of working that can be replicated in other areas. Outcome 1B: DNP's guidelines adapted to local realities and international experience of participation and inclusion.
2. National policies for territorial financing and management. This includes the development of the Colombian system of territorial funding and an equitable, sustainable and evidence-based system for the evaluation of territorial control.
Outcome 2A: National policies for territorial governance are influenced by local realities and international experience and an equitable and evidence-based policies. Outcome 2B: DNP has the capacity to develop and implement effective performance measures.
The project proposal from SKL covers five years. Since it is the last year of the current cooperation strategy for Colombia and a new strategy to be decided on, the Embassy is not able to take a decision on a five-year support. Against this background, the proposed decision will be made for three years for the period 2016-2018 with an option to extend for a further two years from 2019 to 2020. This also fits well taking into account that a Mid-Term Review is planned for 2018, which could lead to changes in the program. According to DNP, 2018 is also appropriate since elections will be held and a new government will take office that year. During the 2019 local elections will be conducted. The assessment of the program, however, will include the entire project period, i.e. five years.

Colombia står inför ett kritiskt moment i sin historia, med en verklig möjlighet att avsluta en 50-årig intern väpnad konflikt med den största gerillarörelsen FARC-EP. Detta innebär stora möjligheter och utmaningar för att stärka och att förändra rollen för det lokala självstyret i landet. Denna process måste inledas snabbt och medföra tydliga och klara förändringar efter det att ett fredsavtal har undertecknats, annars kommer förutsättningarna att kunna genomföra ett effektivt fredsbygge på lokal nivå att försvåras år från år.
Lokala myndigheter spelar en viktig roll i fredsbyggnadsprocessen. De har en stark påverkan på fred- och konfliktssituationen på grund av deras närhet, legitimitet och konstanta närvaro i territorierna. I Colombia refererar de föreslagna fredsavtalen till "territoriell fred" (Paz Territorial), viket innebär att fredsprocessen måste anpassas efter och implementeras på lokal nivå. Kapaciteten hos de lokala myndigheterna att genomföra detta varierar mycket och det är därför viktigt att stärka denna kapacitet där det behövs. Viktiga prioriteringar som kommer att inkluderas i det här aktuella projektet, kommer att vara 1) allmänhetens deltagande, 2) system för finansiella transfereringar mellan myndigheter, samt 3) metoder för att utveckla lokala myndigheters resultatindikatorer. Jämställdhet samt miljö och klimat är centrala områden i det föreslagna samarbetet. Bl.a. väntas ingå tillhandahållande av offentliga tjänster för kvinnor och män, inklusive vatten och sanitet samt avfallshantering.
Allmänhetens deltagande: Det finns behov av att genomföra en verklig förändring vad gäller kvinnors och mäns deltagande i politiska processer, från dagens förhållande där denna till stor del sker formalistiskt utan verklig effekt, till en situation där denna sker på ett effektivt och verkningsfullt sätt. Svenska erfarenheter inom området kan bidra som inspiration för denna förändring gentemot ett mer inkluderande förhållningssätt för deltagande och social dialog. SKL har stött kommuner, landsting och regioner i Sverige för att utveckla en medborgerlig dialog, samarbeta med civilsamhället samt skapa öppenhet och transparens. Detta inkluderar utveckling av metoder för strategier för deltagande i potentiellt kontroversiella situationer och sätt att engagera politiska ledare för att främja allmänhetens deltagande.
Nationella riktlinjer för territoriell styrning, inklusive finansiering och prestandamätning: Utifrån ett postkonfliktperspektiv är det nödvändigt att öka de finansiella resurserna för svagare och konfliktdrabbade kommuner. Den huvudsakliga finansieringen i Colombia är det generella systemet för statliga bidrag till lokala och regionala enheter (Sistema General de Participaciones, SPG). Transfers genom detta system är till stor del öronmärkta för särskilda ändamål, vilket hindrar de svagare kommunerna att förbättra andra behov. De verkar dessutom hämmande för genuint deltagande eftersom kommunerna inte kan påverka hur resurserna används. DNP tittar för närvarande på formler för hur omdistribution av medlen kan förändras. I detta sammanhang måste också frågor avseende de stora skillnaderna vad gäller generering av egna inkomster mellan colombianska kommuner, omfördelning av royalties samt en föreslagen fond för postkonfliktstöd. Varje försök till förändring av systemet måste också se till att försöka öka de sammantagna inkomsterna som skall fördelas.
Det föreslagna svenska stödet syftar till att förbättra förutsättningarna för fred och hållbar utveckling i Colombia genom ökat deltagande av kvinnor och män, ansvarsutkrävande, miljömässig hållbarhet och jämlikhet i landet. Projektet kommer till stor del att fokusera på DNP och nationella riktlinjer, där svenska och internationella exempel och best practice kan hjälpa till för att förbättra utvecklingen av dessa. Det nationella arbetet kommer att kompletteras genom lokalt arbete i ett antal pilotkommuner. På denna nivå syftar projektet till att skapa nya synsätt och vägar för att jobba med deltagande, liksom resultatindikatorer.
Skydd av miljö samt klimatförändringar är viktiga frågor som ingår i processen för lokal fredsbyggnad och anpassning till en postkonfliktsituation. Kvinnor och män måste inkluderas i dialog, olika grupper behöver föras samman kring grundläggande tjänster såsom vatten, sanitet och avfallshantering, som kan leda till förbättringar hur resurser hanteras och deras påverkan på miljön. Utöver att inkludera dessa frågor i den demokratiska deltagandeprocessen, ingår aspekter kring bedömning, övervakning och planering för utvecklingen och användandet av naturresurser, och att inkludera finansiella resurser för att hantera dessa inom ramen för de kommunala budgeterna.
Miljöskydd, användning av naturresurser och de utmaningar som klimatförändringarna medför har högsta prioritet för den colombianska regeringen inom ramen för den nationella planeringen. Landet prioriterar för närvarande stärkande av miljölagar, genomförandet av dessa och utveckling av institutioner med hänsyn till deras betydelse för postkonflikten. DNPs prioriteringar för 2016 fokuserar på reformer relaterade till ett kommande medlemskap i OECD reformer (miljö- och hållbarhetsfrågor), stärkande av medborgarnas delaktighet och lokala territoriella planer. För att uppfylla målen för hållbar utveckling (SDG) kommer det att vara avgörande att säkerställa en förbättring av miljömässig hållbarhet på lokal nivå.
SKL har föreslagit en femårig insats med två huvudresultat och fyra outcomes:
1. Deltagande. Framför allt utveckling av replikerbara modeller för genuint deltagande och inkludering inom specifika sektorer och processer på lokal nivå.
Outcome 1A: Kommuner utvecklar och genomför inkluderande sätt att arbeta som kan replikeras på andra områden. Outcome 1B: DNPs riktlinjer anpassade till lokala verkligheter och internationell erfarenhet avseende deltagande och inkludering.
2. Nationella riktlinjer för territoriell finansiering och styrning. Detta innefattar utveckling av colombianska system för territoriell finansiering och ett jämlikt, hållbart och evidensbaserat system för att utvärdera territoriell styrning.
Outcome 2A: Nationella riktlinjer för territoriell styrning är influerade av lokala verkligheter och internationell erfarenhet avseende jämlika och evidensbaserade riktlinjer. Outcome 2B: DNP har kapacitet att utveckla och implementera effektiva mätinstrument för prestanda.
Projektförslaget från SKL omfattar fem år. Eftersom det för närvarande är sista året för nuvarande samarbetsstrategi för Colombia och en ny strategi är ännu inte beslutad, har ambassaden inte möjlighet att fatta beslut om ett femårigt stöd. Mot denna bakgrund föreslås beslutet att göras på tre år för perioden 2016-2018 med en möjlighet till förlängning för ytterligare två år 2019-2020. Detta passar också bra mot bakgrund av att en Mid Term Review planeras genomföras under 2018, vilken kan leda till förändringar av programmet. Enligt DNP är 2018 också lämpligt som avstämning mot bakgrund att val kommer att ske och en ny regering kommer att tillträda. Under 2019 kommer också lokalval att genomföras. Själva beredningen omfattar emellertid hela projekttiden, dvs. fem år.

The overall development objective is to improve the prospects for peace and sustainable development in Colombia through greater inclusion, accountability and equity at the local level. This overall objective has not changed. From 2016 to 2019 SALAR/SKR worked in three areas of intervention: public participation, conflict management and sub-national performance and statistics information (territorial management. In 2019 inter-municipal cooperation was added as a priority in an effort to strengthen other institutional bodies that are not only the national or local level. In this sense, the project has gone from focusing to a large degree on strengthening Colombia’s National Planning Department’s (DNP) capacities to draft and develop national policies that focus on the municipalities’ needs and realities to increase the support to the local governments, their ability to organise themselves and their joint service delivery trough inter-municipal cooperation. The project’s support to national policy work has from the start been complemented by on-the-ground interventions in pilot municipalities. The extension of one more year (2021) and extra funding are proposed in response to the current Covid 19 context. On one hand, there is a need to have extra time to end the planned activities that have been delayed; on the other hand, the response to the pandemic establishes new challenges that need to be addressed, such as new digital innovative resources and tools. Also, the current context has raised problematics that are necessary to tackle in the areas of intervention such as response to gender violence - that has increased since the confinement - and adequate reactivation of the economic, social and environmental development at national and sub-national level.

sector.narrative: Decentralisation and support to subnational government

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The project has achieved many evidenced outputs as a result of well-planned and realised activities. Component 1 "Participation" has had a clear purpose all along and it has worked with a process oriented approach to citizens participation, focusing on methods and capacity building, training of trainers and implementation where the local government administration gets strengthened and can coordinate and lead new processes of participation. The project has worked with a pedagogical approach where the first step was to build capacity within the local administration with training, workshops and study visits. The main result for this component was the formulation of four "Foincide Plans", one for each municipality, collectively formulated together with participants from the community. These plans are: The Plans were all integrated into a local policy or institutional framework in the municipality and all activities were quite gender balanced. Gender was an important issue that was raised with the municipalities and the tools and methods transferred to the municipalities included strategies to include women in the participatory processes. The main results of these plans were: 1) The change in attitudes of local governments regarding citizens participation processes, 2) Increased local competence in conflict management and in planning of citizen dialogues within complex social situations and 3) Strengthened capacity at DNP. For Component 2 "Development and implementation of performance indicators", the main result was the strengthening of a data web based platform named "TerriData" and its subsequent application for smart phones. TerriData was selected as the Colombian government’s official platform for regional statistics. A mid-term review (MRT) was implemented at the end of 2018 and findings, recommendations and reflexions of the MTR were included in the 2018 report as well as in the project activities that are to be carried out for the next two years. The external evaluator considered that both outputs and outcomes have been delivered according to the projects plan and result matrix.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Denna process måste inledas snabbt och medföra tydliga och klara förändringar efter det att ett fredsavtal har undertecknats, annars kommer förutsättningarna att kunna genomföra ett effektivt fredsbygge på lokal nivå att försvåras år från år.
Lokala myndigheter spelar en viktig roll i fredsbyggnadsprocessen. De har en stark påverkan på fred- och konfliktssituationen på grund av deras närhet, legitimitet och konstanta närvaro i territorierna. I Colombia refererar de föreslagna fredsavtalen till "territoriell fred" (Paz Territorial), viket innebär att fredsprocessen måste anpassas efter och implementeras på lokal nivå. Kapaciteten hos de lokala myndigheterna att genomföra detta varierar mycket och det är därför viktigt att stärka denna kapacitet där det behövs. Viktiga prioriteringar som kommer att inkluderas i det här aktuella projektet, kommer att vara 1) allmänhetens deltagande, 2) system för finansiella transfereringar mellan myndigheter, samt 3) metoder för att utveckla lokala myndigheters resultatindikatorer. Jämställdhet samt miljö och klimat är centrala områden i det föreslagna samarbetet. Bl.a. väntas ingå tillhandahållande av offentliga tjänster för kvinnor och män, inklusive vatten och sanitet samt avfallshantering.
Allmänhetens deltagande: Det finns behov av att genomföra en verklig förändring vad gäller kvinnors och mäns deltagande i politiska processer, från dagens förhållande där denna till stor del sker formalistiskt utan verklig effekt, till en situation där denna sker på ett effektivt och verkningsfullt sätt. Svenska erfarenheter inom området kan bidra som inspiration för denna förändring gentemot ett mer inkluderande förhållningssätt för deltagande och social dialog. SKL har stött kommuner, landsting och regioner i Sverige för att utveckla en medborgerlig dialog, samarbeta med civilsamhället samt skapa öppenhet och transparens. Detta inkluderar utveckling av metoder för strategier för deltagande i potentiellt kontroversiella situationer och sätt att engagera politiska ledare för att främja allmänhetens deltagande.
Nationella riktlinjer för territoriell styrning, inklusive finansiering och prestandamätning: Utifrån ett postkonfliktperspektiv är det nödvändigt att öka de finansiella resurserna för svagare och konfliktdrabbade kommuner. Den huvudsakliga finansieringen i Colombia är det generella systemet för statliga bidrag till lokala och regionala enheter (Sistema General de Participaciones, SPG). Transfers genom detta system är till stor del öronmärkta för särskilda ändamål, vilket hindrar de svagare kommunerna att förbättra andra behov. De verkar dessutom hämmande för genuint deltagande eftersom kommunerna inte kan påverka hur resurserna används. DNP tittar för närvarande på formler för hur omdistribution av medlen kan förändras. I detta sammanhang måste också frågor avseende de stora skillnaderna vad gäller generering av egna inkomster mellan colombianska kommuner, omfördelning av royalties samt en föreslagen fond för postkonfliktstöd. Varje försök till förändring av systemet måste också se till att försöka öka de sammantagna inkomsterna som skall fördelas.
Det föreslagna svenska stödet syftar till att förbättra förutsättningarna för fred och hållbar utveckling i Colombia genom ökat deltagande av kvinnor och män, ansvarsutkrävande, miljömässig hållbarhet och jämlikhet i landet. Projektet kommer till stor del att fokusera på DNP och nationella riktlinjer, där svenska och internationella exempel och best practice kan hjälpa till för att förbättra utvecklingen av dessa. Det nationella arbetet kommer att kompletteras genom lokalt arbete i ett antal pilotkommuner. På denna nivå syftar projektet till att skapa nya synsätt och vägar för att jobba med deltagande, liksom resultatindikatorer.
Skydd av miljö samt klimatförändringar är viktiga frågor som ingår i processen för lokal fredsbyggnad och anpassning till en postkonfliktsituation. Kvinnor och män måste inkluderas i dialog, olika grupper behöver föras samman kring grundläggande tjänster såsom vatten, sanitet och avfallshantering, som kan leda till förbättringar hur resurser hanteras och deras påverkan på miljön. Utöver att inkludera dessa frågor i den demokratiska deltagandeprocessen, ingår aspekter kring bedömning, övervakning och planering för utvecklingen och användandet av naturresurser, och att inkludera finansiella resurser för att hantera dessa inom ramen för de kommunala budgeterna.
Miljöskydd, användning av naturresurser och de utmaningar som klimatförändringarna medför har högsta prioritet för den colombianska regeringen inom ramen för den nationella planeringen. Landet prioriterar för närvarande stärkande av miljölagar, genomförandet av dessa och utveckling av institutioner med hänsyn till deras betydelse för postkonflikten. DNPs prioriteringar för 2016 fokuserar på reformer relaterade till ett kommande medlemskap i OECD reformer (miljö- och hållbarhetsfrågor), stärkande av medborgarnas delaktighet och lokala territoriella planer. För att uppfylla målen för hållbar utveckling (SDG) kommer det att vara avgörande att säkerställa en förbättring av miljömässig hållbarhet på lokal nivå.
SKL har föreslagit en femårig insats med två huvudresultat och fyra outcomes:
1. Deltagande. Framför allt utveckling av replikerbara modeller för genuint deltagande och inkludering inom specifika sektorer och processer på lokal nivå.
Outcome 1A: Kommuner utvecklar och genomför inkluderande sätt att arbeta som kan replikeras på andra områden. Outcome 1B: DNPs riktlinjer anpassade till lokala verkligheter och internationell erfarenhet avseende deltagande och inkludering.
2. Nationella riktlinjer för territoriell finansiering och styrning. Detta innefattar utveckling av colombianska system för territoriell finansiering och ett jämlikt, hållbart och evidensbaserat system för att utvärdera territoriell styrning.
Outcome 2A: Nationella riktlinjer för territoriell styrning är influerade av lokala verkligheter och internationell erfarenhet avseende jämlika och evidensbaserade riktlinjer. Outcome 2B: DNP har kapacitet att utveckla och implementera effektiva mätinstrument för prestanda.
Projektförslaget från SKL omfattar fem år. Eftersom det för närvarande är sista året för nuvarande samarbetsstrategi för Colombia och en ny strategi är ännu inte beslutad, har ambassaden inte möjlighet att fatta beslut om ett femårigt stöd. Mot denna bakgrund föreslås beslutet att göras på tre år för perioden 2016-2018 med en möjlighet till förlängning för ytterligare två år 2019-2020. Detta passar också bra mot bakgrund av att en Mid Term Review planeras genomföras under 2018, vilken kan leda till förändringar av programmet. Enligt DNP är 2018 också lämpligt som avstämning mot bakgrund att val kommer att ske och en ny regering kommer att tillträda. Under 2019 kommer också lokalval att genomföras. Själva beredningen omfattar emellertid hela projekttiden, dvs. fem år.

The overall development objective is to improve the prospects for peace and sustainable development in Colombia through greater inclusion, accountability and equity at the local level. This overall objective has not changed. From 2016 to 2019 SALAR/SKR worked in three areas of intervention: public participation, conflict management and sub-national performance and statistics information (territorial management. In 2019 inter-municipal cooperation was added as a priority in an effort to strengthen other institutional bodies that are not only the national or local level. In this sense, the project has gone from focusing to a large degree on strengthening Colombia’s National Planning Department’s (DNP) capacities to draft and develop national policies that focus on the municipalities’ needs and realities to increase the support to the local governments, their ability to organise themselves and their joint service delivery trough inter-municipal cooperation. The project’s support to national policy work has from the start been complemented by on-the-ground interventions in pilot municipalities. The extension of one more year (2021) and extra funding are proposed in response to the current Covid 19 context. On one hand, there is a need to have extra time to end the planned activities that have been delayed; on the other hand, the response to the pandemic establishes new challenges that need to be addressed, such as new digital innovative resources and tools. Also, the current context has raised problematics that are necessary to tackle in the areas of intervention such as response to gender violence - that has increased since the confinement - and adequate reactivation of the economic, social and environmental development at national and sub-national level.

sector.narrative: Decentralisation and support to subnational government

tag.narrative: 16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

description.narrative: The project has achieved many evidenced outputs as a result of well-planned and realised activities. Component 1 "Participation" has had a clear purpose all along and it has worked with a process oriented approach to citizens participation, focusing on methods and capacity building, training of trainers and implementation where the local government administration gets strengthened and can coordinate and lead new processes of participation. The project has worked with a pedagogical approach where the first step was to build capacity within the local administration with training, workshops and study visits. The main result for this component was the formulation of four "Foincide Plans", one for each municipality, collectively formulated together with participants from the community. These plans are: The Plans were all integrated into a local policy or institutional framework in the municipality and all activities were quite gender balanced. Gender was an important issue that was raised with the municipalities and the tools and methods transferred to the municipalities included strategies to include women in the participatory processes. The main results of these plans were: 1) The change in attitudes of local governments regarding citizens participation processes, 2) Increased local competence in conflict management and in planning of citizen dialogues within complex social situations and 3) Strengthened capacity at DNP. For Component 2 "Development and implementation of performance indicators", the main result was the strengthening of a data web based platform named "TerriData" and its subsequent application for smart phones. TerriData was selected as the Colombian government’s official platform for regional statistics. A mid-term review (MRT) was implemented at the end of 2018 and findings, recommendations and reflexions of the MTR were included in the 2018 report as well as in the project activities that are to be carried out for the next two years. The external evaluator considered that both outputs and outcomes have been delivered according to the projects plan and result matrix.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Colombia 2016-2021
strategy.titleSV: Colombia 2016-2021

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Sida's bidrag till FN:s fredsfond för Colombia. Fonden ger bidrag till insatser för stabilisering förtroendeskapande samt genomförandet av fredsavtalet mellan den colombianska regeringen och FARC, i syfte att: 1. Öka lokalbefolkningens förtroende för statliga institutioner på nationell och lokal nivå. 2. Öka människors och i synnerhet offren och / medborgares förtroende för fredsprocessen i de områden som drabbats hårdast av konflikten. 3. Förhindra och/eller minska brott och våld i samband med utbrott av väpnade konflikter och demobiliseringsprocesser. 4. Hantera konfliktsituationer på lokal nivå genom tidiga insatser (rapid response). 5. Bidra till att skapa fredsvinster, konkreta positiva förbättringar för människors dagliga liv, inom områdena säkerhet, rättvisa och utveckling. Andra givare till fonden inkluderar Canada, Irland, Norge, Storbritannien, Tyskland, och Schweiz.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Sida's contribution to the UN multi-partner trust fund for Colombia. The fund supports actions for stabilization, building trust and implementation of the Peace Accords between the colombian government and FARC, aiming to: 1. Increase trust in public instutions among the local population; 2. Increase trust in the peace process, in particular among victims and Citizens in conflict affected areas; 3. Prevent crimes and voilence in armed conflict and demobilizationsprocesses. 4. Manage conflictivity at local level through rapid response 5. contribute to create peace gains, positive change in people's daily lives in the areas of security, justice and development. Other donors to the fund include Canada, Ireland, Norway, Great Britain, Germany and Switzerland.

tag.narrative: 16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The results for UN Multi-donor trust fund in Colombia, UN Fund for Post-conflict Colombia are progressing according to plan. During its first year of existence, the fund has managed to support early implementation of the Peace agreement between the Colombian government and the FARC. The fund has among other thing strengthened local capacity through training in human rights, social dialogue and Citizen participation. Through the fund 118 conflict affected municipalities have received 291 students supporting the municipality in the process of constructing Peace. In addition the fund has supported 11 infrastructure protects (schools, communal centres, roads, water facilities) benefiting 26 000 women, men, girls and boys as well as providing employment to 186 people. The fund has also supported collective reparation programs where for instance the leaders of FARC give a public excuse to communities affected by the violence of the internal conflict. In the polarised Colombian society, the fund has also supported communication activities informing 200 000 Colombians about the peace agreement and the importance of all Colombians contribution constructing a sustainable peace. The fund has proved to be an effective instrument for both donor coordination and national ownership. The fund is unique for UN as it does not only involve UN and donors, but also the active leadership of the Colombian government.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: We Effect Mayakvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt på landsbygden
We Effect Rural Mayan Women’s Economic Empowerment

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Utvecklingsinsatsen syftar till att minska fattigdom bland ursprungsbefolkningar i fyra territorier på landsbygden i Guatemala genom ett fokus på kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt och förebyggande av könsbaserat våld. Totalt förväntas 7500 ekonomiska initiativ sammansatta och ledda av kvinnor få tillgång till tekniskt och finansiellt stöd, förbättrad tillgång till lokala, regionala och nationella marknader. We Effect samarbetar med tio lokala organisationer i implementeringen av projektet under åren 2016-2020.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 This intervention aims to reduce poverty and violence on indigenous people, particularly Mayan women in four territories of Guatemala, promoting Women´s Economic Empowerment, through strengthening their capacities on productive technical matters and entrepreneurship; strengthening the peasant organizations capacities to ensure their response to their members to reduce poverty and strengthening advocacy work. The project also aims to improve market access and position of rural Mayan women within a framework of organizational strengthening and deepening knowledge of rights and demands for rights compliance, recognizing that economic empowerment ensures sustainable individual, collective and political empowerment.
The State and other actors contribute to rights holders’ poverty and violence reduction, especially for indigenous women in four rural territories of Guatemala.

tag.narrative: 1.1 - By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.
1.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa den extrema fattigdomen för alla människor överallt. Med extrem fattigdom avses för närvarande människor som lever på mindre än 1,25 US-dollar per dag.
2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

description.narrative: Main achieved results: 71 agricultural and livestock productive ventures were implemented by 3,566 women in covered territories of the project (145 rural indigenous communities). Ventures have meant for the families a source of income and have help to meet their basic needs such as food security; ventures also have contributed to generate some employment and self-employment. The Peasant households produce mainly for home consumption, some surplus is being marketed in local and national markets and to a lesser extent in international fair-trade markets such as honey and coffee. These peasant rural women, who have lacked to economic opportunities, before the project 63% of 5,566 participant women, did not have any economic income, currently from their ventures they get around SEK 1200 in profit per production. Due to the accumulation of historical inequalities suffered by rural indigenous women, holistic women’s empowerment has been uphill; however, 35% of women in the project, declare having decision-making power over economic resources at home. To enhance and grow women’s small ventures, productive technical assistance, sustainable planting and harvesting methods have been provided to women. As well as some techniques adapted to climate change and some alternative technologies such as water harvesting and preparation of organic fertilizers have been introduced, which have contributed to increase crop yields and to enhance women producer agricultural practices. Women's economic empowerment besides, has required training/workshops on business and markets (design of business plans, search for markets, calculation of prices and access to micro finance), that help women to develop/refine their business plan, and enhance or grow their small business. It is important to mention that to conduct women economic processes We Effect is based on a principle of a "Feminist Economy". Gender equality and gender-based violence prevention, have been impetrative to promote women’s economic empowerment. In 8 partner organisations, communities and with involved families, awareness processes have conducted, as well as, campaigns in different media such as radio, theatre, forums, posters, etc. Men's schools for equality (which included training for adults and youth) were created. To overcome constraints that women face to participle in community and productive activities, through the project’s promoters home visits to raise awareness in the family about a better distribution of household chores were carried out. In accordance with We Effect, 21% of participant women report positive changes regarding a better distribution of roles at home. Due to inequalities of level that women face, these changes can be considered significant results. Besides 93.71% of the target groups consider that violence against women it is not naturally or culturally acceptable. We Effect also focuses on the institutional strengthening of its partner organizations, so eight partner organizations were trained on administrative, financial and governance issues; as well as 3 women's cooperatives of saving and credits were created. The partner organisations managed to establish strategic alliances at the community, municipal and departmental levels. Among other results, seven women's ventures has started to supply agricultural products to the State, within the national school feeding program, for this, women were trained by the project on the State procurement procedures, quality of the products, among other aspects.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Helvetas project inclusive economic and social development-Scaling up phase
Helvetas projekt för en inkluderande ekonomisk och social utveckling Första fas

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Utvecklingsinsatsen syftar till att minska fattigdom hos landsbygdsbefolkning på västra höglandet i Guatemala genom att facilitera produktiv sysselsättning och utnyttja potential och kulturella värden i den lokala produktionen. Insatsen riktar sig särskilt till urfolkskvinnor. Totalt 26 750 familjer kommer att kunna dra nytta av tekniskt bistånd, förbättrade jordbruksmetoder, tillgång till finansiella tjänster för att utveckla sin produktiva verksamhet, samt tillgång till nationella och internationella marknader. Insatsen genomförs i samarbete med lokala företag, jordbruksorganisationer, samt med nationella och lokala myndigheter.
Helvetas ansöker om tilläggsmedel om 79 800 000 SEK för perioden 2018-2021 för att genomföra utvecklingsinsatsen. Helvetas kommer även att tillföra egna medel om 7 200 000 SEK för expanderingsfasen som startar 2018, och viss delfinansiering kommer att tillhandahållas av kommunerna.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 PRODERT Scaling-up objective is: "Vulnerable rural population particularly indigenous women increase their income and productive employment by capitalising on the potential of local production and cultural values in five departments of the western highlands of Guatemala". The intervention seeks to achieve sustainable results over time and disseminate good practices of the current "Territorial Rural Economic Development Project" PRODERT, in order for the market systems to work more effectively and inclusively in favour of the poor, as well as to increase the number of beneficiaries with potential to increase income and participate in market systems (from 7,500 to 26,750 direct beneficiaries), and increasing geographical coverage from 16 to 27 municipalities in the Departments of Huehuetenango, San Marcos, Totonicapán, Quiché and Quetzaltenango. During this phase the project is expected to develop complementary alliances with potential market partners to support innovations in order to increase scale, scope and to strengthen the target groups response capacity, sustainability and resilience. According to Helvetas, due to the positive results of the previous phases of PRODERT, there is an imminent interest in the selected communities where the population has expressed strong interest to participate in the project. Until now, it has not been possible to incorporate them due to lack of funds.´Based on a previous MSD/M4P analysis, main identified constrains of the target groups to be part of the market systems are: (i) to reach a good level of associativity, (ii) lack of inclusive financial services (iii) lack of technical assistance and (iv) business development. In collaboration with different public, private and civil society actors the project with a catalyst role is expected to facilitate systemic changes in the identified constraints and Helvetas will focus on overcome these barriers. Preliminarily the intervention will support the development of 6 viable value chains with market potential and scaling up: potatoes, coffee, vegetables, handicrafts, beekeeping and sheep.
PRODERT Scaling up amounts SEK 79 800 000, for the period 2018 – 2021. Besides, as part of this intervention it is estimated that the Department of Loans and Guarantees at Sida Headquarter (HQ) will support a guarantee and capital risk instrument, the cost of the guarantee is not still defined. A mission from the Sida HQ visited Guatemala in October 2017 to start assessing this specific support.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

5.4 - Erkänna och värdesätta obetalt omsorgs- och hushållsarbete genom att tillhandahålla offentliga tjänster, infrastruktur och socialt skydd samt genom att främja delat ansvar inom hushållet och familjen, i enlighet med vad som är nationellt lämpligt.

5.4 - Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

description.narrative: This intervention has a Market System Development-MSD or Market for the Poor-M4P approach, so it is not considered a conventional project, an enterprise network is also used. Under MSD approach the intervention seeks to involve poor people in economic growth. The project instead to have an implementer role, assumes a facilitator role of systemic changes in market players. At this stage, the project is already capable of demonstrating changes in the different systems, e.g. institutions/entities with a formal structure that are playing various roles in the market system. Under this logic, an achieved results chain is presented. [Changes in actors] Municipal governments in covered territories have co-invested around USD 390,000.00) in developing enterprise networks' value chains, this means that the project does not invest anymore in these chains but rather they are being financed by other actors such as municipal governments, the private sector and by the same enterprise networks. Incidence on local public policy: public policies for Local Economic Development were formulated in eleven municipalities, where private actors are the protagonists, and the state is a facilitator of the favorable environment for development. Enterprise networks methodology is used by at least eight development organizations. Enterprises networks methodology is used by Helvetas as a strategy to promote associativity among small rural producers, to overcome difficulties inherent in the sector and thus be able to collectively achieve economies of scale. [Market system change] Fourteen private companies (customers and suppliers) are linked to business networks. Eight private companies provide technical assistance services to the agricultural sector. The enterprise networks also provide the producers through technical assistance promoters technical assistance in communities where it is not possible to have access to these services. Impact [Changes in the target group]: The Market Systems Development approach has become stronger to improve rural population access to markets, as a result 8,340 families (41,700 people) improved income and their quality of live. 250 enterprise networks were established. These enterprise networks implemented 10 agricultural and livestock value chains which generated approximately USD 2.6 million in sales. 65% of the target group are rural indigenous women. Other important achieved results: Challenge fund: Since this contribution has an approach to linking producers to markets a kind of "challenge fund" (FIAGRO) was established. This challenge fund seeks to create mutual trust between all actors in a chain. Usually this initiative involves organizing farmers into groups to supply identified markets, to provide technical assistance, training, input and productive infrastructure such as ferti-irrigation, drip irrigation systems, technology for adaptation of potato cultivation, livestock facilities, all with an environmental focus. Under this modality, to link producers, both the project and the private company co invest in a project (50% -50%). Environment and climate change: Two regional agro-climatic tables were established, from where weather forecasts are made, agronomic models are proposed and information on adaptive measures to climate change and recommendations are generated.Women's Economic Empowerment:With members of the families, awareness and training processes on Domestic co responsibility, violence against women, economic autonomy and route of reporting cases of violence issues were carried out. 60% of women participate in management positions within entrepreneur networks. Project's actions has been developed with a women's economic empowerment approach. The project promotes gender within the project's partner organizations, as a result, three gender and social inclusion policies were formulated. These included components of women's economic empowerment link to value chains, and political and social empowerment.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Guatemala 2016-2021
strategy.titleSV: Guatemala 2016-2021

title.narrative: FAO & UNICEF stöd till familjer som drabbats av torkan i Guatemala år 2014.
FAO & UNICEF support to families affected by drought 2014 in Guatemala.

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Guatemala har upplevt en förlängd period av torka under 2014, vilket har påverkan främst i de nordöstra delarna av landet och det område som kallas "den torra korridoren". Torkan har särskilt påverkat personer i fattigdom och extremfattigdom som är beroende av jordbruk för deras uppehälle. Guatemalas regering förklarade katastroftillstånd i de drabbade departementen och framförde en vädjan om humanitärt bistånd. Regeringen lanserade också en plan bistå befolkningen som drabbats. Planen omfattar tre strategier: 1) humanitärt bistånd, 2) återhämtning av försörjningsmöjligheter och 3) motståndskraft och anpassning till klimatförändringar. FN systemet i Guatemala presenterade en omgripande plan som svar på regeringens förfrågan om stöd. Detta projekt är baserat på FAO och UNICEFs föreslagna roller på medel- och långsikt i den planen. Projektet är därmed i linje med Guatemalas regeringsplan för bistånd på medellång och lång sikt: 2) återhämtning av försörjningsmöjligheter och 3) motståndskraft och anpassning till klimatförändringar. Projektansökan är för en period på två år och budgeten är på 20 MSEK. Initiativet syftar till att återställa försörjningsmöjligheter för de familjer som drabbats av den långvariga torkan under 2014, samt skapa motståndskraft hos dem genom metoder för handhålland och bevarande av jord och vatten i kommuner i regionerna Chiquimula och Jalapa.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Guatemala has experienced a prolonged drought during 2014 affecting the north east of the country. The drought has particularly affected smallholder farmers with subsistence and infra subsistence production in the area known as the dry corridor. The Guatemalan government declared a state of emergency in the affected departments and submitted an appeal for humanitarian aid. The government, through its Council of Nutrition and Food Security, SESAN (for its acronym in Spanish), has recognized the damages caused by the extended drought. This led to the government declaring State of Public Calamity in the departments affected and made an appeal for humanitarian assistance. The government also launched a plan to attend the population affected that includes three strategies: 1) humanitarian assistance, 2) livelihoods recovery and 3) resilience and adaptation to climate change. The United Nations system in Guatemala presented a response plan in reaction to the government's request for support. This project is based on the proposed roles for FAO and UNICEF in the medium and long term of the plan. The project is therefore in line with the Guatemalan government plan for the assistance in the medium and long term: 2) recovery of livelihoods and 3) the resilience and adaptation to climate change. The project application is for a period of two years and a budget of 20 MSEK. The contribution aims to recover the livelihoods of the families affected by prolonged drought of 2014, as well as, to create resilience through management and conservation of soil and water in Chiquimula and Jalapa.

tag.narrative: 1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
15.3 - By 2030, combat desertification, restore degraded land and soil, including land affected by desertification, drought and floods, and strive to achieve a land degradation-neutral world.

15.3 - Till 2030 bekämpa ökenspridning, återställa förstörd mark och jord, inklusive mark som drabbats av ökenspridning, torka och översvämningar, samt sträva efter att uppnå en värld utan nettoförstöring av mark.

2.4 - By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2.4 - Senast 2030 uppnå hållbara system för livsmedelsproduktion samt införa motståndskraftiga jordbruksmetoder som ökar produktiviteten och produktionen, som bidrar till att upprätthålla ekosystemen, som stärker förmågan till anpassning till klimatförändringar, extrema väderförhållanden, torka, översvämning och andra katastrofer och som successivt förbättrar mark- och jordkvaliteten.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.
6.6 - By 2020, protect and restore water-related ecosystems, including mountains, forests, wetlands, rivers, aquifers and lakes.
6.6 - Senast 2020 skydda och återställa de vattenrelaterade ekosystemen, däribland berg, skogar, våtmarker, floder, akviferer och sjöar.
6.b - Stödja och stärka lokalsamhällenas deltagande i arbetet med att förbättra vatten- och sanitetshanteringen.
6.b - Support and strengthen the participation of local communities in improving water and sanitation management.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: During 2019, 2,021 families from which 64% are women household harvest 14.1 million liters of rainwater, this allowed them to produce animal and vegetable protein for their consumption and surplus sales for US36,000 over the year. 6,502 families, about 92% of the total families attended, are involved in savings for communitarian loans, this is an important financial resilience process, since is the only access they have for credit, currently the manage a fund of US88,900.00. 4,204 women involved in capacity building for sexual and reproductive health, self-esteem, project management and exchanges with other women. The work performed to promote integrated micro-watershed management resulted in the adoption of Milpa and Home Patio food systems and the introduction of 22 good practices to increase resilience to drought mostly related to water systems improvements, conservation and use of water resources, soil and forests. At this point, the practices are sustainable given that the families have been witnesses of the development (improvement) of their plots, which has implied more food availability, more yields and in some cases income generation through the surplus sales. The main challenges still the staff turn-over in the municipalities and the Ministry of Agriculture extensionists.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: UNDP - Cuilco Rural Development Joint Program

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen, som leds av UNDP, bygger på det sammarbete som tre FN organen har haft under första delen av projektet "Joint Program" i San Marcos regionen. Där uppnåddes en väl fungerande interinstitutionell samordning mellan UNDP- FAO -WHO, civilsamhället, samt lokala och centrala myndigheter. denna insats bygger vidare på detta och har som målsättning att förbättra levnadsvillkoren för familjer som livnär sig på jordbruk och förbättra deras tillgång till sjukvård samt motsståndskraft mot naturkatastrofer. Denna fas 2 kommer verka i kommuner som inte inkluderades i FAS 1 nämligen Comitancillo, San Miguel Ixtahuacán, Concepción Tutuapa, Sipacapa y Tejutla i San Marcos. Initiativet kommer även att arbeta med att förbättra kapaciteten bland aktörer från civilsamhället, lokala och centrala myndigheter för att säkerställa framtagandet och implementeringen av kommunala utvecklingsplaner, samt främja deltagande i lokala utvecklingskommittéer för att främja lokala investeringar.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The proposal aims to replicate inter-institutional coordination between UN Agencies, civil society, local and central government to reproduce successful experience from previous Joint Program in San Marcos Region. The program intents to: improve livelihoods, health and resilience of poor peasant families with productions of subsistence and Infra subsistence in rural poor areas of Comitancillo, San Miguel Ixtahuacán, Concepción Tutuapa, Sipacapa y Tejutla of San Marcos, Guatemala. The program will also strength capacities of civil society, local and central government with presence in the area to enhance the preparation and implementation of Municipal Development Plan and promote participation on Development Council System as a way to reach investment on the region.

description.narrative: The results achieved described here are updated, based in the most recent field visit to the Program, which was held on January 20-23 of 2020. One of the most relevant impacts of the program is the "Institutional Coordination" given that before the program the government institutions worked separately (independent from one each other) there was no dialogue to better address the challenges in their territories. The program has been providing spaces for coordination by providing evidence of the need to understand the territory problems in a holistic way. Now the government institutions work together, they agree on ways to address problems and challenges. The program has also facilitated training on the normative framework to help the government institutions to better use their resources. Even in the financial resources of the government institutions are limited the coordination has allowed a better use if the resources available. The government institutions involved were: Ministry of Health MSPAS; Planning Secretariat SEGEPLAN; Ministry of Agriculture - MAGA; Forestry Institute - INAB; Environment Ministry - MARN; Education Ministry - MINEDUC; Presidency Coordination Secretariat - SCEP; Women Municipal Office - DMM/ Women Secretariat - SEPREM. To date the coordinated work has addressed challenges such as: malnutrition (MAGA, MSPAS and Municipalities); poverty and income generation, climate risk prevention. The government representatives shared how the Program has been a support for them in terms of its contribution to better understand each institution mandate and their interdependence to fulfill their roles as duty bearers. The representatives of government institutions mentioned that they have understood that development depends in their ability to work together in a comprehensive way. They also mentioned that they can see better results of their work in the municipalities where the Joint Program worked, where they have been able to join their efforts and complement each other while strengthening through training. In this sense, the representatives have also replicated this joint approach to development challenges in municipalities not supported by the Joint Program. They were very proud for the improvement of the services provided to citizenship. The Joint Program has been very careful to maintain their facilitator role through accompaniment, technical support and training in order to never substitute the role and mandate of the government institutions. Communitarian Development Councils, Micro Watershed Councils, Health Commissions and Local Coordinators for Risk Reduction have been strengthened through training and accompaniment to apply the Law of Development Councils which implies access to government funding. One of the program impacts is that it facilitates to activate the public policy structures to support rural communities to access more public resources and services. Regarding the work directly with families, the program supports the most vulnerable (in habitat and malnutrition) families to improve their living habitat and access to food. For example, the case of a women who was planning to migrate to United States to financially support her four children, but after receiving training and technical support to design her life plan and her family habitat improvements she started to invest in her house (wood and her own work) to provide better conditions for her children, the Program also invested in her home improvements but the Program contributions were up to 30%. In this example de women house was very close to the steep slope the house is now out of risk to slide. Regarding mother and child health, which is closely linked to malnutrition prevention, the Program has supported the Ministry of Health to improve the Maternal-child attention Center - CAIMI in Tejutla, to the point where the Ministry of Health - MSPAS manifested that the supported CAIMI is the example of the minimum every CAIMI should be in San Marcos. Through the program MSPAS and World Health Organization - WHO where able to support the improvement of processes and equipment of the CAIMI in Tejutla. CAIMI has been strengthened with two obstetricians (Paid by MSPAS), laboratory equipment, ultra-sound equipment which has allowed a more effective attention to pregnant mothers, they also improved operating rooms allowing them to perform emergency caesarean. As an achievement there have been no maternal deaths in the municipalities where the Program works. Given that more women have been able to access health services, since before the Program´s support the CAIMI used to attend 300 births per year but in 2019 it passed to attend 900 normal births and 125 cesarean deliveries. As well, the number of malnourished children dropped from 46 to 14. Regarding support to municipalities, the Municipality of Tejutla where the Program also supported the transition process to the new elected authorities. The monitoring visit mission was able to meet with the outgoing municipal corporation and the newly elected. The previous Mayor presented the results of the strengthening to the municipality regarding: improvement of municipal income, strengthening the Municipal development Council COMUDE; creation of the Risk Management Unit - UMGAR; strengthening of Women Municipal Office - DMM, strengthening of the Municipal Water Office OMAS; increased citizenship participation in the municipalities decisions, creation of the Municipal Development Plan - PDM with territorial planning approach. For more details please refer to the January 2020 Travel Report.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Guatemala 2016-2021
strategy.titleSV: Guatemala 2016-2021

title.narrative: UNDP - Ixil Rural Development Joint Program

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen ”Gemensamma programmet för landsbygdsutveckling i Ixil” har utvecklats under ramverket för den i övergångsrättvisa förekommande principen om icke-upprepning (aldrig mer-principen) såsom ett svar på en begäran från offren under den interna väpnade konflikten i Guatemala om att adressera möjligheten till ekonomiska och andra utvecklingsmöjligheter på lokal nivå och som ett komplement till "Program till stöd för övergångsrättvisa i Guatemala PAJUST", vilket stöds och har stötts av Sverige under flera år. Programmet är ett integrerat landsbygdsutvecklingsprogram som har som mål att öka återhämtningsmöjligheterna för de familjer som föll offer för den interna väpnade konflikten i Santa María Nebaj, Cotzal och Chajul, som samtliga tillhör regionen Quiché i Guatemala genom en helhetssyn på landsbygdsutveckling vilken även omfattar ett hållbart brukande och förvaltning av naturresurser. Helhetssynen omfattar att arbeta med familjer som driver småbruk för det egna uppehället, för att förbättra familjernas hälsa, näringsintag, boende och närområde, förvaltning och hantering av utveckling ifråga om resurser och naturresurser samt kunskaper i företagande. Programmet kombinerar sagda teman med att arbeta med lokala och centrala myndigheter verksamma i Ixil för att utveckla och förbättra kunskaperna inom staten för att uppnå ett inkluderande och fredligt styre utifrån ett rättighets- och återhämtningsperspektiv.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The program Ixil Rural Development Joint Program has been designed under the framework of non-repetition measures of Transitional Justice, as a response to armed conflict victims request to access to economic and local development opportunities and as a complement to PAJUST- Transitional Justice Program sponsored by Embassy of Sweden in Guatemala. The program is an integral rural development program that aims to increase resilience of families victims of armed conflict in Santa María Nebaj, Cotzal and Chajul, department of Quiché,Guatemala, through a holistic rural development approach and natural resources sustainable management. The holistic approach includes working with families with agricultural productions subsistence and infra subsistence to improve their health, nutrition, habitat, development management, natural resources governance and their entrepreneurship capabilities. As well as, working with local government and central government institutions delegated in the Ixil region to develop capacities to reach inclusive and pacific governance with a rights approach and a culture of resilience.

description.narrative: Results achieved during 2019: - With the program support, the three supported municipalities are implementing financial and public services strategies; have designed tools for planning and territorial ordering aligned to Guatemala´s development Plan K´atun. The three municipalities have Municipal Development Councils - COMUDE working in accordance to the Development Councils Law. The three municipalities have increased their revenues, increased the allocation of funds from Departmental Development Council - CODEDE. Two municipalities (Nebaj and Cotzal) have increased their position in the Municipal Ranking and citizen participation; they have also increased their investments in water and sanitation, education and income generation in Q2.3 million. - The program has supported the improvement of the habitat conditions, food security and child-mother health in the three municipalities. where 1,936 families have increased their consumption and availability of food; improved their habitat by avoiding risks of extreme weather and sanitation; reduced the gastrointestinal and respiratory diseases. - The program has also worked to empower 224 Ixil youth in citizen participation, advocacy, entrepreneurship and income generation. - The program has also contributed to empower 524 women involved in entrepreneurial agriculture and non-agriculture organizations to strengthen their participation and decision making, their advocacy capabilities and to improve their income. - The three Women Municipal Directorates have an assigned budget to support income generation, health and education activities for at least 400 women. - The Program has also contributed to reduce conflict through the support to the inter-institutional dialogue to address agrarian conflicts through the Voluntary Guidelines for Land Governance achieving the solution to 5 agrarian conflicts. - Regarding environment and climate change adaption, the program has supported the training and implementation to introduce practices for protection and management of natural resources with a watershed approach. The Program has achieved to implement 18 agro-ecological practices that have significantly reduced the burning of crop residues and pesticide use. - The Program has also supported the join production (Municipalities, government institutions and community organizations) of 100,000 forest plants and endemic fruit trees; achieving more seeds adapted to the region, increasing the quality and adaptability of the seedlings for reforestation of the upper basin of the five micro basins of the Ixil region.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Insatsen avser system för social trygghet, socialförsäkring och arbetsmarknadsprogram. Det övergripande målet är att förbättra de fattigas motståndskraft mot oväntade katastrofer och kriser.

title.narrative: Amendment of agreement between Sida and World Bank Rapid Social Response 2020
Beslut om ändring av avtal mellan Sida och World Bank Rapid Social Response 2020

description.narrative: The Rapid Social Response Multi-donor Trust Fund was designed as a response to meet the effects of the financial crises in 2008-2009. Overall it has had extensive effects for promoting expansion of social protection as a tool to reduce poverty. Since its inception the RSR has approved 260 activities in 100 countries with support amounting to 122 million USD. It is estimated that the RSR through strategic interventions has contributed to leverage 10,8 billion USD in financing from the International Devleopment Association (IDA). The systems reviews, studies and development of capacity and technical know-how has formed the basis for designing and implementing large-scale social protection programmes that reaches an estimated 176 million people. The RSR also gathers practioners in partner countries for knowledge exhange and dialogue in South-South learning forums that has gathered over 1600 participants from 100 countries and also has a "community of practice" for countinous exchange with over 570 participants. A specific component of the RSR is also targeted to knowledge generation with policy and methods development which is essential for expansion of the right to social protection. RSR reports on results bi-annually with a delay in reports which means the latest report covering 2017 to December 2018 was received in November 2019. The report was discussed at a donor meeting in Ankara in November 2019, with Sida participating on-line. In the latest reported period 2017-2018 there is a decline in approved applications during 2018 which also reflects the decline in the available budget for the RSR MDTF. In December 2018, 5,3 MUSD remained of the total budget of 112MUSD. An updated budget overview in November 2019 showed that 3,8MUSD remained of the total budget of the RSR Classic. The main donors that have contributed to the RSR are; Russia, United Kingdom (DFID), Norway, Sweden, Australia and Denmark, Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, and GFDRR (Global Facility for Disaster Risk Reduction). During the implementation period, the original RSR MDTF has also been complemented with specific "windows" with ear-marked thematic support. Russia has supported a window on nutrition-sensitive social protection, while Denmark has support a window focused on youth. In late 2018 the RSR MDTF was complemented with a gender window focused on gender-integration in social protection schemes, which was supported by DFID and Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation with in total 12,2 MUSD. In March 2020, Australia agreed to provide additional funds to the original trust fund "RSR Classic" to support governments to rapidly develop strategies to meet the challenge of increased poverty during the Covid-19 pandemic. The wide scope of the RSR has made aggregation of results challenging, while results are clear in the large number of satisfactory interventions that have been financed which has resulted in development of key aspects of social protection systems in 100 countries. The targeted windows have provided a clearer overview of results and has also enabled focus on strategic aspects. The gender-window supported by DFID was a result of low priority of gender integration in the initiatives that applied for support from the RSR. A few highlights can be mentioned to provide examples of results achieved from the 300 initiatives that were supported during 2017-2018 to improve social protection and labour systems components and architecture to which over 22 MUSD were allocated. In Botswana the RSR grant contributed to the preparation of a comprehensive National Social Protection Framework which provides a road-map for a coordinated nutrition-sensitive and schock-responsive social protection system. A division of labour and respsonsibility for different stakeholders was developed as well as a proposal of how to integrate nutrition into social protection programming. The RSR financed acitivites also contributed to development of a single registry of beneficiaires to improve the efficiency of social protection. In addition, a social intermediation strategy was developed with a focus on supporting beneficiaries to "graduate" from social assistance to labour market programs. In Sierra Leone the RSR financed activities that increased the effectiveness of the social protection program. Technical assistance during the Ebola recovery period and during floods and landslide emergencies supported development of the social safety net system and expansion of standardised cash transfers in the country. The grant also facilitated national dialogue about social protection issues for the revision of the social protection policy. The revised social protection poliy was later approved by the Cabinet. The RSR also supports policy development, for example in 2019 publishing the book "Exploring Universal Basic Income - A Guide to Navigating Concepts, Evidence and Practices". The book has supported learning and discussion on key issues in social protection relating to targeting or universal approaches and on how the term "universal" can be interpreted.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
