title.narrative: Contribution agreement between Sida and FAO, Support to Forest and Farm Facility
Beslut om insats, Forest and Farm Faclity

description.narrative: Within the overall impact goal of achieving climate resilient landscapes and improved livelihoods the following results have been accomplished within the four outcome areas: Outcome area 1 – enabling policy and legal frameworks: A total of 13 changes in policy/legal documents, processes or decisions that work in favour of the interest of FFPOs have been achieved on national and international level. Country level examples include Nepal, where active advocacy supported by FFF provided input into the formation and improvement in Forest Act and in Zambia, FFF continues to provide inputs into the countries new Charcoal Regulations (NAT/INST). There are also several challenges in the work under this outcome. FFPO capacity is often low (internal governance, financial and administrative capacity), and there is a general prevalence of low gender equality. The coordination both sectoral and stakeholder wise is also inefficient. Frequent changes in institutions and high turnover of authorities at the ministry level means slow policy processes and at times conflicting sectoral policies. Outcome area 2: Increased entrepreneurship, access to markets and finance. Country level examples include; improved access to finance and markets in Nepal, with 221 community forestry producer groups linked to government enterprise funding. Furthermore, a tree inventory improved fair market prices in Kenya through the launch of a timber tree census in Nyandarua, whereby 3 000 farmer members were supported to undertake tree inventory of on-farm trees as a mean of improving market information for buyers and thereby their capacity to negotiate a fair market price. Initial results of the census show an average of 1.6 million trees per ha representing USD 17 million in potential income. Outcome 3: Improved delivery of landscape-scale mitigation, adaptation and climate resilience; examples include in Bolivia where FFPOs have been able to leverage access to USD 21.7 million in government funding for ecological cocoa agroforestry systems. FFF together with IUCN organized the Tecpan Learning Exchange that hosted 42 participants and explored barriers and urgent policy issues relevant to indigenous peoples. It included opportunities to influence the CBD, UNFCCC, SDGs and other relevant global policies. Important topics related to conserved and protected areas, and how they relate to indigenous rights to land, territories and resources were covered (GLOB/NORM). Outcome 4: :Improved and equitable access to social and cultural services. For example, the Federation of Community Producers Organization of Nepal organized a national 16- day campaign against gender-based violence.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Swedish Strategy for global development cooperation on sustainable economic development 2018 – 2022
strategy.titleSV: Sveriges globala utvecklingssamarbete inom hållbar ekonomisk utveckling 2018-2022

Outcome area 2: Increased entrepreneurship, access to markets and finance. Country level examples include; improved access to finance and markets in Nepal, with 221 community forestry producer groups linked to government enterprise funding. Furthermore, a tree inventory improved fair market prices in Kenya through the launch of a timber tree census in Nyandarua, whereby 3 000 farmer members were supported to undertake tree inventory of on-farm trees as a mean of improving market information for buyers and thereby their capacity to negotiate a fair market price. Initial results of the census show an average of 1.6 million trees per ha representing USD 17 million in potential income. Outcome 3: Improved delivery of landscape-scale mitigation, adaptation and climate resilience; examples include in Bolivia where FFPOs have been able to leverage access to USD 21.7 million in government funding for ecological cocoa agroforestry systems. FFF together with IUCN organized the Tecpan Learning Exchange that hosted 42 participants and explored barriers and urgent policy issues relevant to indigenous peoples. It included opportunities to influence the CBD, UNFCCC, SDGs and other relevant global policies. Important topics related to conserved and protected areas, and how they relate to indigenous rights to land, territories and resources were covered (GLOB/NORM). Outcome 4: :Improved and equitable access to social and cultural services. For example, the Federation of Community Producers Organization of Nepal organized a national 16- day campaign against gender-based violence.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Sustainable environment, climate, oceans and use of natural resources 2018-2022
strategy.titleSV: Hållbar miljö, hållbart klimat och hav samt hållbart nyttj. av naturresurser 2018-2022

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI) är en global tankesmedja och koalition av 15 internationella organisationer och med ett brett nätverk av samarbetspartners. Verksamheten är en kombination av forskning, analys och faktabaserad opinionsbildning. RRI sammanför och katalyserar samarbete mellan en mångfald av aktörer, så som företrädare för offentliga myndigheter, företag, investerare, internationellt och nationellt civilsamhälle, forskningsorgan, bondeorganisationer, ursprungsbefolkningar och lokalsamhällen. Det ger också mindre projektbidrag till partners och initiativ som är verksamma på nationell och lokal nivå i ett antal utvalda länder. Sekretariatet ligger i Washington DC, USA.
Sida har mottagit en ansökan om stöd till ett program med titeln "Från risk och konflikt till fred och välstånd: Säkra mark- och skogsrättigheter för ursprungsfolk, lokalsamhällen och kvinnor, för att hantera klimatförändringar och främja hållbar utveckling, trygghet och välbefinnande för alla", vilket utgör RRI’s strategiska program för perioden 2018-2022.
Programmets övergripande mål är att "dramatiskt öka erkännandet av ursprungsfolks, lokalsamhällens och kvinnors mark- och (natur)resursrättigheter i utvecklingsländer och förbättra deras möjligheter till försörjning".
De förväntade resultaten av programmet kan sammanfattas enligt följande: 1. Ursprungsfolk, lokalsamhällen och kvinnor har säkrare rättigheter till mark och andra naturresurser 2. Regeringar/stater stöder detta och verkar för juridiskt erkännande och tillämpning av lag 3. Företag och investerare antar standarder och rättighetsbaserade förhållningssätt som erkänner lokala ägande- och nyttjanderättigheter
Ansökan gäller SEK 20 000 000 per år under fem år, totalt SEK 100 000 000 under perioden 2018-2022. På grund av kommande skifte till nya globala strategier för ekonomiskt hållbar utveckling samt för miljö och klimat, fattar Sida enbart beslut om bidrag för perioden 2018-2021.
Det föreslagna beloppet på 20 miljoner kronor per år 2018-2021 utgör ca 20% av den beräknade totala budgeten för samma period. Under första året, 2018, beräknas stödet från Sida utgöra 25-30% av de troliga intäkterna under detta år. I absoluta tal innebär stödet nästan en dubblering av den finansiering som Sida avtalade för 2013-2017, vilket ursprungligen var SEK 50 miljoner (minskades 2016 till SEK 44 miljoner på grund av dåvarande flyktingmottagandet i Sverige). Det här innebär också att Sida kommer att stå för en större andel av budgeten än tidigare. Sidas andel bedöms dock fortfarande vara på en rimlig nivå.
Det ökade stödet motiveras av det föreslagna programmets relevans och positiva erfarenheter från tidigare samarbete. Det bedöms troligt att RRI kommer att kunna genomföra förslaget kostnadseffektivt och med goda resultat. RRI bedöms även ha kapacitet att, om utrymme ges, öka volymen som vidareförmedlas till partners på lokal nivå.
Sida har förmedlat organisationsstöd till RRI sedan 2008 och har positiva erfarenheter av samarbetet. RRI har visat goda resultat och förmåga att anpassa verksamheten till förändringar i omvärlden. Man har kontinuerligt utvecklat nya metoder och initiativ, involverat nya aktörer och hittat nya möjligheter att påverka och främja markrättigheter, särskilt för de mest sårbara och utsatta på landsbygden. Organisationen har en tydlig betoning på lokalt ägarskap och rättighetsperspektiv.
På grund av förändrad biståndspolitik har några av de tidigare givarna till RRI avsevärt minskat eller avslutat bidragen till RRI. Detta var fallet med Schweiz och Finland. Storbritannien kommer sannolikt att fortsätta, men minska volymen. Fortsatt stöd förväntas även från Ford Foundation, WellSpring och Norge. Sida bedömer att ett långsiktigt åtagande om kärnstöd i ett tidigt skede av strategiperioden kommer att ge bättre förutsättningar för organisationens långsiktiga planering och rekrytering av personal. Det kan också underlätta projektfinansiering från andra källor.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI) is a global think-tank and coalition with a wide network of collaborators that works through a combination of research, analysis and evidence-based advocacy. RRI engages with, and convenes, a diversity of actors, including representatives of public agencies, companies, investors, international and national civil society, academia, farmer organisations, indigenous peoples and communities. It also provides small grants to partners and initiatives that operates at national and local level in the countries where RRI has collaboration.
Sida has received a request for support to: "From risk and conflict to peace and prosperity: Securing indigenous peoples', communities and women's land and forest rights to confront climate change and advance sustainable development, security and wellbeing for all", which is the strategic programme of RRI during 2018-2022. The request amounts to SEK 20 000 000 per year for five years, for a total of SEK 100 000 000 over the period 2018-2022.
The overall objective of the programme is to "dramatically scale-up the recognition of the land and resource rights of indigenous peoples, local communities and women across the developing world and improve their livelihoods."
The expected outcomes of the programme can be summarised as follows: 1. Indigenous peoples, local communities and women are empowered and have more secure tenure rights to land and other natural resources 2. Governments support this and scale-up legal recognition and enforcement 3. Companies and investors adopt standards and rights-based approaches recognizing local tenure rights
The amount of SEK 20 million per year 2018-2021 from Sida would constitute 20 % of the aspired total budget for the period. It implies a 70-100 % increase of the funding agreed to by Sida for 2013-2017, which initially was SEK 50 million (in 2016 reduced to SEK 44 million due to the refugee crisis in Sweden). The proposed contribution constitutes a larger share of the total than before, but considered to still be at an acceptable level.
Sida has provided core-support to RRI since 2008, when the coalition was newly established. The increased support by Sida is motivated by the relevance of the programme proposed, and by positive experiences from previous cooperation. It is assessed likely that RRI will be able to implement the proposal in an effective and cost-efficient way. It is also assessed that RRI would have capacity, if funding alloes, to expand the provision of small grants in direct support of partners at country and local level.
Due to a changing political context, some of the previous donors to RRI have significantly reduced or ended financing to RRI. UK is likely to continue but reduce the grant. Continued commitment is also likely from Ford Foundation, WellSpring and Norway. A long-term commitment from Sida at an early stage will provide better conditions for long-term planning and recruitment of senior professionals by RRI. It may also help to attract project funding from other sources.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

13.b - Främja mekanismer för att höja förmågan till effektiv klimatrelaterad planering och förvaltning i de minst utvecklade länderna, med särskilt fokus på kvinnor, ungdomar samt lokala och marginaliserade samhällen.

13.b - Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries and small island developing States, including focusing on women, youth and local and marginalized communities.

15.2 - By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally.

15.2 - Till 2020 främja genomförandet av hållbart brukande av alla typer av skogar, stoppa avskogningen, återställa utarmade skogar och kraftigt öka nybeskogningen och återbeskogningen i hela världen.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation

title.narrative: 17/000153 Amendment 1 to the Grant Agreement between Sida and the Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI) 2018-2021
17/000153 Grant Agreement between Sida and the Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI) 2018-2021
17/000153 Beslut om insats, Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI) 2018-2021
17/000153 Beslut om ändring av insats, Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI) 2018-2021

description.narrative: Some of the major results during 2019 which RRI reported in its programme book for 2020 (in time for the annual governce meeting) include on a global level: - RRIs contribution towards recognizing indigenous and community land rights as a priority in the biodiversity and climate change crisis. With reference to the IPCC report and the 2019 IPBES Global Report Assessment highlighted the positive contributions of indigenous and community land rights to conservation and biodiversity as well as the necessity to recognize and strengthen their rights and roles in conservation. RRI have contributed to the issue being raised with key stakeholders and donors. (GLOB NORM/DIAL) On a national level: - The RRI Coalition and Indigenous Peoples and local communities made significant progress securing over 6.5 million hectares of land and forest with support from the Tenure Facility in just two years in RRI priority countries of Colombia, Peru, Indonesia and India. A result that will probably also figure in Tenure Facility’s annual reporting. - In India, legal and political advocacy work contributed to a stay in a Supreme Court case that would have evicted 10 million forest dwellers. RRI supported legal advocacy work for civil society/government affidavits for theSupreme Court Case, and mobilized media and advocacy support to combat the ruling; the order was stayed, andhearings are ongoing. - RRI media and advocacy support also contributed to the withdrawal of proposed amendments to India’s Forest Rights Act that threatened community and indigenous land rights.(NAT/INST) - Through the Interlaken Group (IG), RRI has been serving as the secretariat and ensuring participation and dialogue within the Interlaken Group. RRI engaged globally and at the national level in Peru, Liberia, DRC, Malawi, Kenya, Laos, India, and Indonesia to leverage the influence of the private sector to support secure community land tenure. Although no evaluation or audit specific to the Interlaken Group has been conducted yet progress progress has been assessed within annual evaluations of RRI by independent monitors. In Malawi, a new Platform on Responsible Land Based Investment emerged from an Interlaken Group workshop held in July 2018 and the IG has continued to engage in Kenya, Liberia, Myanmar, Laos, and Indonesia. Internationally, the IG has engaged with new companies, investors, and platforms, including the Chinese Chamber of Commerce of Metals, Minerals, and Chemicals and Proforest. 47 private sector actors are testing new approaches to managing tenure issues and changing standards and practice as a result of using the Land Scope tool and a further 10 are changing their management of tenure in response to Interlaken Group processes. (GLOB/DIAL)
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.
12.2 - By 2030, achieve the sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources.
12.2 - Senast 2030 uppnå en hållbar förvaltning och ett effektivt nyttjande av naturresurser.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

RRI bedöms även ha kapacitet att, om utrymme ges, öka volymen som vidareförmedlas till partners på lokal nivå.
Sida har förmedlat organisationsstöd till RRI sedan 2008 och har positiva erfarenheter av samarbetet. RRI har visat goda resultat och förmåga att anpassa verksamheten till förändringar i omvärlden. Man har kontinuerligt utvecklat nya metoder och initiativ, involverat nya aktörer och hittat nya möjligheter att påverka och främja markrättigheter, särskilt för de mest sårbara och utsatta på landsbygden. Organisationen har en tydlig betoning på lokalt ägarskap och rättighetsperspektiv.
På grund av förändrad biståndspolitik har några av de tidigare givarna till RRI avsevärt minskat eller avslutat bidragen till RRI. Detta var fallet med Schweiz och Finland. Storbritannien kommer sannolikt att fortsätta, men minska volymen. Fortsatt stöd förväntas även från Ford Foundation, WellSpring och Norge. Sida bedömer att ett långsiktigt åtagande om kärnstöd i ett tidigt skede av strategiperioden kommer att ge bättre förutsättningar för organisationens långsiktiga planering och rekrytering av personal. Det kan också underlätta projektfinansiering från andra källor.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI) is a global think-tank and coalition with a wide network of collaborators that works through a combination of research, analysis and evidence-based advocacy. RRI engages with, and convenes, a diversity of actors, including representatives of public agencies, companies, investors, international and national civil society, academia, farmer organisations, indigenous peoples and communities. It also provides small grants to partners and initiatives that operates at national and local level in the countries where RRI has collaboration.
Sida has received a request for support to: "From risk and conflict to peace and prosperity: Securing indigenous peoples', communities and women's land and forest rights to confront climate change and advance sustainable development, security and wellbeing for all", which is the strategic programme of RRI during 2018-2022. The request amounts to SEK 20 000 000 per year for five years, for a total of SEK 100 000 000 over the period 2018-2022.
The overall objective of the programme is to "dramatically scale-up the recognition of the land and resource rights of indigenous peoples, local communities and women across the developing world and improve their livelihoods."
The expected outcomes of the programme can be summarised as follows: 1. Indigenous peoples, local communities and women are empowered and have more secure tenure rights to land and other natural resources 2. Governments support this and scale-up legal recognition and enforcement 3. Companies and investors adopt standards and rights-based approaches recognizing local tenure rights
The amount of SEK 20 million per year 2018-2021 from Sida would constitute 20 % of the aspired total budget for the period. It implies a 70-100 % increase of the funding agreed to by Sida for 2013-2017, which initially was SEK 50 million (in 2016 reduced to SEK 44 million due to the refugee crisis in Sweden). The proposed contribution constitutes a larger share of the total than before, but considered to still be at an acceptable level.
Sida has provided core-support to RRI since 2008, when the coalition was newly established. The increased support by Sida is motivated by the relevance of the programme proposed, and by positive experiences from previous cooperation. It is assessed likely that RRI will be able to implement the proposal in an effective and cost-efficient way. It is also assessed that RRI would have capacity, if funding alloes, to expand the provision of small grants in direct support of partners at country and local level.
Due to a changing political context, some of the previous donors to RRI have significantly reduced or ended financing to RRI. UK is likely to continue but reduce the grant. Continued commitment is also likely from Ford Foundation, WellSpring and Norway. A long-term commitment from Sida at an early stage will provide better conditions for long-term planning and recruitment of senior professionals by RRI. It may also help to attract project funding from other sources.

tag.narrative: 10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.

16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.

17/000153 Grant Agreement between Sida and the Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI) 2018-2021
17/000153 Beslut om insats, Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI) 2018-2021
17/000153 Beslut om ändring av insats, Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI) 2018-2021

description.narrative: Some of the major results during 2019 which RRI reported in its programme book for 2020 (in time for the annual governce meeting) include on a global level: - RRIs contribution towards recognizing indigenous and community land rights as a priority in the biodiversity and climate change crisis. With reference to the IPCC report and the 2019 IPBES Global Report Assessment highlighted the positive contributions of indigenous and community land rights to conservation and biodiversity as well as the necessity to recognize and strengthen their rights and roles in conservation. RRI have contributed to the issue being raised with key stakeholders and donors. (GLOB NORM/DIAL) On a national level: - The RRI Coalition and Indigenous Peoples and local communities made significant progress securing over 6.5 million hectares of land and forest with support from the Tenure Facility in just two years in RRI priority countries of Colombia, Peru, Indonesia and India. A result that will probably also figure in Tenure Facility’s annual reporting. - In India, legal and political advocacy work contributed to a stay in a Supreme Court case that would have evicted 10 million forest dwellers. RRI supported legal advocacy work for civil society/government affidavits for theSupreme Court Case, and mobilized media and advocacy support to combat the ruling; the order was stayed, andhearings are ongoing. - RRI media and advocacy support also contributed to the withdrawal of proposed amendments to India’s Forest Rights Act that threatened community and indigenous land rights.(NAT/INST) - Through the Interlaken Group (IG), RRI has been serving as the secretariat and ensuring participation and dialogue within the Interlaken Group. RRI engaged globally and at the national level in Peru, Liberia, DRC, Malawi, Kenya, Laos, India, and Indonesia to leverage the influence of the private sector to support secure community land tenure. Although no evaluation or audit specific to the Interlaken Group has been conducted yet progress progress has been assessed within annual evaluations of RRI by independent monitors. In Malawi, a new Platform on Responsible Land Based Investment emerged from an Interlaken Group workshop held in July 2018 and the IG has continued to engage in Kenya, Liberia, Myanmar, Laos, and Indonesia. Internationally, the IG has engaged with new companies, investors, and platforms, including the Chinese Chamber of Commerce of Metals, Minerals, and Chemicals and Proforest. 47 private sector actors are testing new approaches to managing tenure issues and changing standards and practice as a result of using the Land Scope tool and a further 10 are changing their management of tenure in response to Interlaken Group processes. (GLOB/DIAL)
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Human rights, democracy and the rule of law 2018-2022
strategy.titleSV: Mänskliga rättigheter, demokrati och rättsstatens principer 2018-2022

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Det föreslagna stödet är ett kärnstöd om 190 miljoner SEK 2018-2022 till The Tenure Facility (TF). TF är en internationell organisation med säte i Sverige som verkar för att säkra kollektiva mark och skogsrättigheter för urfolk och lokalsamhällen med syfte att öka deras egenmakt, att kunna skydda sin mark. Detta väntas få som effekt, enligt organisationens Theory of Change, att möjligheterna till livsmedelstrygghet, ekonomisk utveckling, och hållbart nyttjande av naturresurser främjas, samt att konfliktnivån minskar.
Kollektiva markrättigheter har de senaste årtiondena fått ökat erkännande och anpassat lagligt ramverk i många länder. Dessvärre översätts dessa sällan fullt ut i administrativa åtgärder som leder till lagfarter och en tryggare situation. The Tenure Facility skapades för att praktiskt stötta implementeringen av dessa lagar i konkreta projekt. Därigenom byggs kunskap och erfarenhet som the Tenure Facility delar internationellt.
Samarbetsparten är lokalsamhället som eftersträvar kollektiva rättigheter till sin traditionella mark, ofta urfolk. Avtal ingås antingen direkt eller via en administrativ samarbetspart beroende på kapacitet. Ansvarig statlig enhet ska alltid vara involverad i projektformulering och genomförande, eftersom ett mål med projekten också är att staten ska applicera resultatet på nationell nivå. 80% av projekten kommer implementeras i tropiska skogsområden, 20% i övriga landskap, samtliga i utvecklingsländer med fokus på marginaliserade grupper.
Initiativet att bilda the Tenure Facility kom från Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI), en global koalition av NGOs som arbetar för kollektiva markrättigheter. RRI får kärnstöd från Sida sen 2013. Sida gav stöd till Rights and Resources Initiative för konsultation och formulering av TF-konceptet 2012-2013, och för en pilotfas 2014-2017 där konceptet testades i sex länder med ett Sidastöd på 130 miljoner SEK. Utvärderingen som utfördes 2017 av de sex pilotprojekten (Universalia, 2017) var positiv gällande relevans, resultatuppfyllelse och kostnadseffektivitet. Rekommendationerna från utvärderingen var huvudsakligen riktade till och integrerades i den vidare institutionella utvecklingen.
I andra halvan av pilotfasen påbörjades etableringen av organisationen the Tenure Facility med målet att nästa fas skulle genomföras av en fristående institution. Denna process har letts av RRI och följts noggrant av givargruppen, bestående av Sida, Norway's International Climate and Forest Initiative (NICFI, på norska miljödepartementet)/Norad och Ford Foundation. RRI och givarna har följt upp med flera utvärderingar och revisioner. Utifrån dessa har utvecklingsplaner med milstolpar tagits fram för att säkra en transparent och balanserad process. "Internationella Insamlingsstiftelsen för Mark och Skogsrättigheter" - Tenure Facility's juridiska namn - stiftades i januari 2017. Sedan början av 2018 har etableringen letts av the Tenure Facility från sekretariatet Stockholm.
Tenure Facility styrs av en styrelse med upp till 11 medlemmar, varav 4 ingår i den grupp som väljer projekt. Sammansättningen är noga avvägd, med finansiell expertis, såväl som representanter med erfarenhet från stat, civilsamhälle, ursprungsfolk och privata sektorn. Det finns också en rådgivargrupp, där civilsamhälle, ursprungsbefolkningsgrupper och olika internationella organ, så som IFC och FAO, finns representerade. Givarna har separata möten samt har möjlighet att delta i rådgivargruppens möten med styrelsen, men deltar inte i styrelsens beslut eller i urvalet av projekt.
TF är en organisation som skapar kunskap genom att finansiera och lära ifrån implementeringen av projekt. Minst två tredjedelar av budgeten kommer därför gå till projekt. Deras storlek varierar mellan 200 000USD och 2 000 000USD och är upp till tre år långa. TF ingår avtal för varje projekt efter att avtalspartens kapacitet bedömts enligt etablerade kriteria.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The proposed intervention is a core support of SEK 190 million 2018-2022 to The Tenure Facility (TF), of which SEK 130 million from the Strategy for Globally Sustainable Economic Development, and SEK 60 million from Strategy for Sustainable Environment, Climate, Oceans and Use of Natural Resources. The contribution is also highly relevant to the Strategy for Human Rights, Democratization and Rule of Law. Close cooperation and coordination is foreseen on the issue of tenure between the three strategies including in the follow up of this intervention.
In addition, the European Commission plans to channel EUR 7 million via Sida in a delegated cooperation agreement for core support. This support is planned for 2019-2021. Therefore the full assessment is written in English.
The TF aims to secure land and forest rights for Indigenous peoples and local communities in the developing world by providing project support to the communities, civil society, and to some extent to governments. Government support and involvement is always required for a project to be accepted.
Sida supported Rights and Resources Initiative’s (RRI) establishment of the TF since its beginnings in 2012-2013 for the development of the initial proposal and program documents. The pilot phase of TF was also managed by RRI, in 2014-2018, with a Sida support of 130 MSEK. In addition, Sida supports RRI with core support, 9 MSEK on average 2013-2017 and 25 MSEK per year 2018-2021.
This proposed intervention will be the first considerable direct support to this new organization. It has approximately the same annual amount as the previous phase, that was channeled through RRI. Thus far, it has received direct funding from the Ford Foundation, 3 MUSD in 2017 and 2018.
Access to land and natural resources for rural poor is often based on customary tenure, which tends to be insecure due to a lack of political, legal and administrative recognition, and contradictions between the formal and informal systems. This leads to a situation of insecurity for these local communities that affects most aspects of life, such as access to and/or security of livelyhoods, including food, water, housing and source of income, political rights to participate in processes that concern the land you live on and the land you have used for generations, the social rights and traditions that relate to the community; how you take decisions, plan your production, etcetera. For the wider society, insecurity of tenure also has negative aspects, since it can limit economic development, spark conflict and lead to deforestation and unsustainable land use – a climate change driver and a cause of flooding, mudslides and loss of ecosystem services.
Collective tenure is often not considered in the legal systems, and insecure collective tenure often concerns forest. Therefore, both RRI and the TF have a focus on forest lands, although grazelands and agricultural lands also can be considered for support.
Fortunately, the global advocacy over the last decades - by RRI and others - for the political and legal recognition of communal land rights for indigenous peoples (IPs) and local communities have resulted in considerable advances and adapted legal frameworks in many countries. However, all this leeway did not give secure tenure on the ground, since there is a void in implementation and in administrative recognition.
The lack of implementation should not automatically be interpreted as a lack of political will or of resources – but often a lack of capacity, information and experience. It is a new field of work for government administration as well as for NGOs and communities. RRI concluded that a special focus on the practical aspects of implementation was needed. The TF offers the following kinds of support (quoted from web page https://thetenurefacility.org/what-we-do/ on 181122)
Scale up implementation of land and forest tenure reform policies and legislation by:– Providing support to establish legitimate tenure rights in areas where traditional communal rights are not formally recognized– Providing support for community mapping, demarcation, and registration efforts– Strengthening the capacity of national organizations to provide land tenure related services to reach disadvantaged and vulnerable groups
Enable governments and communities to test new models, strategies and approaches by:– Testing practical solutions to implementation challenges– Assisting governments and communities to overcome administrative obstacles to land rights recognition and titling– Building capacity of government agencies responsible for titling and protecting indigenous and community rights
About the Tenure Facility organization:
The TF has its headquarters in Stockholm, established in 2017. RRI decided to place the headquarters in Stockholm following their independent analysis. It is registered as a non-profit foundation, insamlingsstiftelse, and subject for control by the Stockholm Province Authority (Länsstyrelsen) in accordance with the Foundation Law, SFS 1994:1220.

participating-org.narrative: Internationella Insamlingsstiftelsen för Mark och Skogsrättigheter

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.

10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.
15.6 - Främja en rimlig och rättvis fördelning av den nytta som uppstår vid användning av genetiska resurser samt lämpligt tillträde till sådana resurser, i enlighet med internationella avtal.
15.6 - Promote fair and equitable sharing of the benefits arising from the utilization of genetic resources and promote appropriate access to such resources, as internationally agreed.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

title.narrative: 18/000592 Grant Agreement between Sida and the Tenure Facility
18/000592 Beslut om insats The Tenure Facility 2018-2022

description.narrative: The baseline has been built retrospectively progress made during 2019, will be included in the annual report to be submitted in May 2020. The baseline findings and report as well as the executive directors report containing progress of the Tenure Facility maturing as an organisation, were all presented during the learning exchange in Bogota/Colombia during October 2019. Some of the results included: - Base-line established with data from project partners Sept 2019 - Increased Funding 2018-2020 from donors, USD 13,6 million in 2019 and secured USD 13,6 million for 2020 - Consolidated Secretariat, from 4 fulltime staff to now 13 - Stronger partnerships with government in Liberia, Peru, Indonesia Colombia, Guyana, Mozambique, Mali The monitoring framework, the TF results framework with indicators and targets as well as the risk register, are still not final and Norad are coordinating the donor response. The was all discussed during the last meeting with Tenure Facility, Norad and Sida in March 2020 (minutes in Dox).The monitoring framework is set to be approved by donors by June 2020. Sidas input mainly concentrated on environment and livelihoods integration (see meeting minutes). According to TF, tenure is their niche and their support to livelihood efforts is through their partners strategies and efforts. The first offical results from the contribution are expected to be included in the annual report from 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

13.b - Främja mekanismer för att höja förmågan till effektiv klimatrelaterad planering och förvaltning i de minst utvecklade länderna, med särskilt fokus på kvinnor, ungdomar samt lokala och marginaliserade samhällen.

13.b - Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries and small island developing States, including focusing on women, youth and local and marginalized communities.

15.2 - By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally.

15.2 - Till 2020 främja genomförandet av hållbart brukande av alla typer av skogar, stoppa avskogningen, återställa utarmade skogar och kraftigt öka nybeskogningen och återbeskogningen i hela världen.

title.narrative: 18/000592 Grant Agreement between Sida and the Tenure Facility
18/000592 Beslut om insats The Tenure Facility 2018-2022

description.narrative: The baseline has been built retrospectively progress made during 2019, will be included in the annual report to be submitted in May 2020. The baseline findings and report as well as the executive directors report containing progress of the Tenure Facility maturing as an organisation, were all presented during the learning exchange in Bogota/Colombia during October 2019. Some of the results included: - Base-line established with data from project partners Sept 2019 - Increased Funding 2018-2020 from donors, USD 13,6 million in 2019 and secured USD 13,6 million for 2020 - Consolidated Secretariat, from 4 fulltime staff to now 13 - Stronger partnerships with government in Liberia, Peru, Indonesia Colombia, Guyana, Mozambique, Mali The monitoring framework, the TF results framework with indicators and targets as well as the risk register, are still not final and Norad are coordinating the donor response. The was all discussed during the last meeting with Tenure Facility, Norad and Sida in March 2020 (minutes in Dox).The monitoring framework is set to be approved by donors by June 2020. Sidas input mainly concentrated on environment and livelihoods integration (see meeting minutes). According to TF, tenure is their niche and their support to livelihood efforts is through their partners strategies and efforts. The first offical results from the contribution are expected to be included in the annual report from 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative:
ILO's programme and budget for the biennium 2018 - 2019 includes ten policy outcomes that reflect the priorities of the organisation, aimed at the promotion of social justice through the Decent Work Agenda and its strategic objectives of employment, social protection, social dialogue and tripartism, and fundamental principles and rights at work. Sida's support will focus on the two following policy outcomes:
Policy Outcome 1 - More and better jobs for inclusive growth and improved youth employment prospects: Member states implement policies and programmes that promote more and better jobs and enhance youth employment prospects with a view to inclusive growth and development.
Policy Outcome 8 - Protecting workers from unacceptable forms of work: Member states develop or enhance laws and policies, strenghten institutions, and foster partnerships to protect women and men from unacceptable forms of work.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Sammanfattande bakgrund till stödet ILO är FN:s fackliga organ för frågor med koppling till produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor, och en ledande normativ och standardsättande aktör. ILO:s "Decent work"-agenda - med inriktning på arbetsrätt, social dialog, sysselsättning och sociala skyddsnät - utgör ett ramverk för att bidra till fattigdomsminskning och mänskliga rättigheter på global, regional och nationell nivå. Samarbete mellan regeringar, arbetsgivar- och arbetstagarorganisationer - den s.k. "trepartsstrukturen" - är en central del av ILO:s uppbyggnad och sätt att arbeta. ILO:s verksamhet är relevant inom de flesta områden som rör utveckling och fattigdomsbekämpning, såsom; mänskliga rättigheter (inklusive barns rättigheter), konfliktförebyggande, ekonomisk hållbar utveckling, migration etc. Detta är kopplat till det faktum att sysselsättning är en multisektoriell, övergripande ämnesfråga som relaterar till alla delar av samhället och människors liv.
Sida har arbetat med ILO som partner sedan 70-talet, och på global nivå sedan ett tiotal år tillbaka. Erfarenheterna från tidigare samarbete är generellt goda. Förutom att arbeta genom sina konventioner och rekommendationer, med tillhörande standarder, är ILO ledande inom policy- och metodutveckling, datainsamling/analys samt kapacitetsbyggande inom sysselsättningsområdet. ILO är även en operativ organisation med kontor i 42 länder runtom i världen. ILO:s kapacitet på landnivå är skiftande, mycket på grund av att en stor andel av personalen i fält finansieras genom projekt. Kapaciteten och kunskapen hos personalen på de fast bemannade kontoren bedöms dock vara hög, och ILO har ofta ett starkt mandat på landnivå genom sin trepartsstruktur. Det trepartiska arbetssättet gör att ILO å ena sidan kan uppfattas som tungrott, å andra sidan som en organisation som arbetar långsiktigt mot hållbar utveckling.
Sverige, genom Sida, är den sjunde största bilaterala givaren till ILO. Sida stödjer ILO:s utvecklingssamarbete på bilateral, regional och global nivå. Utöver detta ansvarar Arbetsmarknadsdepartementet för Sveriges medlemsavgift till ILO, vilken uppgår till ca 31,5 MSEK per år. Utrikesdepartementet (UD) har kanaliserat ett mindre stöd till ILO under 2017, genom dess Global Deal-sekretariat.
Trots att Sverige och Sida inte är en av ILO:s största givare finns relativt goda möjligheter till påverkan. Dels kan Sida påverka genom givargruppen. Dels kan Arbetsmarknadsdepartementet och UD påverka genom ILO:s styrande organ Governing Body (GB) och International Labour Conference (ILC). De svenska parterna - arbetsgivar- och arbetstagarorganisationerna - kan också driva svenska prioriterade frågor genom sina kanaler.
Stödets inriktning Föreslaget stöd gäller globalt programstöd till ILO för åren 2018-2020 i form av lätt öronmärkt, tematiskt stöd (s.k. "Outcome"-stöd, i enlighet med ILO:s tvååriga planering ) samt oöronmärkt stöd till ILO:s DAC-fäiga arbete till "Regular Budget Supplementary Account" (RBSA) fördelat enligt följande:
- Tematiskt stöd/Outcome-stöd, totalt: 83 MSEK Outcome 1 (Fler och bättre jobb för människor i fattigdom, inklusive för ungdomar): 30 MSEK Outcome 8 (Oacceptabla arbetsförhållanden): 21 MSEK Genderintegrering: 10,5 MSEK Miljö- och klimatintegrering: 10,5 MSEK Integrering av social dialog och "Global Deal": 11 MSEK
- Oöronmärkt stöd till RBSA: 55 MSEK
Storleken på stödet är i linje med tidigare avtalsperiod (2014-2017) och inriktningen i stort densamma. De huvudsakliga skillnaderna utgörs av: - större andel oöronmärkt stöd - nytt stöd till social dialog som tvärfråga - inget projektstöd.
Stödet till ILO:s integrerings/tvärfrågor bygger på organisationens egna markörer för tvärfrågor.
Inriktningen på stödet ligger väl i linje med ILO:s egna prioriteringar samt svenska prioriterade frågor inom utvecklingssamarbetet i allmänhet, och inom området hållbar ekonomisk utveckling i synnerhet.
Sida bedömer att nivån på stödet är i linje med ILO:s absorptionskapacitet. Möjlighet finns dock att öka stödet till vissa delar, såsom den flexibla RBSA-mekanismen.
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 ILO Partnership Programme 4, 2018-2020

tag.narrative: 8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.
8.6 - By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
8.6 - Till 2020 väsentligt minska den andel ungdomar som varken arbetar eller studerar.
8.8 - Protect labour rights and promote safe and secure working environments for all workers, including migrant workers, in particular women migrants, and those in precarious employment.

8.8 - Skydda arbetstagarnas rättigheter och främja en trygg och säker arbetsmiljö för alla arbetstagare, inklusive arbetskraftsinvandrare, i synnerhet kvinnliga migranter, och människor i otrygga anställningar.
8.b - By 2020, develop and operationalize a global strategy for youth employment and implement the Global Jobs Pact of the International Labour Organization.
8.b - Senast 2020 utarbeta och börja tillämpa en global strategi för ungdomssysselsättning samt genomföra Internationella arbetsorganisationens globala sysselsättningspakt.

title.narrative: Avtal mellan International Labour Organization (ILO) och Sida

description.narrative: ILO’s overarching results framework, in which the above mentioned areas are included, has baselines, targets and indicators expressed in the overarching Programme and Budget (P&B). Progress and achievements related to these indicators are reviewed and reported through the ILO “Programme Implementation Report” (PIR) at the end of each biennium. The Sida-ILO Partnership Programme report for the biennium 2018-2019 includes references to the PIR for 2018-2019, which illustrate how Sida’s support contributed to ILOs overall results framework and overall objectives, rather than being treated as stand-alone interventions. During 2020, clustered evaluations were also conducted of the Sida supported work. Example of results: Sida funds are supporting development of global products and processes, as well as country level interventions with the aim to strengthen the ILO'S development cooperation in achieving the overall objective of the ILO. [GLOB/NORM, NAT/INST] The Partnership has supported sharpening of diagnostics, analysis, and guidance to support policy development on employment, youth employment and skills development. These are used to both influence the global policy debate on employment, as well as strengthen the ILO’s advisory tools and services at national level. For example, this work contributed to the development of a labour market diagnostics tools focused on changing labour markets and how to review and design relevant employment strategies at national level. The tool has supported the development of employment policies in El Salvador, Ethiopia and Kenya. The tool was further developed as a part of the ILO’s COVID-19 response and was used in 16 country analysis with focus on the pandemics effects on the economy and labour market, with the aim of supporting the constituents in developing national employment policies to address challenges for vulnerable workers in sectors hit especially hard. [GLOB/NORM, NAT/INST] The Partnership also supported the development and expansion of knowledge products for social dialogue and industrial relations, such as the ILO Global Legal Database on Industrial Relations (IRLex) and a training toolkit on industrial relations (IR Toolkit). The IRLex is a source for comparative information on legal and institutional frameworks regulating industrial relations used for advice in the context of labour law reforms to government officials, social partners, industrial relations and legal practitioners as well as researchers in labour law and industrial relations, and the IR Toolkit aims at improving industrial relations and strengthening decent work and sustainable development in global supply chains. The IR Toolkit has been pilot tested at country level as part of ongoing programmes, including in the Sida funded programmes in Myanmar and Ethiopia, which provided valuable feedback to inform further development of the tool. [GLOB/NORM, NAT/INST] The support contributed to revision and development of laws and policies to protect women and men workers from unacceptable forms of work. At the global level, the Standard-Setting Committee on Violence and Harassment in the World of Work adopted the Violence and Harassment Convention 2019 (No. 190) and its accompanying Recommendation (No. 206) in June 2019 - the first international labour standards on violence and harassment in the world of work. Sida’s contribution supported legal reviews and tripartite consultations which were important parts of the standard setting process and promotion of the Convention. At national level capacity building of constituents on national labour legislation and relevant international instruments has taken place. This led to progress in a number of national processes. In Cameroon there was progress in preparing bills regulating wages and hours of work, and also in protecting domestic workers from violence and harassment. Bolivia adopted a legislation granting compulsory accident insurance to women and men workers in construction, while in Bangladesh, working conditions were enhanced for tea plantation workers, including women workers, through a collective agreement. [GLOB/NORM, NAT/INST] Support was also aimed at further developing the ILOs work related to Just Transition and Environmental Sustainability. At the global level, the latest evaluation confirms that global products produced under the SIDA-ILO Partnership have succeeded in achieving high-level impact. This both internally through the development of a General Note on mainstreaming Just transition in ILO operations, and at UN level with the production of the ‘labor and working conditions’-safeguard standard for the UN Environment Management Group’s common approach to environmental and social standards in UN programming. At national level, capacity building was organised for constituents and partners in Tanzania to enhance understanding and practical modalities to advance a just transition. This country-level process revealed the need for sector-specific interventions, and a market system analysis was conducted in line with the MSD approach in the horticulture sector. This resulted in recommendation of specific policy recommendations and sector level interventions to promote greener jobs in the sector. To further catalyse efforts on green business development, a national green business competition was organised in collaboration with the Tanzania Employers Association, the Tanzania Recyclers Association, and UN Environment, followed by enterprise training and coaching to support their role in sustainable growth.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 FIDH, International Federation for Human Rights, har ansökt om fortsatt kärnstöd för perioden 2017-2020 i enlighet med dess strategiska plan 2017-2022.
FIDH är en federation bestående av 184 MR-organisationer från 112 länder. FIDH verkar för att skydda och upprätthålla de mänskliga rättigheterna såsom de uttrycks i FN's deklaration om de mänskliga rättigheterna och de centrala konventionerna för mänskliga rättigheter. FIDH riktar sig både mot ansvarsbärare och rättighetsbärare. Under strategiperioden prioriterar man sju områden: stöd till MR-försvarare; stärkt demokrati och ökade friheter; kvinnors rättigheter; migranterns rättighteter; LGBTI-personer rättigheter; kampen mot straffrihet; och mänskliga rättigheter och företagande.
Den totala budgeten för 2017-2020 uppgår till ca 400 miljoner SEK. Sida's bidrag uppgår till totalt 40 000 000 SEK. Det är en ökning i förhållande till tidigare stöd.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Support to International Federation for Human Rights (FIDH) a global network of more than 180 human rights organisations from more than 110 countries. FIDH works for the promotion of human rights, women's rights, migrants'rights and rule of law and for the protection of human rights defenders.

title.narrative: COVID-19 International Media Support Basket Fund 2016-2020
COVID-19 International Media Support Basket Fund 2016-2020

description.narrative: In line with IMS’ 2016-2019 Strategy, the 2016-2019 strategic support agreement between IMS and Sida the cost extension period will continue within the same two areas: 1. Strategic and organisational development, and 2. Rapid Response. The first part covers three pillars: a) programmatic and strategic development; b) organisational development; c) governance and leadership. The Rapid Response part serves the original core mandate of IMS and is part of the organisation’s innovative methodology development. Further, as the IMS’ new strategy for 2020-2023 emphasizes the great need for independent media and human rights-based civil society groups to leverage each other’s work and together push for accountability from those in power, recognizing that neither media nor civil society are able to bring about the necessary change alone. IMS intends to start the set up for the implementation if its new strategy by recruiting two expert advisors: one on safety for journalists and one on public inteterst journalism. Further, IMS will in teh new startegy period recruit two full-time staff members who will be tasked with improving the link between the individual programmes, departments and the organisation-wide communication of impact and results, as well as the learning that comes from implementing the programmes.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 International Media Support, IMS, stödjer överlevnaden hos media och journalistik i länder/samhällen som genomgår/upplever negativ demokratisk utveckling och strävar efter att återställa dess demokratiska funktion och roll i samhället. IMS arbete syftar till att stärka medias/journalisters konstruktiva roll till exempel under konflikt, genom att producera oberoende och professionella nyheter och information, som allmänheten och politiker kan använda för att fatta beslut baserat på korrekt och objektiv rapportering. IMS arbetar globalt och har ett flertal avtal med Sidas olika geografiska avdelningar för verksamhet i olika regioner och/eller länder: MENA, Somalia, Myanmar, Ryssland, Irak och Afghanistan.
Insatsen har två delar: - Organisationsutveckling och stärkande av funktioner som kommer hela organisationen tillgodo. Detta innebär i konkreta termer finansiering av tjänster inom IMS för bl a administrativ/finans/organisatoriskt lärande/jämställdhetsområden, resultatrapportering samt för att tillhandahålla möjligheter och system för det organisatoriska lärandet (t ex IT-system).
- Snabbresponsmekanismen (Rapid Response Mechanism, RRM), vilken möjliggör för IMS att agera snabbt till skydd och stöd för media och journalister i områden/på platser som utsatts för en allvarlig kris av något slag (t ex väpnad konflikt eller naturkatastrof).
Båda delarna svarar, på olika sätt, mot IMS övergripande strategi, vars målsättning är att bidra till att media och journalistik fungerar på ett sätt som gör att medborgare och beslutsfattare kan använda sig av informationen/journalistiken som produceras och publiceras för att fatta välinformerade beslut.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 International Media Support,IMS, supports media that has been affected by a given development in order to survive and to restore its functions and roles in society, and supports media in providing a constructive role for example under conflict,by producing independent and professional news and information.

title.narrative: COVID-19 UN Women 2017-2021 Strategic Partnership Framework
COVID-19 UN Women Strategic Partnership Framework

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 UN Women bildades 2010 genom beslut i FN:s generalförsamling och är operativt sedan den 1 januari 2011. UN Women arbetar med jämställdhet och kvinnors ökade egenmakt. UN Women har ett unikt mandat att leda, samordna och främja ansvarsutkrävande för hela FN-systemets arbete för jämställdhet och är sekretariat för FN:s Kvinnokommission (Commission on the Status of Women, CSW). Organisationen arbetar såväl normativt som operativt och ska ej ersätta övriga delar av FN-systemets jämställdhetsarbete. UN Womens målsättning är att uppmärksamma de jämställdhetsdimensioner som finns inom alla utvecklings- och MR-områden. Med utgångspunkt i den vision om jämställdhet som uttrycks i FN-stadgan arbetar UN Women bland annat för eliminering av diskriminering av kvinnor och flickor, kvinnors egenmakt och jämställdhet mellan kvinnor och män som mottagare av utveckling, MR, humanitär hjälp och fred och säkerhet. Organisationen arbetar även med att i samarbete med andra delar av FN-systemet formulera globala standarder och normer samt med att stödja medlemsländerna med implementering av dessa.
UN Women har ansökt till Sida om finansiering för "Strategic Partnership Framework 2017-2020" (SPF) med en total budget på 320 MSEK för fyra år.
Programmet är en fortsättning på det SPF som implementerades under 2011- 2016 med goda resultat. Resultaten bekräftas av en utvärdering av programmet samt en halvtidsöversyn av UN Womens strategiska plan 2014-2017. SPF 2017- 2020 syftar till att stödja UN Women att implementera sin Strategiska Plan 2014-2017 samt den nya Strategiska Planen som kommer att gälla 2018- 2021. Sidas finansiering kommer att gå till följande två resultatområden (Impact areas); 1) Öka kvinnors deltagande och inflytande i beslutsfattande organ; 4) Öka kvinnors ledarskap i fred, konflikt och humanitär respons. Programmet har en global ansats.
Sammanfattningsvis kommer det föreslagna programmet att bidra till: - Öka kvinnors ledarskap och deltagande, genom lagstiftning och policyer som förbättrar kvinnors rättigheter och genom att verka för kvinnors deltagande i beslutsfattande organ, samt genom att öka kvinnors politiska deltagande och inflytande.
- Öka kvinnors ledarskap i insatser för fred, säkerhet och humanitär respons genom att stärka implementeringen av kvinnor, fred och säkerhets åtaganden och ansvarsutkrävande ramverk i konflikt - och post konflikt länder, men även genom att stärka implementeringen av jämställdhetsåtaganden i humanitära insatser. Det bedöms relevant att humanitärt arbete omfattas av stödet då 80% av humanitära kriser sker i konfliktkontexter.
- Stärka UN Womens koordinering av FN systemet och dess partnerskap, resultatbaserade styrning, rapportering, kunskapshantering och utvärdering samt organisatorisk effektivitet på regional - och landnivå.
Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Continuation of SPF, support to UNWomen´s Strategic Plan goal 1 and 4.

To deliver on its triple mandate, UN Women should lead issues on gender equality and the empowerment of women, and to promote accountability within the UN system (coordinating mandate), have universal coverage, strategic presence and provide support to intergovernmental policy and normative processes (normative mandate) and carry out programmes at country level (operational mandate). The intervention will support two thematic areas of UN Women's Strategic Plan, Impact area 1: Increase women's leadership and participation and Impact area 4: to increase women's leadership in peace, security and humanitarian response. The SPF has four intended outcomes (two per impact area).1.1 Legislation and policies to advance women's rights and promote their participation in decision-making bodies are reformed and adopted.1.2 Gender responsive measures (mechanisms, processes and services) promote women's leadership and participation in politics. 4.1 Women, Peace and Security committments and accountability frameworks are adopted and implemented in conflict and post-conflict countries.4.2 Gender equality committments adopted and implemented in humanitarian action which includes disaster risk reduction and preparedness, response and recovery.

description.narrative: High lights of results SPF II in 2019 Since the contribution was initiated the SPF II has been aligned to UN Women's current Strategic Plan 2018-2021, why the outcomes have been reformulated as below: Outcome 1.1 Legislation and policies to advance women's rights and promote their participation in decision-making bodies are reformed and adopted. - Through SPF support, more than 30 countries and 6 regional offices were provided with technical assistance and comparative knowledge through various activities. Seed funding disbursements supported programming in 9 countries to advance legal and policy frameworks for strengthening women’s political participation. - In the area of data and SDG 5.5.1b monitoring and reporting several results were achieved. For example, the availability of comparable, quality data on SDG indicator 5.5.1b increased to 133 countries. This enabled the calculation of global and regional averages of the indicator for the first time. The UN Inter-Agency and Expert Group on Sustainable Development Goal Indicators (IAEG-SDGs) reclassified the indicator as Tier 1. Additionally, a chapter, co-written by UN Women and UNDP, within the Handbook on Governance Statistics, discussed the role of Electoral Management Bodies as primary source of data on political participation and the importance of integrating these data into the national systems of statistics. The Handbook, according to UN Women the first of its kind, was endorsed by UN Statistical Commission for use by National Statistical Offices and is expected to have high impact on the production and use of governance statistics across the world. - In its work on preventing violence against women in politics (VAWP) UN Women organized an Expert Group Meeting on Data and VAWP gathering more than 40 experts. This enabled mapping existing knowledge tools, databases, and surveys as sources of data on VAWP through sharing lessons learned, experiences, and good practices in VAWP data collection. The Guidebook on Preventing Violence Against Women in Elections continued to be used as a tool to engage with national stakeholders and raise their awareness of the issue. For example, in Zimbabwe, the guidebook informed capacity building initiatives for police forces. In Guatemala, the Civil Education Institute of the Electoral Tribunal issued a civic education guide on VAW in elections, largely informed by the guidebook. In Bolivia, the Guidebook informed monitoring by domestic observers. UN Women also partnered with Uppsala University to contribute a chapter to a forthcoming publication on VAW in Politics which is being edited by Prof. Elin Bjarnegård and Dr. Pär Zetterberg. The book is called Gender and Violence Against Political Actors. - Regarding UN Women’s work to promote responsive political processes and electoral arrangements one example is from Guatemala, where the gender policy of the Supreme Electoral Tribunal was implemented for the first time. This resulted on more than 150 members of municipal electoral boards and polling officers trained on gender mainstreaming in elections management; the implementation of gender responsive civic education and voting site arrangements (e.g. priority access for pregnant women and women with children, women with disabilities and special assistance to illiterate women); and the consolidation of a multi-stakeholder coordination platform on elections which now monitors VAWE. The program was supported by UN Women and UNDP. In Cameroon a gender diversity barometer was developed by the National Communications Council (CNC-NCC) to provide sound evidence to inform gender-responsive decision-making by the media and at the same time, promoting social norms change and positive perceptions of women political leaders. It is a result of the strategic partnership established between UN Women and the CNC-NCC ahead of the 2018 presidential elections. The first set of results were published in September 2019 and used to build the capacities of eighty gender focal points of key national media. Outcome 2.1 Gender responsive measures (mechanisms, processes and services) promote women's leadership and participation in politics. UN Women continued to provide technical assistance, knowledge-sharing and capacity strengthening to parliaments and parliamentary bodies to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment. - Through SPF support over 2,500 women leaders, aspiring candidates and elected officials in Bolivia, Cameroon, Côte d’Ivoire, Guatemala, DRC, Niger, and Uruguay enhanced their political leadership and networking skills in campaign planning, communications and messaging, constituency outreach and networking. In Bolivia and Guatemala the trainings were especially directed towards indigenous women leaders. - The UN Women global training curriculum on women’s political leadership was rolled out at country level. UN Women expanded the pool of certified trainers on the curriculum to assist with country offices’ capacity-building plans for aspiring women leaders and candidates. The curriculum was translated into French and Spanish, and put into practice with 2 regional Training of Trainers workshops in collaboration with UN Women offices in Africa. - In Côte d’Ivoire, members of parliament enhanced their skills on gender responsive law reform through capacity building initiatives facilitated by UN Women. This effectively contributed to the inclusion of gender provisions (definitions of rape and related penalties) in the new penal code. - In Rwanda, the Women’s Parliamentary Forum enhanced organisational capacities through technical support and capacity building provided by UN Women. In addition, legal analysis supported by UN Women informed initial efforts to repeal articles of the family legislation law. Outcome 3.1 Constitutions and legal frameworks to advance gender equality and women's rights are reformed and adopted. UN Women continued to engage with field offices and UN partners to support development and implementation of gender responsive legal frameworks. - UN Women organized a global training for staff on legal reform and women's access to justice in partnership with UNICEF, UNODC and UNDP. Thirty staff members from 16 Country Offices and two Regional Offices, UN Women HQ as well as from UNODC, UNDP, UNICEF and DPO, participated in the two-day training. - Policy guidance, technical assistance and seed funding provided to Country Offices contributed to advancing gender responsive legal reform and implementation. In Bangladesh, for example, a request from the Ministry of Women and Children’s affairs (MOWCA), for support on reporting on SDG indicator 5.1.1, presented an opportunity for UN Women to partner with MOWCA on the implementation of the Strategy on Equality in Law for Women and Girls by 2030. As a first step UN Women commissioned a gender analysis of discriminatory legislation, in coordination with UN partners on the ground and in line with CEDAW Committee concluding observations. Through consultations and workshops partnership was strengthened with civil society organizations (especially women’s led organizations and LGBTI organizations), as well as with lawyers and representatives of the Judiciary. Another example is from Côte d’Ivoire where UN Women in collaboration with the Prime Minister's Office and others, conducted a law review and identified discriminatory provisions, with specific consideration to the needs of women widows, women living with disabilities and women living with HIV. In addition, direct technical support provided to review the National Development Plan informed the public administration reform process. Outcome 4.1 Women, Peace and Security committments and accountability frameworks are adopted and implemented in conflict and post-conflict countries. - SPF II supported the development or implementation of National Action Plans in 26 different countries and four regional organisations (AU, EU, NATO and League of Arab states). Some highlights of SPF II involvement include a fully financed, time-bound NAP with indicators in Lebanon, timely implementation in Jordan, outlining process for NAP in Egypt and Morocco, supporting Uruguay to develop its first NAP and new NAPs in Kosovo and Tajikistan. Fund raising for NAP implementation has increasingly emerged and in Liberia the SPF funded WPS specialist supported the NAP process as well as the successful fund raising for its implementation. A SPF funded consultant helped the AU to start monitoring implementation of 1325 in eight countries with NAPs in eastern and southern Africa. - The programme supported activities or deployments in 30 countries, 4 regional offices and funded directley investigations on Gaza, Syria, Mali, South Sudan, Cote d´Ivoire and Yemen. The 32 depolyed experts documented atrocities against women and girls in some of the worst conflicts of our times. Six of the investigations were funded by SPF II. The experts contributed to deepen the gender analysis and connect the fact finding and documenting of sexual violence with harmful practises and norms, early and forces marriages, bride price etc and how those for example in South Sudan then relate to cattle-raiding and CRSV. This could then sharpen the advice and recommendation of the Commission of Inquiry. In Yemen the Group of Experts the scope could be expanded to gender-based prosecutions of women human rights defenders, journalists and activists and hostage taking of women and girls - apart from the direct documenting of sexual violence incidents committed by the parties to the conflict. - 40 per cent of the individuals addressing the Security Council in 2019 were women, ten points higher than previous record. SPF II finance and structures and many other actors have been part of pushing for this result. UN Women undertook an independent assessment of the gender provisions in the three peace and security reviews from 2015, including the global study. Out of 30 gender-related recommendations from 2015, 50% have been implemented or are in progress, 40% have mixed or inconsistent results and 10% are not progressing or are going backwards. Findings were included in the Secretary Generals report on WPS in 2019. - In countries in transition and with peace keeping missions like Liberia, Sudan and Haiti, UN Women could play a prominent role in positioning and integrating gender equality and women empowerment. In for example Haiti, SPF funded UN Womens participation in the Strategic Assessment mission to ensure these links were explored and integrated in the transition between missions (MINUJUSTH to BINUH). And in for example the Philippines, SPF-funded WPS specialist was critical in advancing women's inclusion in the Bangsamoro, Mindanao process of transition. - In Kosovo over 650 of women got reparations for the crimes committed against them 20 years ago, by the strengthening of the governments mechanism for the processes like the police investigations, special prosecution and the commission. - In Liberia over hundred women were released from pre-trial detention after benefiting from free legal aid. The work foregone the outcome was the approval of five new gender policies within the security institutions and a gender responsive legal aid policy where a WPS specialist provided technical and strategic oversight. - In several countries there is an increase in women representation, with for example lebanese women showing highest ever political participation, South sudanese women increasing presence in the pre-transitional commissions. In Syria women constitutes 30% of the Constitutional Committee (a partial but incomplete success and by the efforts of many actors). Outcome 4.2 Gender equality commitments adopted and implemented in humanitarian action which includes disaster risk reduction and preparedness, response and recovery. - UN Women has been the convener for the Grand Bargain Friends of Gender group, which has helped to place gender equality and empowerment of women and girls in crisis contexts as recognized by the Grand Bargain Eminent person for transformative action and allowed for local women to advocate globally within the Grand Bargain (being the leading platform for humanitarian financing). - UN Women offered technical expertise in 29 countries to help ensure that the UN coordinated response took women and girls needs and priorities into account. In 18 countries UN Women was directly contributing as member of the Humanitarian Country Teams and in 16 countries provided TA in preparations of Humanitarian Needs Overiew/Humanitarian Response Plans at national level. Examples include Cox´s Bazar in Bangladesh where SPF II has taken on a coordinating and strategic role in gender equality and empowerment of women and children in the Rohinga Refugee Crisis response. - The Gender Handbook for humanitarian action went online and was translated into Arabic, English, French and Spanish and launched in 2019. Over 2 500 humanitarian actors and frontline responders were training by UN Women in 24 crisis affected countries. - Direct support to over 500 000 crisis affected women in need of lifesaving and livelihood support. - Contributed with gender-responsive disaster resilience policies, strategies, plans and needs assessments in 41 countries, covering 181 million people, in cooperation with national governments and 562 women's organisations to increase women's agency and leadership. - UN Women partnered with 10 UN agencies across humanitarian settings and supported 752 local women-led and women's rights organisations, enabling them to to take part of the humanitarian response. - Within Disaster Risk Reduction, UN Women implemented joint programs with 16 UN agencies to enhance gender-responsiveness of the UN system's DDR and resilience programming. - On behalf of the IASC reference group for gender in humanitarian action, the first follow-up report was produced as part of the monitoring cycle of the IASC new "Gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls in humanitarian action" Policy from 2017. Organizational effectiveness and efficiency The Mid-term Review was concluded in September 2019 and 13 out of 17 agreed recommendations for implementation was initiated before December 2019 but the follow-up will be reflected in the report covering 2020. The delivery rate for 2019 was 96 percent and is regarded as high and have been consistent for the past few years. 19 out of 24 outcomes and outputs are achieved or surpassed. It is clear that deliveries in terms of finances and programmatic targets are high and has increased steadily since inception. It also shows that implementation is satisfactory on track.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
