description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 RWI:s ”Human Rights Capacity Development Programme in China” för perioden är i huvudsak ett samarbete med den akademiska sektorn.
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 RWI's China program focuses on strengthening Chinese academic institutions in Human Rights components and teaching.

The overall objective of the Raoul Wallenberg Institute of Human Rights and Humanitarian Law’s Human Rights Capacity Development Programme for China 2017 – 2018 is to strengthen institutions and networks for the promotion and protection of human rights, including gender equality, in China. The interventions intended outcomes are: 1: Improved human rights education and engagement, including education for gender equality, by key Chinese academic institutions; 2: Improved capacity for research-based advocacy, including an inter-sectional perspective, amongst academics, CSOs, DPOs and government officials; 3: Institutionalisation of human rights education within the Chinese prosecution system; 4: Improved implementation of gender sensitive juvenile justice mechanisms among justice sector stakeholders.

description.narrative: Overall, RWI’s activities in China have contributed to the program objective; namely "to strengthen institutions and networks for the promotion and protection of human rights, including gender equality, in China". The efforts to register the organization in China, a requirement by the Foreign NGO Law of 2017, were however unsuccessful. This development had consequences for the program plans, and resulted in discontinued cooperation with justice sector institutions. RWI was subsequently not able to support the continued strengthening of human rights education within the Chinese prosecution system. Working through temporary activity approvals, as a result of not being able to register in-line with the mentioned Law, the program focused on the consolidation of initiatives and partnerships in the academic sector where some space remain to continue to support education, training and research. Despite the challenges, the following results are noted: i. Peking University’s PULS/RCHR Human Rights Master Programme is recognized as an established model institution and a valuable resource for human rights teaching across China. ii. There is an increased interest in learning and teaching courses on gender and human rights as well as business and human rights in China. iii. There is increased networking and knowledge-sharing among Chinese academics, and encouraging examples of an increased voice of human rights educators within China. iv. Institutionalised and sustainable human rights training courses of high quality are provided by Chinese prosecutor training institutions, both at national and provincial levels. v. Chaoyue Agency is increasingly seen as a leading proponent of juvenile justice reform in line with international human rights standards in China. Despite of the discontinuation of the NPrC project, there is still a steady continuation of human rights education within the prosecutor training system, which is the legacy of the cooperation between RWI and NPrC during the past decade. Furthermore, Chaoyue Agency has taken the lead in research on juvenile justice social work in China, informing and improving the legislative and policy framework through dissemination of international experiences. vi. The disability and human rights project becomes a strong network for rights-based approaches to disability beyond the project itself, with the project partner EISA establishing itself as a national centre for human rights expertise, skills and resources. The annual publication of Disability Rights Studies in China is a useful resource for researchers and advocates working in the field of disability rights in China. RWI has explored possibilities of developing activities in the field of human rights and environment through a series of workshops and round-tables on human rights and chemicals organised in 2018, which resulted in a very timely publication and created broader interest and support for RWI’s China Programme.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Human Rights, Inclusion and Empowerment Trust Fund 2020-2022
Human Rights, Inclusion and Empowerment Trust Fund 2020-2022

description.narrative: Objectives and outcomes of the intervention The main objective of the HRIETF is to "increase and strengthen the understanding and application of human rights principles in the WBG work". Through technical and financial support, the HRIETF aims to scale up internal capacity of human rights in the WBG through the HRIETF-supported activities. The TF has the following outcomes: Outcome 1: Human Rights are incorporated into analytical products and operations Outcome 2: WB staff and management understand and value the incorporation of human rights in development Outcome 3: Partnerships influence analysis and/or operations supported by the HRIETF The above results will be achieved through sex thematic funding windows; Governance, Inclusive Institutions and Empowerment, 2) Infrastructure, 3) Fragility, Conflict, Violence and Forced Displacement, 4) Research and Evaluation, 5) Social Inclusion and 6) Program management and Administration.

Fonden för mänskliga rättigheter, inkludering och Empowerment (Human Rights, Inclusion and Empowerment Fund) – HRIETF är en fond inom Världsbanken (VB) vars verksamhet bygger på erfarenheter och lärdomar (utvärdering gjord 2017) från den tidigare Nordic Trust Fund (NTF).
HRIETF har ett WBG (World Bank Group)-mandat och dess övergripande mål är att "öka och stärka förståelsen och tillämpningen av principerna för mänskliga rättigheter i WBG´s arbete". Genom tekniskt och finansiellt stöd vill HRIETF öka den interna kunskapen om mänskliga rättigheter och hur mänskliga rättigheter kan integreras i Världsbankens verksamhet. För att uppnå detta avser HRIETF att arbeta strategiskt med WBG ledarskap/chefskap för att säkerställa att mänskliga rättigheter inkluderas och integreras på institutionell nivå i organisationen. Dess syfte är även att ge finansiellt bidrag till VBs landskontor och tematiska enheter på huvudkontoret för att integrera mänskliga rättigheter i sin verksamhet. Fonden kommer också att fokusera sitt arbete på kommunikation, kunskapshantering, lärande och partnerskapsbyggande. HRIETF kommer arbeta genom sex tematiska fönster för att nå sitt övergripande mål; 1) Demokrati, Institutioner och Empowerment, 2) Infrastruktur, 3) ) Sårbarhet, Konflikt, Våld och Tvångsförflyttning, 4) Forskning och Utvärdering) och 5) Social Inkludering samt 6) Programhantering och Administration.
HRIETF är ett ”kunskaps- och lärande” initiativ som inrättades 2009 av Danmark, Finland, Island, Norge och Sverige och senare anslöt sig även Tyskland. Fonden har haft sin organisatoriska hemvist på olika enheter inom VB genom åren. I oktober 2019 påbörjade ett organisatoriskt förändringsarbete inom banken vilket i förlängningen kom att innebära att fonden flyttats från Governance avdelningen till avdelningen för Social Utveckling.
NTF´s övergripande mål var att hjälpa banken att ”utveckla en ökad uppfattning om hur de mänskliga rättigheterna förhåller sig till organisationens analytiska och operativa verksamhet”. Dess verksamhet var att utforska och identifiera innovativa metoder för att integrera rättighetsperspektivet i organisationen för att nå VB-målet att minska fattigdomen och öka det gemensamma välståndet. NTF gav ekonomiskt bidrag till VBs landkontor samt enheter på huvudkontoret och bidrog med tekniskt stöd till Världsbanks team för att utforska sambandet mellan deras arbete och mänskliga rättigheter. Sedan 2010 har fonden godkänt 111 bidrag i fem bidrags-rundor, genomsnitt US $240 000 och med ett maximalt beviljande av US $450 000.
I denna nya fas har HRIETF, vidareutvecklat tre strategier som fokuserar på kommunikation, kunskapshantering, lärande och partnerskap. Kommunikationsstrategin är inriktad mot identifiering av viktiga målgrupper och partners med syfte att på ett strategiskt vis kommunicera verksamheten samt dess resultat. Den övergripande målsättningen för kunskapshantering och lärande är att öka tillämpningen av mänskliga rättigheter i och utanför projektbidragen och därigenom bidra till att lärandet institutionaliseras. Den tredje strategin är partnerskapsstrategin som omfattar partnerskap mellan både externa och interna partners.
The Nordic Trust Fund (NTF), har nu bytt namn till HRIETF utvärderades 2017 (2009 - 2017). Sammanfattningsvis har NTF bidragit till att minska vissa av spänningarna som relaterar till mänskliga rättigheter inom VB. VB-team har integrerat mänskliga rättighet i sitt arbete på ett sätt som har upplevts som stärkande. De ekonomiska bidragen (grants) har bidragit till att bygga kunskap bland VB-team när det gäller att genomföra projekt och påverka attityder och beteenden i relation till mänskliga rättigheter. Projekt har lett till institutionell förändring inom VB, till exempel antagandet av strategin för sexuell orientering och könsidentitet samt både antagande och implementering av ramverket för miljö och socialfrågor som uttryckligen hänvisar till mänskliga rättigheter.
Sidas erfarenhet av att samarbeta med fonden har varit positiv. Dialogen med sekretariatet och andra givare har varit produktiv och robust. Resultaten av kontinuerlig och tät diskussion speglas i det nya och förstärkta projektdokument där resultatstyrning förstärkts och strategin för projekt (grants) har omarbetats och är nu mer systematisk och strategisk. Det kvarstår utmaningar som reflekteras i de identifierade dialogfrågorna samt i riskerna. Dialogfrågor kommer Sida att driva i dialog med banken, fondens sekretariat och andra givare under avtalsperioden.
VB har genom olika initativ svarat mot covid -19 pandemin. Fonden för diskussioner internt om hur man på bästa sätt ska involvera fondens aktiviteter i responsen. I det nästkommande PC (sept. 2020) kommer frågan att diskutteras i mer detalj.

The World Bank Group (WBG) through the Human Rights, Inclusion and Empowerment Trust Fund (HRIETF ) is mandated and committed (through its five institutions) to reduce poverty and increase shared prosperity (Twin-goals). The WBG has a member base of 189 countries and has presence in 130 offices worldwide.
The HRIETF follows on from the Nordic Trust Fund (NTF) and is based on discussions with the NTF donors during the second quarter 2019. The HRIETF is placed within the WBG at the Social Development Practice. The new TF also builds on the conclusions from the independent evaluation conducted during 2017.
The HRIETF has a WBG mandate, and the development objective of the TF is: “increase and strengthen the understanding and application of human rights principles in the WBG´s work”. Through technical and financial support, the HRIETF want to scale up internal capacity on human rights. It aims to work strategically with the WBG management to ensure institutional advancement of human rights in its operations. In addition, the HRIETF will provide grants to WB teams (WBG Country Management Units at country level and to WBG practices at the headquarters) to integrate human rights into its operations. It will also scale- its communication and knowledge management & learning work. The HRIETF has sexthematic windows in which it aims to operate; 1) Governance, Inclusive Institutions and Empowerment, 2) Infrastructure, 3) Fragility, Conflict, Violence and Forced Displacement, 4) Research and Evaluation, 5) Social Inclusion and 6) Program management and Administration.
The HRIETF is a knowledge and learning initiative established in 2009 by Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden, and joined later by Germany. The mandate of the NTF was to help the Bank develop an informed view of how human rights relate to its analytical and operational activities. Its objectives were to explore and identify innovative approaches for incorporating human rights perspectives and empowering vulnerable groups to help make WBG analysis and operations more effective in reducing poverty and boosting shared prosperity. It did so through a grant program that provided financial and technical support to World Bank teams interested in exploring the link between their work and human rights. Since 2010 the grant program has approved 111 grants in five grant rounds, averaging US$ 240,000 and with a maximum grant of US$ 450,000.
In addition to the programme document, the Secretariat has developed three strategies that focuses on Communication, Knowledge Management and Learning and Partnerships. The communication strategy is centered on identification of key audiences and partners for communicating results. The Knowledge Management and Learning strategy overall goal is to increase the uptake of human rights in and beyond the grants, thereby contributing to learning being captured and institutionalized. The third strategy is the partnership strategy which encompasses Trust Fund wider partnerships.
In 2017 the Nordic Trust Fund (NTF), now HRIETF (name change in 2020) was evaluated (2009 - 2017). In sum, the NTF has contributed to alleviating some of the tensions with respect to human rights issues within the WBG. WBG teams have integrated human rights considerations into their work in a manner that has been perceived as strengthening the work. Grant projects have helped to build knowledge among WBG teams in implementing grants and influenced attitudes and behavior in relation to human rights. NTF grant activities have led to some specific cases and results of institutional change, affecting Bank-wide approaches to certain issues or specific policy implementation, such as the strategy for Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity as well as the adoption and implementation of the Environmental and Social Framework (ESF) that explicitly reference to human rights.
Sida´s experience engaging with the TF has been positive. The dialogue with the secretariat and other donors have been productive and robust. The results of these discussion can be mirrored in the new and strengthened project document where results based managed has been reinforced and the strategy for grant making has been modified and is now more systematic and strategic. Several challenges however remain; the TF ability to demonstrate results on impact level is one such example. The identified dialogue issues will be important to explicitly emphasize in the upcoming agreement period.
Covid -19 has had severe impact on our whole society. The World Bank Group has put in place a response. The role of the TF in this response is not clear. It is however something Sida aims to follow closely in dialogue with the Secretariat but also to raise in the upcoming PC.

title.narrative: COVID-19 UNESCO Freedom of Expression, Communication and Culture 2018-2021
COVID-19 UNESCO Yttrandefrihet, kommunikation och kultur 2018/07-2022/0621

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Extrabudgetärt stöd till UNESCOs sektioner för Yttrandefrihet, kommunikation och kultur 2018-2021 utifrån UNESCO's Strategi 39 C/5 samt till Unesco Institute for Statistics.
FN's organisation för utbildning, vetenskap och kultur - UNESCO - har genom fyra projektförslag sökt stöd från Sida för sin verksamhet när det gäller främjande av yttrandefrihet globalt, regionalt och nationellt genom två av sina verksamhetsområden; Kommunikation & Information samt Kultur. Ansökningspaketet består av två Special Accounts, dvs multigivarfonder för icke-öronmärkt flexibelt stöd till UNESCO's kärnverksamhet inom Kommunikation & Information samt två projektstöd som stöd till verksamhetsområdena kultur och statistik. Förslagen inkluderar: - Programdokument för "The Special Account for Freedom of Expression and the Safety of Journalists" från UNESCO's Communication & Information Sector - Programdokument för "The Special Account for the International Progarmme for Development of Communication" från UNESCO's Communication & Information Sector - Projektförslag "Reshaping Cultural Policies for the promotion of Fundamental Freedoms and the Diversity of Cultural Expressions" från UNESCO's Culture Sector - Projektförslag "Global Monitoring of Communication & Information" från UNESCO's Institute for Statistics
Sida ger stöd till UNESCO's normativa och operativa arbete för yttrandefrihet med det övergripande målet att skapa förutsättningar globalt för fri och självständig media, fritt och självständigt kulturliv, mångfald samt säkerhet för journalister. Verksamheten är både global och landspecifik, där globala komponenter i huvudsak är normativt orienterade och komponenter på landnivå fokuserar på kapacitetsutveckling, policyutveckling och implementering samt skapar arenor för dialog mellan ansvarstagare och civilsamhället. Verksamheten bedrivs genom ett sampel mellan det globala och landspecifika arbetet och genom synergier mellan de två verksamhetsområdena Kommunikation & Information samt Kultur. I fokus för verksamhet på landnivå är länder som präglas av ett demokratisk underskott, inklusive inskränkningar inom yttrandefrihet och brist på oberoende media och kulturliv. Jämställdhet är ett fokusområde för insatsen.
När det gäller det normativa arbetet globalt för yttrandefrihet och medieutveckling bidrar Kommunikation & Information-programmet (CI) i huvudsak till områdena säkerhet för journalister, yttrandefrihet online och offline, media literacy samt jämställdhet inom media. På landnivå bidrar programmet till landspecifika yttrandefrihetsinsatser i Afrika, MENA och Latinamerika inom lagstiftnings- och påverkansarbete samt kapacitetsbyggande insatser inom ICT, media, jämställdhet och journalistik, vilket är ett viktigt bidrag till att stärka demokratisering och yttrandefrihet i dessa länder. Programmet bidrar även till UNESCO's arbete med att utveckla globala indiktorer för media och internet genom IPDC - International Programme for the Development of Communication och UNESCO Institute for Statistics - UIS. CI-programmet kommer att stödjas genom två så kallade Multi-Donor Special Accounts i linje med en programansats för Sidas samarbete med UNESCO samt genom ett projektstöd till UIS.
Kulturprogrammet (CLT) är starkt förankrat i 2005 års UNESCO konvention för kulturell mångfald som har yttrandefrihet och jämställdhet som grundläggande principer. Kapacitetsutveckling på landnivå (16 länder) fokuserar på förståelse av konventionen och metoder för datainsamlig och uppföljning av konventionen, vilket bl a inkluderar bevakning av yttrandefrihet/kommunikation. Det globala normativa arbetet fokuserar på att dokumentera och formulera policies, standards och regleringar inom området. CLT-programmet stöds genom ett projektstöd.
Total budget för UNESCO's verksamheter 2018-2019 är för CI 185 MSEK och för CLT Expected Result 7 133,5 MSEK. Då står Regular Programme + Voluntary contributions för respektive 30% av CI och 75% av CLT. Ett flertal givare bidrar till det extrabudgetära stödet, ca 129 MSEK för CI, varav Sida 88 MSEK respektive 33,6 MSEK för CTL, varav Sida 28 MSEK. Därutöver är de största givarna EU, Världsbanken, Norge, Finland, Nederländerna, Kamerun och Schweiz.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Extrabudgetary support to UNESCO's sections on Communication and Information, and Culture
UNESCO has applied to Sida for funding to carry out its "Freedom of Expression, Communication and Culture Programme 2018-2021". The intervention aims at contributing to fostering freedom of expression at a global, regional and local level through two of its sections; Communication & Information and Culture.
Sida supports UNESCO's normative and operational work for freedom of expression with the overall objective to contibute to global conditions for free and independent media and cultural life including diversity of cultural expressions as well as safety for journalists. The work is both global and country specific, where global components are mainly normatively oriented while components on a country level focus on capacity building, policy development and implementation as well as create foras for dialogue between duty bearers and civil society. The programme is conducted through interplay between the global and country specific work and through synergies between the two sections' respective work, Communication & Information and Culture. In focus for the country work are countries characterized with democratic deficit, including restrictions on freedom of expression and lack of an independent media and cultural life. Gender equality is of main focus for the contribution.
For the global normative work for freedom of expression and media development is the Communication & Information Programme (CI) contributing to the areas of saftey for journalists, freedom of expression on line and offline, media literacy as well as gender in media. At a country level, the programme contributes to country specific freedom of expression projects in Africa, MENA and Latin America within the areas of justice and advocacy work and for capacity building projects within ICT, media, gender equality and journalism, which is an important contribution for the strengthening of democratization and freedom of expression in these countries. The programme also contributes to UNESCO's IPDC - Intenational Programme for the Development of Communication's and UIS - UNESCO's Institute for Statistics' work with the development of global indicators for media and Internet.
The Culture Programme (CLT) is strongly anchored in the UNESCO Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions 2005 with freedom of expression and gender equality as guiding principles. Capacity development at a country level (in 16 countries) focuses on the understanding of the Convention and methods for data collection and follow-up of the Convention, which includes monitoring freedom of expression and communication. The global normative work focuses on documentation and formulation of cultural policies, standards and legislation.

This intervention supports UNESCO's work on freedom of expression and 2005 Convention on culture diversity through the Communication and Information (CI) sector and the Culture (CLT) sector during the period 2018-2021. The main objectives correspond to expected results in the UNESCO's Medium Term Strategy for 2014-2021 (37 C/4) and Programme and Budget for 2018-2021 (39 C/5). The main objectives of the contribution are: Support to Communication and Information Sector: Outcome/expected result 1: Targeted Member States enhance legal and institutional frameworks related to the protection and promotion of freedom of expression online/offline, right of access to information and safety of journalists, in accordance with international standards (and UN Plan of Action on the Safety of Journalists and the Issue of Impunity) and through integrating a gender sensitive approach. Outcome/expected result 2: Member States have benefited from enhanced media contributions to diversity, gender equality and youth empowerment in and through media; and societies are empowered through media and information literacy programmes and effective media response to emergency and disaster. Outcome/expected result 3: Media development is strengthened, and Member States have improved monitoring and reporting systems, and these results are reinforced by external grass roots projects supported by the International Programme for the Development of Communication (IPDC). Support to the Culture Sector: Outcome/Expected result: Governments and civil society organizations engage in evidence-based and participatory policy making and monitoring processes in accordance with the principles and objectives of the 2005 Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions. Support to UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS): This is considered by Sida a pilot, with the aim of strengthening UIS' role and a coordinated work between CI, IPDC and UIS to contribute to data collection and statistics for freedom of expression and SDG 16.
The above objectives correspond directly to Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and contribute in particular to SDG 16:10 and its targets 16:10:1 and 16:10:2 and also SDG 4, 5, 9, 13. The support to the CI sector is channelled through two multi donor accounts, the Multidonor Programme for Freedom of expression and the Safety of Journalists and the Multidonor Special Account for the International Programme on Development Communication (IPDC). Key features of the programmes include support to the UN Action Plan for the Safety of Journalists and Issues of Impunity, The World Trends report on Freedom of Expression and Media Development, monitoring of SDG 16:10, Internet Universality Indicator Suite, to mention a few. Activities serve to promote the development, adoption and implementation of relevant policies and normative frameworks to strengthen the environment for freedom of expression and press freedom and to support sustainable and independent media institutions. Main activities to achieve the objectives of the intervention are to enhance legal and institutional frameworks, building on UNESCO's leverage to influence duty-bearers, including judges, legislature, parliamentarians, and law enforcement bodies. This is done through evidence based policy formulation and recommendations, technical expertise, capacity building and advocacy. At the same time media, journalists, artists, academia and civil society are enabled by UNESCO to take an active role in this work, by capacity building and multi-stakeholders platforms. Trainings differ for different context, but could include countering hate speech, conflict sensitive or gender sensitive reporting as well as elections covering. Activities also facilitate pluralism and participation in media, promote gender equality in both media production and content, and empower citizens with increased media and information literacy competencies. The support to the 2005 Convention supports governance and cultural policy making through capacity buidling of cultural policy makers, civil society organisations and other stakeholders. Also platforms for interaction between governments and civil society for monitoring the Convention and contributing to evidence based culture policy making. Freedom of expression is a guiding principle of the Convention and artistic freedom a monitoring pillar of the convention. Mechanisms for UNESCO to optimize its contribution globally, in targeted countries (16 for culture and more than 80 for media) and within the UN are so called flagship reports where international standards and norms, including UN Action Plans and Conventions, are implemented and followed up, used as reference and for accountability and standard setting. These include the "World Trends Report on Freedom of Expression and Media Development" and the 2005 Convention Global Report "Re:Shaping Cultural Policies". Another activity is to contribute to community media policies and to enhance Media Literacy. Global Standard setting, developing media indicators, is also part of UNESCO’s work. Awareness raising and networking is supported for instance by organising celebrations of international days such as World Press Freedom Day, International Day to End Impunity for Crimes against Journalists and World Day for Cultural Diversity for Dialogue and Development.

description.narrative: - World Press Freedom Day globally was celebrated in Addis Abeba 2019. As a major accomplishments of the Conference, participants adopted the Addis Ababa Declaration, which focuses on the media's role in electoral processes in digital times, and which now informs UNESCO's strategic approach going forward around the world. As part of the International Day to End Impunity UNESCO launched the global campaign #KeepTruthAlive - Three In-Focus Reports were published in 2019 under the following themes: (i) Elections and Media in Digital Times; (ii) Access to Information: A New Promise for Sustainable Development and (iii) Intensified Attacks, New Defences: Developments in the Fight to Protect Journalists and End Impunity to shape discussion and deepen policy resonance around the key themes - Safety of Journalists enhanced. Within the framework of African Union, a Working Group on the Promotion and Protection of Journalism and the Safety of Journalists in Africa was established. National and regional networks and mechanisms were created in Palestine, Somalia, Myanmar, Pakistan, Tunisia and Eastern Africa. - UNESCO has enhanced the technical and editorial capacities of over 370 community radio stations in seven countries to serve diverse audiences - Member states capacity of Media and Information Literacy (MIL) has strengthened through workshops, curricula review and training. This has empowered 480 duty bearers, 300 teachers and 33 youth organisations. 193 countries have unanimously proclaimed Global MIL Week as official week at the 40th Session of the UNESCO General Conference on 25 November 2019, thereby committing UNESCO to assist Member States in their quest to advance MIL policy and practices - The endorsement by the IPDC Council of the use of the indicators for UNESCO’s Internet Universality ROAM (Rights, Openness, Accessibility to all, Multistakeholder participation) principles has contributed to the improvement of Internet policies and fostering of digital collaborations at international and regional levels. Thanks to programmatic work in this area, national assessment based on ROAM indicators have been undertaken in eight countries (Benin, Brazil, Ecuador, Kenya, Paraguay, Senegal, Tunisia and Uruguay) even though the original plan was for three countries. Training on the implementation of Internet indicators has been provided in six Latin American countries - A significant number of countries saw their capacities built or strengthened to effectively monitor and report on the safety of journalists at the national level (e.g. Colombia, Pakistan, Uganda, Vietnam). Five South-East Asian Member States (Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Timor-Leste) enhanced the capacity of their researchers to conduct assessments on journalists’ safety using the Journalists’ Safety Indicator (JSI) Framework. These advances help stimulate and nourish the creation of institutions mechanisms for protection of journalists and prosecution of perpetrator - Capacity were strengthened through the training of more than 2 800 judiciary operators from twelve Latin American countries in international and regional standards on freedom of expression, access to information and safety of journalists - Monitoring and reporting instruments for SDG indicator 16.10.2 (access to information) were designed in collaboration with the UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS) and expert organizations from all regions, to enable uniform and accurate comparison at global and national levels. Following UNESCO’s data collection exercise in January 2019, 43 countries collected and provided data at national level that fed into UNESCO’s Global Report on SDG 16.10.2, which mapped global progress for the first the time in a more comparable manner. As a result of this work, a worldwide survey (with the involvement of 69 countries) on the implementation of Access to Information laws was launched in early 2020 - Member States at the 74th UN General Assembly on 15 October 2019 decided to recognize 28 September as the International Day for Universal Access to Information (IDUAI) - 30 young female journalists from Gambia, who used to be marginalized within their newsrooms, have been empowered with new capacity to do journalism about development and over 80 female journalists in Uganda feel more secured in their reporting and advocating freedom of expression through gaining knowledge and skills that will ensure their safety offline and in online spaces. An educational programme in over 20 Latin American countries dedicated to building resilience among Caribbean journalists in the context of Climate Change - IPDC supported 42 projects aimed at strengthening the capacity of locally-owned media in Africa, Asia, and Latin America and the Caribbean. The projects involved stakeholders such as the Samoa Journalists Association, Asia-Pacific Broadcasting Union, various community radio partners, as well as journalism training institutions. The projects fostered quality journalism, coverage of climate change, advancement of gender equality in and through media, community participation through local media, enhancing media pluralism, and also strengthened media crisis preparedness. Over 203 journalists, editors, and media professionals received training - In line with the 2005 Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions (2005 Convention) spaces for dialogue and participatory processes are in place in 16 countries, gathering relevant actors (government, civil society, academia, private sector, media sector, women's ministries and organisations etc) for informed policy making and monitoring. The platforms include interministerial as well as regional cooperation. - Three “Create 2030” debates were organised at country-level (Mongolia, Uganda and Tanzania) as part of the project’s activities, reaching wider audiences and enhancing public dialogue for policy change. Create 2030 is a series of talks hosted by UNESCO to discuss how investments in creativity can have a direct impact on achieving the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. During 2020 a new concept of global debate was launched by UNESCO as a response to the Corona crises; ResiliArt - The Global monitoring framework for cultural expression was advanced. The 2005 Convention's monitoring framework was revised to have clear links to the Sustainable Development Goals. During 2020 two In Focus Reports on Artistic Freedom and Gender Equality was published in order to feed in to global debate on cultural policy - During 2020, the programme has swiftly adapted as a response to the Corona crises, with accentuated need for support to media houses, reliable information, mobility, safety and freedom of expression for cultural workers and journalists. New initiatives are on line training to more than 6000 media professionals in 163 countries in reporting about the pandemic, global conferences on the theme of Freedom of Expression in times of pandemic, Resiliart-talks - a global debate as how to best rescue the cultural sector, strengthening of a global fact checkers network, etc
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative: - World Press Freedom Day globally was celebrated in Addis Abeba 2019. As a major accomplishments of the Conference, participants adopted the Addis Ababa Declaration, which focuses on the media's role in electoral processes in digital times, and which now informs UNESCO's strategic approach going forward around the world. As part of the International Day to End Impunity UNESCO launched the global campaign #KeepTruthAlive - Three In-Focus Reports were published in 2019 under the following themes: (i) Elections and Media in Digital Times; (ii) Access to Information: A New Promise for Sustainable Development and (iii) Intensified Attacks, New Defences: Developments in the Fight to Protect Journalists and End Impunity to shape discussion and deepen policy resonance around the key themes - Safety of Journalists enhanced. Within the framework of African Union, a Working Group on the Promotion and Protection of Journalism and the Safety of Journalists in Africa was established. National and regional networks and mechanisms were created in Palestine, Somalia, Myanmar, Pakistan, Tunisia and Eastern Africa. - UNESCO has enhanced the technical and editorial capacities of over 370 community radio stations in seven countries to serve diverse audiences - Member states capacity of Media and Information Literacy (MIL) has strengthened through workshops, curricula review and training. This has empowered 480 duty bearers, 300 teachers and 33 youth organisations. 193 countries have unanimously proclaimed Global MIL Week as official week at the 40th Session of the UNESCO General Conference on 25 November 2019, thereby committing UNESCO to assist Member States in their quest to advance MIL policy and practices - The endorsement by the IPDC Council of the use of the indicators for UNESCO’s Internet Universality ROAM (Rights, Openness, Accessibility to all, Multistakeholder participation) principles has contributed to the improvement of Internet policies and fostering of digital collaborations at international and regional levels. Thanks to programmatic work in this area, national assessment based on ROAM indicators have been undertaken in eight countries (Benin, Brazil, Ecuador, Kenya, Paraguay, Senegal, Tunisia and Uruguay) even though the original plan was for three countries. Training on the implementation of Internet indicators has been provided in six Latin American countries - A significant number of countries saw their capacities built or strengthened to effectively monitor and report on the safety of journalists at the national level (e.g. Colombia, Pakistan, Uganda, Vietnam). Five South-East Asian Member States (Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Timor-Leste) enhanced the capacity of their researchers to conduct assessments on journalists’ safety using the Journalists’ Safety Indicator (JSI) Framework. These advances help stimulate and nourish the creation of institutions mechanisms for protection of journalists and prosecution of perpetrator - Capacity were strengthened through the training of more than 2 800 judiciary operators from twelve Latin American countries in international and regional standards on freedom of expression, access to information and safety of journalists - Monitoring and reporting instruments for SDG indicator 16.10.2 (access to information) were designed in collaboration with the UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS) and expert organizations from all regions, to enable uniform and accurate comparison at global and national levels. Following UNESCO’s data collection exercise in January 2019, 43 countries collected and provided data at national level that fed into UNESCO’s Global Report on SDG 16.10.2, which mapped global progress for the first the time in a more comparable manner. As a result of this work, a worldwide survey (with the involvement of 69 countries) on the implementation of Access to Information laws was launched in early 2020 - Member States at the 74th UN General Assembly on 15 October 2019 decided to recognize 28 September as the International Day for Universal Access to Information (IDUAI) - 30 young female journalists from Gambia, who used to be marginalized within their newsrooms, have been empowered with new capacity to do journalism about development and over 80 female journalists in Uganda feel more secured in their reporting and advocating freedom of expression through gaining knowledge and skills that will ensure their safety offline and in online spaces. An educational programme in over 20 Latin American countries dedicated to building resilience among Caribbean journalists in the context of Climate Change - IPDC supported 42 projects aimed at strengthening the capacity of locally-owned media in Africa, Asia, and Latin America and the Caribbean. The projects involved stakeholders such as the Samoa Journalists Association, Asia-Pacific Broadcasting Union, various community radio partners, as well as journalism training institutions. The projects fostered quality journalism, coverage of climate change, advancement of gender equality in and through media, community participation through local media, enhancing media pluralism, and also strengthened media crisis preparedness. Over 203 journalists, editors, and media professionals received training - In line with the 2005 Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions (2005 Convention) spaces for dialogue and participatory processes are in place in 16 countries, gathering relevant actors (government, civil society, academia, private sector, media sector, women's ministries and organisations etc) for informed policy making and monitoring. The platforms include interministerial as well as regional cooperation. - Three “Create 2030” debates were organised at country-level (Mongolia, Uganda and Tanzania) as part of the project’s activities, reaching wider audiences and enhancing public dialogue for policy change. Create 2030 is a series of talks hosted by UNESCO to discuss how investments in creativity can have a direct impact on achieving the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. During 2020 a new concept of global debate was launched by UNESCO as a response to the Corona crises; ResiliArt - The Global monitoring framework for cultural expression was advanced. The 2005 Convention's monitoring framework was revised to have clear links to the Sustainable Development Goals. During 2020 two In Focus Reports on Artistic Freedom and Gender Equality was published in order to feed in to global debate on cultural policy - During 2020, the programme has swiftly adapted as a response to the Corona crises, with accentuated need for support to media houses, reliable information, mobility, safety and freedom of expression for cultural workers and journalists. New initiatives are on line training to more than 6000 media professionals in 163 countries in reporting about the pandemic, global conferences on the theme of Freedom of Expression in times of pandemic, Resiliart-talks - a global debate as how to best rescue the cultural sector, strengthening of a global fact checkers network, etc
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: UNESCO Freedom of Expression, Communication and Culture 2018-2021

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Extrabudgetärt stöd till UNESCOs sektioner för Yttrandefrihet, kommunikation och kultur 2018-2021 utifrån UNESCO's Strategi 39 C/5 samt till Unesco Institute for Statistics.
FN's organisation för utbildning, vetenskap och kultur - UNESCO - har genom fyra projektförslag sökt stöd från Sida för sin verksamhet när det gäller främjande av yttrandefrihet globalt, regionalt och nationellt genom två av sina verksamhetsområden; Kommunikation & Information samt Kultur. Ansökningspaketet består av två Special Accounts, dvs multigivarfonder för icke-öronmärkt flexibelt stöd till UNESCO's kärnverksamhet inom Kommunikation & Information samt två projektstöd som stöd till verksamhetsområdena kultur och statistik. Förslagen inkluderar: - Programdokument för "The Special Account for Freedom of Expression and the Safety of Journalists" från UNESCO's Communication & Information Sector - Programdokument för "The Special Account for the International Progarmme for Development of Communication" från UNESCO's Communication & Information Sector - Projektförslag "Reshaping Cultural Policies for the promotion of Fundamental Freedoms and the Diversity of Cultural Expressions" från UNESCO's Culture Sector - Projektförslag "Global Monitoring of Communication & Information" från UNESCO's Institute for Statistics
Sida ger stöd till UNESCO's normativa och operativa arbete för yttrandefrihet med det övergripande målet att skapa förutsättningar globalt för fri och självständig media, fritt och självständigt kulturliv, mångfald samt säkerhet för journalister. Verksamheten är både global och landspecifik, där globala komponenter i huvudsak är normativt orienterade och komponenter på landnivå fokuserar på kapacitetsutveckling, policyutveckling och implementering samt skapar arenor för dialog mellan ansvarstagare och civilsamhället. Verksamheten bedrivs genom ett sampel mellan det globala och landspecifika arbetet och genom synergier mellan de två verksamhetsområdena Kommunikation & Information samt Kultur. I fokus för verksamhet på landnivå är länder som präglas av ett demokratisk underskott, inklusive inskränkningar inom yttrandefrihet och brist på oberoende media och kulturliv. Jämställdhet är ett fokusområde för insatsen.
När det gäller det normativa arbetet globalt för yttrandefrihet och medieutveckling bidrar Kommunikation & Information-programmet (CI) i huvudsak till områdena säkerhet för journalister, yttrandefrihet online och offline, media literacy samt jämställdhet inom media. På landnivå bidrar programmet till landspecifika yttrandefrihetsinsatser i Afrika, MENA och Latinamerika inom lagstiftnings- och påverkansarbete samt kapacitetsbyggande insatser inom ICT, media, jämställdhet och journalistik, vilket är ett viktigt bidrag till att stärka demokratisering och yttrandefrihet i dessa länder. Programmet bidrar även till UNESCO's arbete med att utveckla globala indiktorer för media och internet genom IPDC - International Programme for the Development of Communication och UNESCO Institute for Statistics - UIS. CI-programmet kommer att stödjas genom två så kallade Multi-Donor Special Accounts i linje med en programansats för Sidas samarbete med UNESCO samt genom ett projektstöd till UIS.
Kulturprogrammet (CLT) är starkt förankrat i 2005 års UNESCO konvention för kulturell mångfald som har yttrandefrihet och jämställdhet som grundläggande principer. Kapacitetsutveckling på landnivå (16 länder) fokuserar på förståelse av konventionen och metoder för datainsamlig och uppföljning av konventionen, vilket bl a inkluderar bevakning av yttrandefrihet/kommunikation. Det globala normativa arbetet fokuserar på att dokumentera och formulera policies, standards och regleringar inom området. CLT-programmet stöds genom ett projektstöd.
Total budget för UNESCO's verksamheter 2018-2019 är för CI 185 MSEK och för CLT Expected Result 7 133,5 MSEK. Då står Regular Programme + Voluntary contributions för respektive 30% av CI och 75% av CLT. Ett flertal givare bidrar till det extrabudgetära stödet, ca 129 MSEK för CI, varav Sida 88 MSEK respektive 33,6 MSEK för CTL, varav Sida 28 MSEK. Därutöver är de största givarna EU, Världsbanken, Norge, Finland, Nederländerna, Kamerun och Schweiz.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Extrabudgetary support to UNESCO's sections on Communication and Information, and Culture
UNESCO has applied to Sida for funding to carry out its "Freedom of Expression, Communication and Culture Programme 2018-2021". The intervention aims at contributing to fostering freedom of expression at a global, regional and local level through two of its sections; Communication & Information and Culture.
Sida supports UNESCO's normative and operational work for freedom of expression with the overall objective to contibute to global conditions for free and independent media and cultural life including diversity of cultural expressions as well as safety for journalists. The work is both global and country specific, where global components are mainly normatively oriented while components on a country level focus on capacity building, policy development and implementation as well as create foras for dialogue between duty bearers and civil society. The programme is conducted through interplay between the global and country specific work and through synergies between the two sections' respective work, Communication & Information and Culture. In focus for the country work are countries characterized with democratic deficit, including restrictions on freedom of expression and lack of an independent media and cultural life. Gender equality is of main focus for the contribution.
For the global normative work for freedom of expression and media development is the Communication & Information Programme (CI) contributing to the areas of saftey for journalists, freedom of expression on line and offline, media literacy as well as gender in media. At a country level, the programme contributes to country specific freedom of expression projects in Africa, MENA and Latin America within the areas of justice and advocacy work and for capacity building projects within ICT, media, gender equality and journalism, which is an important contribution for the strengthening of democratization and freedom of expression in these countries. The programme also contributes to UNESCO's IPDC - Intenational Programme for the Development of Communication's and UIS - UNESCO's Institute for Statistics' work with the development of global indicators for media and Internet.
The Culture Programme (CLT) is strongly anchored in the UNESCO Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions 2005 with freedom of expression and gender equality as guiding principles. Capacity development at a country level (in 16 countries) focuses on the understanding of the Convention and methods for data collection and follow-up of the Convention, which includes monitoring freedom of expression and communication. The global normative work focuses on documentation and formulation of cultural policies, standards and legislation.

This intervention supports UNESCO's work on freedom of expression and 2005 Convention on culture diversity through the Communication and Information (CI) sector and the Culture (CLT) sector during the period 2018-2021. The main objectives correspond to expected results in the UNESCO's Medium Term Strategy for 2014-2021 (37 C/4) and Programme and Budget for 2018-2021 (39 C/5). The main objectives of the contribution are: Support to Communication and Information Sector: Outcome/expected result 1: Targeted Member States enhance legal and institutional frameworks related to the protection and promotion of freedom of expression online/offline, right of access to information and safety of journalists, in accordance with international standards (and UN Plan of Action on the Safety of Journalists and the Issue of Impunity) and through integrating a gender sensitive approach. Outcome/expected result 2: Member States have benefited from enhanced media contributions to diversity, gender equality and youth empowerment in and through media; and societies are empowered through media and information literacy programmes and effective media response to emergency and disaster. Outcome/expected result 3: Media development is strengthened, and Member States have improved monitoring and reporting systems, and these results are reinforced by external grass roots projects supported by the International Programme for the Development of Communication (IPDC). Support to the Culture Sector: Outcome/Expected result: Governments and civil society organizations engage in evidence-based and participatory policy making and monitoring processes in accordance with the principles and objectives of the 2005 Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions. Support to UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS): This is considered by Sida a pilot, with the aim of strengthening UIS' role and a coordinated work between CI, IPDC and UIS to contribute to data collection and statistics for freedom of expression and SDG 16.
The above objectives correspond directly to Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and contribute in particular to SDG 16:10 and its targets 16:10:1 and 16:10:2 and also SDG 4, 5, 9, 13. The support to the CI sector is channelled through two multi donor accounts, the Multidonor Programme for Freedom of expression and the Safety of Journalists and the Multidonor Special Account for the International Programme on Development Communication (IPDC). Key features of the programmes include support to the UN Action Plan for the Safety of Journalists and Issues of Impunity, The World Trends report on Freedom of Expression and Media Development, monitoring of SDG 16:10, Internet Universality Indicator Suite, to mention a few. Activities serve to promote the development, adoption and implementation of relevant policies and normative frameworks to strengthen the environment for freedom of expression and press freedom and to support sustainable and independent media institutions. Main activities to achieve the objectives of the intervention are to enhance legal and institutional frameworks, building on UNESCO's leverage to influence duty-bearers, including judges, legislature, parliamentarians, and law enforcement bodies. This is done through evidence based policy formulation and recommendations, technical expertise, capacity building and advocacy. At the same time media, journalists, artists, academia and civil society are enabled by UNESCO to take an active role in this work, by capacity building and multi-stakeholders platforms. Trainings differ for different context, but could include countering hate speech, conflict sensitive or gender sensitive reporting as well as elections covering. Activities also facilitate pluralism and participation in media, promote gender equality in both media production and content, and empower citizens with increased media and information literacy competencies. The support to the 2005 Convention supports governance and cultural policy making through capacity buidling of cultural policy makers, civil society organisations and other stakeholders. Also platforms for interaction between governments and civil society for monitoring the Convention and contributing to evidence based culture policy making. Freedom of expression is a guiding principle of the Convention and artistic freedom a monitoring pillar of the convention. Mechanisms for UNESCO to optimize its contribution globally, in targeted countries (16 for culture and more than 80 for media) and within the UN are so called flagship reports where international standards and norms, including UN Action Plans and Conventions, are implemented and followed up, used as reference and for accountability and standard setting. These include the "World Trends Report on Freedom of Expression and Media Development" and the 2005 Convention Global Report "Re:Shaping Cultural Policies". Another activity is to contribute to community media policies and to enhance Media Literacy. Global Standard setting, developing media indicators, is also part of UNESCO’s work. Awareness raising and networking is supported for instance by organising celebrations of international days such as World Press Freedom Day, International Day to End Impunity for Crimes against Journalists and World Day for Cultural Diversity for Dialogue and Development.

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Yttrandefrihet är en mänsklig rättighet och en av pelarna i en fungerande demokrati. Runt om i världen hotas medias frihet och enligt Freedom House har yttrandefriheten i världen minskat konsekvent och nu nått sin lägsta punkt på 13 år. Till och med i stora demokratier hotas journalister och auktoritära stater hittar nya vägar för att kontrollera media även utanför deras lands gränser. Internet och sociala medier har å ena sidan möjliggjort att journalister, informationsaktivister och vanliga individer kan nå ut med information snabbt, billigt och till en potentiellt mycket stor publik, å andra sidan har det också försett utländska och inhemska aktörer med en extremt användbar och billig plattform för spridandet av hat eller desinformation. I ett flertal länder behöver journalister och andra informationsaktivister riktat, kontinuerligt stöd för att motstå vissa myndigheters eller andra aktörers taktik för att censurera, snedvrida och blockera information.
Internews har inkommit med ett förslag till Sida om finansiering av deras Closed States Programme Strategi (2020-2024) med 75 MSEK. Close States Programme syftar till att stärka yttrandefriheten och tillgången till oberoende och ocensurerad information i flera av världens mest ofria länder. Detta kommer att ske genom att lokala journalister och informationsaktivister får kompetensutbildning och tillgång till ny teknik för att på ett säkert sätt upprätthålla produktionen och spridningen av oberoende, ocensurerad information och göra den tillgänglig genom nya och/eller traditionella medie- och kommunikationskanaler. Den övergripande målsättningen för programmet är att tillgången på högkvalitativ och oberoende information kommer att öka i dessa länder och att denna information kommer att nå 12 miljoner människor, samt att kapaciteten och hållbarheten hos de 50 lokala mediaaktörer kommer att stärkas genom skräddarsydda kapacitetsutbildningar vad det gäller produktion av högkvalitativ journalistik, organisatorisk färdighet och ekonomisk hållbarhet.
Sida avser att hantera och följa upp insatsens utveckling och resultat på programnivå. Dock kommer Sidas stöd att öronmärkas för särskilda poster i enlighet med bilagd budget. Skälet till detta är att andra givares projektstöd inom programmet inte svarar upp mot Sidas krav på kvalitetssäkring, varken avseende årlig revision eller tröskelvärden på revision av tredje part. Därav ser Sida sig nödgade att avtalsmässigt och revisionsmässigt hantera stödet som ett projektstöd med en öronmärkt Sida budget som årligen revideras. De andra stora givarna är Europeiska Kommissionen, Nederländerna, Frankrike och USA och dessa stödjer landspecifika projekt inom programmet.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Freedom of Expression is a Human Right and one of the pillars of Democracy. Freedom of Media across the globe is seriously declining. Monitoring undertaken by Freedom House shows media freedom has dropped to its lowest point in 13 years. Unprecedented threats to journalists and media outlets in major democracies and new moves by authoritarian states to control the media, including beyond their borders, are taking place. Social media on the one hand have allow ordinary people, civic groups, and journalists to reach a vast audience at little or no cost, but on the other hand it have also provided an extremely useful and inexpensive platform for malign influence operations by foreign and domestic actors alike. What was once a liberating technology has now also become a conduit for surveillance and electoral manipulation. In many countries journalists and other information activists need targeted, sustained support to withstand authorities’ tactics to censor, distort and block information.
Internews has submitted a proposal to Sida for funding of their Closed State Programme (CSP) Strategy (2020-2024) with 75,5 MSEK. The proposed programme aims to reach the most vulnerable populations in repressive authoritarian states and conflict affected areas of the globe with independent and uncensored information. This will be done by providing local journalists and other information activists with cutting edge skills and technologies to safely and securely sustain the production and dissemination of independent, uncensored information and make it available to their audiences through new or traditional media and communication channels.
Sida will monitor the development and the results of the support at programme level. Sida's support will, however, be earmarked for in accordance with the attached budget. The reason for this is that other donors' project support within the programme does not meet Sida's requirements for quality assurance, neither regarding annual audits nor thresholds for third party audits. As a result, Sida deems it necessary to manage the support in terms of contractual and audit terms as a project support with an earmarked Sida budget that is revised annually. The other major donors are the European Commission, the Netherlands, France and the United States and these support country-specific projects within the programme.

The Theory of Change for the Closed States Programme:
The Closed States Programme aims to reach 12 million people with information produced, by the 50 information providers strengthened through the programme.

description.narrative: Strategic Approach to International Chemicals Mana (SAICM) är en internationell, icke bindande, överenskommelse. Syftet är att bidra till att kemikalier hanteras på ett säkert sätt . Målet är att 2020 ska kemikalier hanteras på ett sätt så att hälsa och miljö inte skadas. Quick Start Program (QSP) är ett program för att u-länder ska komma igång med kemikaliearbetet.www.saicm.org

The Strategic Approach to International Chemicals Management, Quick Start Programme. SAICM is a policy framework to promote chemical safety around the world. Its overall objective the achievement of the sound management of chemicals throughout their life cycle so that, by 2020, chemicals are produced and used in ways that minimize significant adverse impacts on human health and the environment. Quick Start Program is a fund to kickstart developing countries.

"SAICM Quick Start Programme" var en tidsbegränsad förvaltningsfond (Trust Fund) som startades 2006 och avslutades i december 2019 och som administrerades av FN:s miljöprogram UNEP. Målet med programmet var att "stödja initial kapacitetsuppbyggnad för en hållbar kemikaliehantering och genomförandeaktiviteter i utvecklingsländer, minst utvecklade länder, önationer och länder med övergångsekonomier". Medel tilldelade programmet användes för att finansiera projekt i länder som syftade mot att uppnå en förbättrad kemikalie- och avfallshantering i enlighet med den den globala kemikaliestrategin: "Strategic Approach to International Chemicals Management (SAICM)". SAICM är ett internationellt policyramverk som antogs 2006 för hantering av kemikalier och avfall. Till skillnad från ett antal relaterade konventioner som behandlar enskilda kemikalier och avfallsfrågor tar SAICM alltså ett helhetsgrepp. SAICMs nuvarande mål går ut 2020 och en process är inledd för att ta fram en nya agenda för kemikalier och avfall: "SAICM Beyond 2020". Den processen är försenad på grund av Covid-pandemin. De internationella förberedelsemötena och kongresserna planeras att återupptas under andra halvåret 2021.

description.narrative: SAICM Quick Start Programme höll sin sista inbjudan till att söka medel från fonden 2015, varefter programmet sekretariat, baserat i Geneve, har förvaltat och följt upp de finansierade projekten tills dess att fonden formellt avslutades i december 2019. The Quick Start Programme Trust Fund har sedan starten 2006 beviljat medel till 184 projekt omfattande ca 38,5 MUSD i 108 länder varav 54 minst utvecklade länder eller små önationer. Den tematiska spännvidden på projekten har varit mycket bred, då SAICM till sin natur tar en bred ansats på kemikaliehantering. I stort sett alla projekt har avslutats helt, några få är i olika stadier av avslutning. En utvärdering publicerades i september 2015 vilken konkluderade att många goda resultat föreligger, men att det ofta förekom förseningar i projekten, att sekretariatet var underbemannat och att gender inte behandlades i tillräcklig utsträckning. Målet var att alla projekt skulle avslutas före årsskiftet 2018 och fonden avslutades 31 december 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Accountability in Tanzania Phase Two (AcT2) Programme is a five year £38m, innovative and exciting programme whose purpose is to increase the responsiveness and accountability of Government in Tanzania, through a strengthened civil society. AcT2 seeks to support civil society organisations (CSOs) to implement context-specific strategic interventions that will enable them to influence positive change in the attitudes and behaviour of citizens, civil society and government, making government as a whole more responsive and accountable. The second phase started in February 2018 and will end in December 2022. The programme funds mid-to-large sized Civil Society Organisations (CSOs) and is managed by KPMG Advisory Limited in Tanzania. The programme works with CSO partners supporting Tanzanian citizens to engage with and hold their government to account. This is crucial to fostering a well-functioning state that acts in the best interests of its people - in tackling corruption, efficient spending of public resources and delivering effective public services. The Tanzanian President has made anti-corruption his top priority. AcT2 partners seeks to deploy different tools and resources to equip citizens to challenge corruption rather than accept it. AcT2 programme underlines the need to bolster groups that can continue to champion pluralism, articulate the demands of citizens, and engage in constructive debate and negotiation with government. As an integrated and cohesive civil society offer, AcT2 enables DFID to deliver greater impact from our wider portfolio priorities in human development and sustainable growth teams and promoting democratic space. It will do this through focusing on governance blockages in these areas, with a focus on promoting accountability and social inclusion, especially focusing on gender, disability and youth/elderly groups. The programme has ambition to deploy different innovative approaches including policy research, advocacy, dialogue, experimentation, and brokering, and it will work with civil society, private sector actors, elected officials and faith-based groups. The four thematic priorities for the programme includes: • Civic Space (sector policy dialogues, media, voice, CS advocacy, human rights) • Social Inclusion (disability, women, girls and youth/elderly) • Anti-Corruption • Climate Change

title.narrative: Activity 05: Great Lakes Focal Points Meeting

description.narrative: The Great Lakes Region Focal Points Meeting involving National Committee (NC) members from both Anglophone and Francophone countries in the region was conducted through a series of activities that included: (I) A total of 6 zoom meetings focusing on IBV crosscutting themes; (ii) Research and production of 7 country-specific case studies; and (iii) Generation of regional strategies and recommendations (Francophone and Anglophone states) to facilitate collaboration among states, regional, and continental inter-governmental organizations. As part of adopting to the current programming challenges raised by COVID-19, the above events involved 29 Focal Persons selected from active members of the respective NC’s represented their respective countries.

title.narrative: COVID19 RESPONSE FOR THE UGANDAN NORTHERN TRANSPORT CORRIDOR

description.narrative: Amref Health Africa Uganda and Healthy Entrepreneurs-HE partner to support districts, health workers and communities along the Northern Transport Corridor to respond effectively to the virus. We aim to mobilize and build the capacity of a network of Village Health Teams (VHTs) and health workers along the northern transport corridor (Luwero, Nakasongola, Kiryandongo and Amuru to Elegu border) to scale up the efforts for increased awareness, prevention, control and management of COVID-19 and to support continuity of SRH and other related medical services. The intervention is proposed for a period of six months, working with ~4000 VHTs and ~132 health workers (HWs) from selected ~33 health facilities. The activities include: A) capacity building of VHTs for community mobilization, B) deployment of a dedicated and free surveillance support line for health workers (HWs), C) development and distribution of contextualized communication materials for Districts, VHTs, HWs and the general public, and dissemination of MOH continuity of essential services guidelines, D) procurement and distribution of PPEs for HWs and E) support coordination and technical support for districts.

title.narrative: Health Systems Advocacy Partnership: ACHEST activities in Zambia

description.narrative: ACHEST HSAP activities in Zambia from January to December 2017 Quarter 1 January - March Participated in a planning meeting for the launch of the joint HSAP Zambia Started the process of registering ACHEST as an organisation Held a planning meetings for a dissemination meeting of the baseline findings in the districts the study was conducted in. Quarter 2 April - June ACHEST trained and mentored Amref in Community Health Worker research activities. ACHEST took part in collecting and analysing the data in the Zambian context ACHEST Zambia reached out to the Zambia Centre for Applied Health Research and Development (ZCAHRD) country director, Dr Biemba and scheduled a meeting to discuss attendance of this very important capacity building workshop scheduled for August, 2017 in Kampala, Uganda hosted by ACHEST Uganda. Margarate from ACHEST met with Dr Biemba and information about the partnership, ACHEST Zambia and the capacity building workshop was shared. A representative from this organization who would attend the meeting was also suggested. A member of ACHEST attended the dissemination meeting based on community health worker research at Amref in Kenya Quarter 3 July - September ACHEST trained and mentored MeTA in their research on SRH commodities in August/September Held meeting with the Minister of Health on HR transfers- HRH distribution in general. This was a very fruitful meeting as information on the partnership was disseminated and possibilities for future collaborations discussed Held a meeting with Member of Parliament in September after interview regarding ACHEST work. This activity created a platform for ACHEST to lobby at parliamentary level for SRHR issues as the meeting established a relationship with some of the parliamentarians Quarter 4 October - December The highlight during this quarter was CSO training in lobby and advocacy. Held two CSO and Media Lobbying and Advocacy training workshops in In Kitwe at the Greek Olive and Lusaka at Mika Lodge. In November and December respectively. This activity was also an opportunity for ACHEST members to also gain more skills in advocacy and lobbying for evidence based policies, by holding discussions with these CSOs and media, and also share some information about research. 18 CSOs were trained with a total of 41 representatives 21 males and 20 females. ACHEST Zambia attended a meeting with Young Women in Action in order to get more acquainted with their activities. During the January-March 2018 period , ACHEST trained 15 CSOs in February 2018. The training was aimed at building capacity in research skills around Sexual and Reproductive Health among the CSOs and HSA partners. Of the 15 people trained, 6 were female. The HSA partnership held a meeting with the members of parliament. The main purpose of the meeting was to introduce the HSA partnership including ACHEST and advocate for HRH and availability and access to SRH commodities. In the meeting it was agreed that the members of parliament would join in advocating for SRHR

ACHEST activities will fall into three areas:- i) Creating evidence on which to base advocacy strategies through research ii) Developing the capacities of relevant stakeholders in lobby and advocacy ii) Lobby and advocacy for adequate HRH and financing and good governace. ACHEST Iception phase activities in Zambia in 2016 will focus on: 1.Establishing project management systems including governance, financial management, operations and communication 2.Engaging and introducing the project to stakeholders in Zambia through an inception workshop and face-to face meetings 3.Baseline and evidence gathering 4. Situation analysis on HRH in Zambia with special attention to the needs of SRH .5. Situation analysis for financing and governance 6. Mapping of SRHR CSOs active in Zambia. 7 Analysis of policy environment and data on status of performance of existing policies and initiatives. 8.Identification of gaps and opportunities for interventions in SRH and HRH

title.narrative: Leading the Charge to Eradicate Rural Poverty

description.narrative: Kenya Q1 2021 Country Update: At the end of 2020, we kicked off operations supporting the 2021 long rains season (corresponding to 2021 reporting), with enrollment concluding in October and delivery and planting beginning in most areas. COVID-19 continues to limit our operational capacity, but we are slowly reopening all field operations. While the team is working full-time in the field, they are working in small groups and through primarily 1-on-1 farmer follow-up rather than through large group meetings. We continue to regularly supply PPE (masks, soap, sanitizer) to keep the field team safe, and will revert to remote work if there is a concentration of COVID-19 in particular sites. Pests like locusts were an ongoing challenge over the last year, and we continue to monitor the situation closely.

Our prior project with the Dutch Government, “Subsistence to Self-Reliance – Bringing the Power of Markets to Africa’s Lowest-Income Farmers” underscored our shared passion for inclusive economic development and showcased the key milestones that we can accomplish together. Core operating support from DGIS facilitated the strategic expansion of One Acre Fund’s ‘impact ecosystem.’ Within two years, we doubled the scale of our farmer network, launched operations in two new country programs (Malawi and Uganda), and rolled out impactful new products like tree planting kits and clean cookstoves at country-wide scale. Simultaneously, we refined our innovative systems-change platform, leveraging our core organizational competencies to improve large-scale public and private actors’ service to smallholders. This success has now placed One Acre Fund in a position where we can realistically envision moving the needle on hunger and poverty across the entire African continent. Our current project with DGIS, “Leading the Charge to Eradicate Rural Poverty,” aims to capture this powerful opportunity. The project involves a smartly structured two-part investment spanning September 15, 2018 – December 31, 2022: First, DGIS is once again providing critical support to the varied, evolving platforms within our organization that lay the foundation for our growth and impact. Core operating support from DGIS will enhance and extend One Acre Fund’s proven model by funding key strategic priorities across our M&E, R&D, and new country expansion units. Secondly, DGIS is also providing working capital to revolutionize One Acre Fund’s growth trajectory. This injection to our ‘permanent fund’ will completely fund our projected expansion of 245,000+ new farm families in 2019, bringing us past the 1 millionth farmer milestone. Crucially, farmers’ loan repayments will replenish our permanent fund each year, allowing us to re-extend this contribution to provide input loans to an estimated 245,000 farm families (including over 980,000 children) annually. This project will anchor One Acre Fund’s expansion to directly serve 1.85 million farm families annually by year-end 2022. Simultaneously, it will help us reach an additional 3.5 million farmers via systems-change partnerships that are expressly designed to transform entire agricultural ecosystems. Together, the reach of these efforts will generate transformative change for rural communities across rural Africa.

activity-date.narrative: Note that while project activities commenced on 2016-01-01, the grant agreement was signed on 2018-10-09.
